div1.head: τάβλα
div1.sense: = Lat. tabula, a dice-table, Anth.

div1.head: ταβλιόπη
div1.sense: comic word, formed after Καλλιόπη, a game at dice, Anth.

div1.head: ταγεία
div1.sense: the office or rank of ταγός, Xen.

div1.head: ταγεύω
div1.sense: to be Chief of Thessaly, Xen.:— Pass. to be united under one ταγός, Xen.
Mid. to let soldiers be posted or stationed, Aesch.

div1.head: ταγέω
div1.sense: to be ruler, ἁπάσης Ἀσίδος τ. Aesch.

div1.head: τάγηνον
div1.sense: a frying-pan, saucepan, Ar., Luc.

div1.head: ταγή
div1.sense: an array, command:— collectively, ξύμφρων ταγά the chiefs of one mind, Aesch.

div1.head: τάγμα
div1.sense: that which has been ordered or arranged: esp.,
an ordinance, ἐκ δυοῖν τ. from a combination of two constitutions, Arist.
a body of soldiers, a regiment or brigade, Xen., etc.: —the Roman manipulus, Polyb.

div1.head: ταγός
div1.sense: a commander, chief, Aesch., Eur.
esp. the Chief of Thessaly, Xen.

div1.head: ταγοῦχος
div1.sense: holding command, Aesch.

div1.head: Ταίναρος
div1.sense: Taenarus, the southern point of Laconia, Pind., etc.: neut. Ταίναρον, ου, τό, Strab.

div1.head: ταινία
div1.sense: a band, riband, fillet, esp. a head-band, worn in sign of victory, Xen., Plat., etc.
a strip or tongue of land, Plut., etc.

div1.head: ταινιόπωλις
div1.sense: a dealer in ταινίαι, Dem.

div1.head: ταινιόω
div1.sense: to bind with a head-band, as a conqueror, Thuc., Xen.: Pass. to be crowned, Ar.

div1.head: τακερός
div1.sense: melting in the mouth, tender, Com.: of eyes, melting, languishing, Anth.

div1.head: τακτικός
div1.sense: fit for ordering or arranging, esp. in war, τ. ἀνήρ a tactician, Xen.; τακτικὸν ἡγεῖσθαί τι to think it a good piece of tactics, Xen.; οἱ τ. ἀριθμοί the regular battalions, Xen.: τὰ τακτικά the art of drawing up soldiers in array, tactics, Xen.

div1.head: τακτός
div1.sense: ordered, prescribed, τ. ἀργύριον a stated sum, Thuc.; σῖτος τ. a fixed quantity of corn, Thuc.; τ. ὁδός a prescribed way, Dem.

div1.head: ταλαεργός
div1.sense: enduring labour, drudging, of mules, Hom., Hes.; of Hercules, Theocr.

div1.head: ταλαιπωρέω
div1.sense: to go through hard labour, to suffer hardship or distress, Eur., Thuc., etc.
trans. to weary, wear out, Isocr.:—in Pass. to be worn out, be sore distressed, Ar., etc.

div1.head: ταλαιπωρία
div1.sense: hard work, hardship, suffering, distress, Thuc.; in pl. hardships, Hdt.
bodily suffering or pain, caused by disease, Thuc.

div1.head: ταλαίπωρος
div1.sense: suffering, miserable, Aesch., etc.:—adv. -ρως, Thuc.
of things, τ. βίος Soph.; πράγματα Ar.

div1.head: ταλαίφρων
div1.sense: suffering in mind, wretched, Soph., Eur.: daring, Soph.:—voc. ταλαῖφρον, Soph.

div1.head: ταλακάρδιος
div1.sense: patient of heart, stouthearted, of Hercules, Hes.: of Oedipus, much-enduring, miserable, Soph.

div1.head: ταλαντεύω
div1.sense: to weigh or measure out, Anth.

div1.head: ταλαντιαῖος
div1.sense: worth a talent, Dem.

div1.head: τάλαντον
div1.sense: a balance, Theogn., Ar.:—in pl. a pair of scales, Il., etc.
anything weighed,
a definite weight, a talent, in Hom. of gold; but the weight of the Homeric talent is unknown.

in later times the τάλαντον was both a weight and a sum of money represented by that weight of silver:—the Attic talent weighed about 57.75 lbs. avoird., and its value in our money was about 200 l. There was, of course, no such coin as a talent. For purposes of coinage, a talent of silver was coined into 6000 drachmae.

div1.head: ταλαντοῦχος
div1.sense: holding the balance: metaph., Ἄρης τ. who turns the scale in battle, Aesch.

div1.head: ταλαπείριος
div1.sense: subject to many trials, much-suffering, of Ulysses, Od.:—hence, vagrant, vagabond, Anth.

div1.head: ταλαπενθής
div1.sense: patient in woe, Od.

div1.head: ταλαρίσκος
div1.sense: quasillus, Theocr., Anth.

div1.head: τάλαρος
div1.sense: a basket, Lat. qualus, Od.; πλεκτὸς τάλ. a basket of wicker-work, in which new-made cheeses were placed so as to let the whey run off, Hom.

div1.head: ταλασία
div1.sense: wool-spinning, Xen., etc.

div1.head: ταλάσιος
div1.sense: of or for wool-spinning, Xen.

div1.head: ταλασιουργέω
div1.sense: to spin wool, Xen., Luc.

div1.head: ταλασιουργικός
div1.sense: of or for wool-spinning, Xen.

div1.head: ταλασιουργός
div1.sense: a wool-spinner, Plat.

div1.head: ταλασίφρων
div1.sense: patient of mind, stout-hearted, Il.; epith. of Ulysses, Hom.

div1.head: τάλας
div1.sense: suffering, wretched, Lat. miser, Od., Trag.; ὦ τάλας ἐγώ Soph.; ὦ τάλαινʼ ἐγώ Aesch.; ὦ τάλαν Soph.;—c. gen. causae, τάλαινʼ ἐγὼ τῆς ὕβρεως wretched that I am for this insolence, Ar.:—in bad sense, τάλαν wretch! Od.—comp. ταλάντερος, η, ον· Sup. ταλάντατος, η, ον, Ar.
div1.etym: ταλᾱς; Doric also ταλας: voc. τάλαν.

div1.head: ταλαύρινος
div1.sense: with shield of tough bullʼs-hide, Il.; τ. χρώς a thick tough hide, Anth.:— neut. as adv., ταλαύρινον πολεμίζειν to fight toughly, stoutly, Il.

div1.head: τᾶλις
div1.sense: a marriageable maiden, Soph.

div1.head: ταμεσίχρως
div1.sense: cutting the skin, wounding, Il.

div1.head: ταμία
div1.sense: a housekeeper, housewife, Hom., Xen.

div1.head: ταμίας
div1.sense: one who carves and distributes, a dispenser, Il., Pind., Ar.:—of Zeus, as the dispenser of all things to men, Il.; so Aeolus is τ. ἀνέμων Od.:—of kings or rulers, a controller, director, Pind.; τ. κώμων master of the revels, Pind.; τ. Διός the priest of Zeus, Pind.: τ. Μοισᾶν, i. e. a poet, Pind.; οἶκος τ. στεφάνων that hath store of crowns, Pind.; τῆς τε ἐπιθυμίας καὶ τῆς τύχης τ. controller both of his desire and of fortune, Thuc.; τ. τριαίνης, of Poseidon, Ar.
in Prose, a controller of payments, treasurer, Hdt.; τ. τοῦ ἱροῦ the controller of the sacred treasure in the citadel of Athens, Hdt.
at Rome, the quaestor, Plut.

div1.head: ταμιεία
div1.sense: stewardship, management, economy, Xen.
the office of paymaster, as a polit. term, Arist.
at Rome, the quaestorship, Plut.

div1.head: ταμιεῖον
div1.sense: a treasury, Thuc., etc.
a magazine, Xen.

div1.head: ταμιευτικός
div1.sense: of or for stewardship:—at Rome, belonging to the quaestorship, Plut.

div1.head: ταμιεύω
div1.sense: to be controller of receipts and expenditure, to be treasurer, paymaster, Ar., Dem.:—c. gen., τ. τῆς Παράλου to be paymaster of the Paralus, Dem.
at Rome, to be quaestor, Plut.

trans. to deal out, dispense, Plat., etc.:—Pass., τοὺς νόμους τεταμιεύμεθα we have the laws dealt out, Lys.:—Mid., ταμιεύεσθαι εἰς ὅσον βουλόμεθα ἄρχειν to control the limits to which we mean to extend our sway, Thuc.
of keeping house, to regulate, manage, Ar., Xen.:— Pass., χώρα ταμιευομένα τινί governed or possessed by one, Pind.
to store up, Dem.; Ζηνὸς ταμιεύεσκε γονάς she was the depository of it, Soph.

div1.head: τάμισος
div1.sense: rennet, Theocr.

div1.head: Ταναγραϊκή
div1.sense: the district of Tanagra, Plut.

div1.head: Ταναγραῖος
div1.sense: a man of Tanagra, Xen.

div1.head: Τάναγρα
div1.sense: a town of Boeotia, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: Ταναγρικός
div1.sense: of Tanagra, Hdt.

div1.head: ταναήκης
div1.sense: with long point or edge, Il.

div1.head: ταναίμυκος
div1.sense: far-bellowing, Anth.

div1.head: ταναόδειρος
div1.sense: long-necked, Ar.

div1.head: ταναός
div1.sense: stretched, outstretched, tall, long, taper, Il.; πλόκαμος τ. long flowing locks, Eur.; τ. αἰθήρ outspread ether, Eur.; τ. γῆρας long old age, Anth.

div1.head: ταναύπους
div1.sense: stretching the feet, long-striding, longshanked, Hhymn., Od.

div1.head: ταναῶπις
div1.sense: far-sighted, Emped.

div1.head: τανηλεγής
div1.sense: laying one out at length, epith. of death, Hom.

div1.head: Τάνις
div1.sense: a town in lower Egypt, the Hebrew Zoan, Strab.:— ὁ Τανίτης, νόμος the Tanite nome, Hdt.

div1.head: τᾶν
div1.etym: only in phrase, ὦ τᾶν or ὦ τάν
div1.sense: sir, my good friend, Soph., Eur., Plat., etc.; used in addressing several persons, ὦ τᾶν, ἀπαλλαχθῆτον Ar.

div1.head: Ταντάλειος
div1.sense: of or belonging to Tantalus, Eur.

div1.head: Τανταλίδης
div1.sense: son of Tantalus, Aesch.

div1.head: Τανταλίς
div1.sense: daughter of Tantalus, i. e. Niobe, Anth.
div1.etym: From *τλάω, prob. in relation to his long endurance of torment.

div1.head: τανταλόομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to be balanced or swung, ἐπὶ γᾷ πέσε τανταλωθείς fell with a swing upon earth, Soph.

div1.head: Τάνταλος
div1.sense: Tantalus, king of Phrygia, ancestor of the Pelopidae, Od.

div1.head: τανύγλωσσος
div1.sense: long-tongued, chattering, Od.

div1.head: τανυγλώχις
div1.sense: with long point, Il.

div1.head: τανύδρομος
div1.sense: running at full stretch, Aesch.

div1.head: τανυέθειρα
div1.sense: with flowing hair, Pind.

div1.head: τανυήκης
div1.sense: like ταναήκης, with long point or edge, Hom.
tapering, Il.

div1.head: τανυῆλιξ
div1.sense: of extended age, Anth.

div1.head: τανύθριξ
div1.sense: long-haired, shaggy, Hes.

div1.head: τάνυμαι
div1.sense: Pass., to be stretched, Il.

div1.head: τανυμήκης
div1.sense: long-stretched, tall, ἰτέαι Anth.

div1.head: τανῦν
div1.sense: now, at present, v. νῦν I.

div1.head: τανύπεπλος
div1.sense: with flowing peplos, Hom.

div1.head: τανύπλεκτος
div1.sense: in long plaits, Anth.

div1.head: τανύπλευρος
div1.sense: long-sided, enormous, Anth.

div1.head: τανύπτερος
div1.etym: shorter form of τανυσίπτερος, Hes., Pind.

div1.head: τανύρριζος
div1.sense: with far-stretching roots, Hes.

div1.head: τανυσίπτερος
div1.sense: with extended wings, long-winged, Od., Hes., Ar.

div1.head: τανυστύς
div1.sense: a stretching, stringing, Od.

div1.head: τανύσφυρος
div1.sense: with taper ancles, Hes.

div1.head: τανύφλοιος
div1.sense: of trees, with long-stretched bark, i. e. of tall or slender growth, Il.

div1.head: τανύφυλλος
div1.sense: with long-pointed leaves, of the olive, Od.
with thick foliage, leafy, Theocr.

div1.head: τανύω
div1.sense: to stretch, strain, stretch out, Il.; τ. βιόν to string a bow, Od.; and in Mid., τόξον τανυσσάμενος having strung his bow, Il.:—of putting the strings to a harp, ἐτάνυσσε χορδήν Od.; τ. κανόνα to push the weaving-bar tight, i. e. to weave, Il.; ὅπως τανύσηι when he reins in [the horses], Il.; ἐπὶ Ἀκράγαντι τανύσσας (sc. ὀϊστούς) having aimed them, Pind.:—Pass., γναθμοὶ τάνυσθεν (for ἐτανύσθησαν) the hollow cheeks filled out, Od.; to run at full stretch, of horses galloping, Hom.
metaph. to strain, make more intense, μάχην Il.; ἔριδα πολέμοιο πεῖραρ τάνυσσαν strained the tug of war, Il.

to stretch out, lay along, lay, Hom.; τ. τινὰ ἐν κονίηις, ἐπὶ γαίηι to lay one in the dust, stretch him at his length, Hom.:—Pass. to lie stretched out, Hom.: to extend, Od.; ἐπὶ χθονὶ κεῖτο τανυσθείς Il.:—also, τρίβος τετάνυστο the path stretched away, Theocr.

div1.head: ταξιαρχέω
div1.sense: to be a taxiarch, Ar., Thuc., etc.

div1.head: ταξιαρχία
div1.sense: the office of taxiarch, Arist.

div1.head: ταξίαρχος
div1.sense: the commander of a squadron, Hdt.
at Athens, the commander of a τάξις ( I. 4), the corresponding cavalry- officers being φύλαρχοι, Ar.: generally an officer, Xen.

div1.head: ταξίλοχος
div1.sense: commanding a λόχος or division, Anth.

div1.head: ταξιόομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to engage in battle, Pind.

div1.head: τάξις
div1.sense: an arranging:
in military sense:
a drawing up, the order or disposition of an army, Thuc., Xen., etc.; τὰ ἀμφὶ τάξεις tactics, Xen.
battle array, order of battle, Lat. acies, κατὰ τάξιν Hdt.; ἐν τάξει Thuc., etc.
a single rank or line of soldiers, Lat. ordo, ἐπὶ τάξεις ὀλίγας γίγνεσθαι to be drawn up a few lines deep, Thuc.

a body of soldiers, a squadron, Aesch., Soph.: at Athens, the quota of infantry furnished by each φυλή (cf. ταξίαρχος II), Lys.: of smaller bodies, a company, cohort, Xen.; so of ships, a squadron, Aesch.:—generally, a band, company, Aesch.
a post or place in the line of battle, Lat. statio, Hdt.; μένειν ἐν τῇ ἑωυτοῦ τάξει, opp. to ἐκλείπειν τὴν τ., Hdt.
generally, an arrangement, order, Plat., etc.
order, regularity, Plat.
τ. τοῦ φόρου an assessment of tribute, Xen.: an arrangement with creditors, Lex ap. Dem.
a political order, a constitution, Arist.
metaph. from I. 5, the post or position one holds, Aesch., etc.; ἐν Θετταλῶν τάξει, ἐν ἐχθροῦ τ. viewed as Thessalians, as an enemy, Dem.; ἐν ἐπηρείας τάξει by way of insult, Dem.
oneʼs duty towards another, ἡ ὑπέρ τινος τ. Dem.; ἡ εὐνοίας τ. the duty of good-will, Dem.
a class of men, as of magistrates, Xen., Dem.

div1.head: τάξος
div1.sense: the yew-tree, Lat. taxus.

div1.head: ταπεινός
div1.sense: low:
of Place, lying low, Hdt.; ταπεινὰ νέμεσθαι to live in low regions, Pind.; of stature or size, low, Xen.

of the condition of persons, brought down, humbled, submissive, Hdt., Aesch., etc.: of low rank, lowly, mean, Lat. vilis, Eur., etc.: small, poor, weak, Eur., Dem.:—adv., ταπεινῶς πράττειν to be poorly off, Isocr.
of the spirits, humbled, dejected, Thuc., Xen.
in moral sense, partly bad, mean, base, abject, Xen., etc.; partly good, lowly, humble, Xen., NTest.
of things, mean, low, poor, τ. σχῆμα mean apparel, Xen.: of style, low, poor, Arist.; adv., ταπεινῶς λέγειν Arist.

div1.head: ταπεινότης
div1.sense: lowness of stature, Hdt.
of condition, low estate, abasement, Thuc., Isocr.
lowness of spirits, dejection, Xen.
in moral sense, baseness, vileness, Plat.

div1.head: ταπεινοφροσύνη
div1.sense: lowliness, humility, NTest.

div1.head: ταπεινόφρων
div1.sense: lowly in mind, Plut.

div1.head: ταπεινόω
div1.sense: to lower:—Pass., πᾶν ὄρος ταπεινωθήσεται NTest.
metaph. to lessen, τὸν φθόνον Plut.: to disparage, Polyb.
to humble, abase, Xen., Aeschin.:—Pass., Plat., Xen.
in moral sense, to make lowly, to humble, NTest.:—Pass. to humble oneself, NTest.

div1.head: ταπείνωσις
div1.sense: humiliation, abasement, defeat, Plat.
low estate, low condition, NTest.

div1.head: τάπης
div1.sense: a carpet, rug, Lat. tapes, Hom., Ar.

div1.head: ταπρῶτα
div1.sense: at first, Il.

div1.head: τάραγμα
div1.sense: disquietude, Eur.

div1.head: ταραγμός
div1.sense: disturbance, confusion, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: ταρακτικός
div1.sense: disturbing, c. gen., τῆς ψυχῆς Plut.

div1.head: τάρακτρον
div1.sense: a tool for stirring with, Ar. ταράκτωρ, ὁ, poet. for ταράκτης, Aesch.

div1.head: Ταραντῖνος
div1.sense: Tarentine, Strab.; T., a Tarentine, Hdt.

div1.head: ταραξικάρδιος
div1.sense: heart-troubling, Ar.

div1.head: ταραξιππόστρατος
div1.sense: troubling the horse-array, of Cleon as a foe to the Ἱππεῖς, Ar.

div1.head: Τάρας
div1.sense: Tarentum, a town of Magna Graecia, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: ταράσσω
div1.sense: to stir, stir up, trouble, in a physical sense, ἐτάραξε πόντον Od.; ὁμοῦ τ. τήν τε γῆν καὶ τὴν θάλατταν Ar.; βροντήμασι κυκάτω πάντα Aesch.; πάντα τ., of a speaker, to jumble up, Dem.; δεινὰ τ. makes "confusion worse confounded," Soph.
to trouble the mind, confound, agitate, disturb, disquiet, Trag., Plat., etc.: absol. to cause confusion, Plat.
of an army, to throw into disorder, Hdt., Xen., etc.:—Pass. to be in disorder, Hdt., Thuc.
of political matters, to agitate, distract, Ar.:—Pass. to be in a state of disorder or anarchy, Thuc., Dem.
ταράττεσθαι ἐπὶ τῶν ἵππων to be shaken in oneʼs seat on horseback, Xen.
to stir up mud, raise by stirring up, Ar.: metaph., τ. νεῖκος, πόλεμον Soph., Plat.; Pass., πόλεμος ἐταράχθη Dem.
intr. perf. τέτρηχα, to be in disorder or confusion, be in an uproar, τετρήχει δʼ ἀγορή Il.; ἀγορὴ τετρηχυῖα Il.

div1.head: ταραχή
div1.sense: trouble, disorder, confusion, Pind., Thuc., etc.
of an army or fleet, Thuc., etc.; ἐν τῇ ταραχῇ in the confusion, Hdt.
political confusion, tumult, and in pl. tumults, troubles, Hdt., Attic; τ. γίγνεται τῶν ξυμμάχων πρὸς τοὺς Λακεδαιμονίους Thuc.

div1.head: ταραχώδης
div1.sense: troublous, turbulent, Hdt.; ἴχνη τ. uncertain, baffling, Xen.
troubled, disordered, Arist.
of an army, Thuc., Xen.
adv., ταραχωδῶς ζῆν to live in a state of confusion, Isocr.; τ. ἔχειν πρός τινα to be rebelliously disposed, Dem.; Sup. -έστατα Isocr.

div1.head: ταρβαλέος
div1.sense: frighted, fearful, Hhymn., Soph.

div1.head: ταρβέω
div1.sense: intr. to be frightened, alarmed, terrified, Hom.; τ. φόβῳ Soph., Eur.:— absol. to shew fear, Il., Aesch.; τὸ ταρβεῖν a state of fear, Eur.; μή με ταρβήσας προδῷς from fear, Soph.; τεταρβηκώς fear-stricken, Eur.
c. acc. to fear, dread, Il., Aesch., etc.
to stand in awe of, revere, Aesch.

div1.head: τάρβος
div1.sense: fright, alarm, terror, Il., Trag., etc.
awe, reverence, τινός for one, Aesch.
an object of alarm, a fear, alarm, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: ταρβόσυνος
div1.sense: affrighted or affrighting, Aesch.

div1.head: ταριχεία
div1.sense: a preserving, pickling: in pl., αἱ Ταριχεῖαι factories for salting fish, Hdt., Strab.

div1.head: ταρίχευσις
div1.sense: embalming, of mummies, Hdt.
pickling, salting, of fish, Hdt.

div1.head: ταριχευτής
div1.sense: an embalmer, of mummies, Hdt.

div1.head: ταριχεύω
div1.sense: to preserve the body by artificial means, to embalm, of the Egyptian mummies, Hdt., Plat.
to preserve meat or fish by salting, pickling, or smoking, Plat.:—Pass., ἰχθύας ἐξ ἅλμης τεταριχευμένους Hdt.; τεμάχη τεταριχευμένα preserved meat, Xen.
metaph. in Pass. to shrivel up, Aesch.; τεταριχευμένος stale, Dem.

div1.head: ταριχοπώλιον
div1.sense: the salt-fish market, Theophr.

div1.head: ταριχοπωλέω
div1.sense: to sell salt fish, Plat.
to be engaged with the embalming of corpses, Luc.

div1.head: ταριχοπώλης
div1.sense: a dealer in salt fish, Plut., etc.

div1.head: τάριχος
div1.sense: a dead body preserved by embalming, a mummy, Hdt.
meat or fish preserved by salting, pickling, or smoking, Hdt.

div1.head: ταρσός
div1.sense: a stand or frame of wicker-work, a crate, Lat. cratis, Od., Thuc.:— generally, a basket, Ar.
a mat of reeds, built into brickwork to bind it together, Hdt.
any broad flat surface, as,
τ. ποδός the flat of the foot, the part between the toes and the heel, Il., Hdt.
τ. κωπέως the flat or blade of an oar, Lat. palmula, Hdt.: absol. an oar, Eur.:—in collective sense, the oars on one side of a ship, Thuc.
τ. πτέρυγος the flat of the wing, a wing, Anth.: of a peacockʼs tail, Mosch.

div1.head: Ταρτάρειος
div1.sense: Tartarean, horrible, Eur., Luc.

div1.head: Τάρταρος
div1.note: Τάρτᾰρος, ἡ· heterocl. pl. Τάρταρα, ων, τά,
div1.sense: Tartarus, a dark abyss, as deep below Hades as earth below heaven, the prison of the Titans, Il., Hes., etc.:—later, the nether world, like Ἅιδης, Hes., Aesch.

div1.head: Ταρταρόω
div1.sense: to cast into Tartarus or hell, NTest.

div1.head: Ταρτήσσιος
div1.sense: Tartessian, Hdt., Ar.

div1.head: Ταρτησσός
div1.sense: a city of Spain at the mouth of the Baetis, the Tarshish of Scripture, Hdt., Strab.

div1.head: τάρφος
div1.sense: a thicket, Il.

div1.head: ταρφύς
div1.sense: thick, close, Aesch.; pl. masc. and neut., like Lat. frequentes, ταρφέες ἰοί thick-flying arrows, Il.; ταρφέα δράγματα Il.:— neut. pl. ταρφέα as adv. ofttimes, often, Hom.:— ταρφειαί in Il. must belong to a nom. ταρφειός, unless we write ταρφεῖαι, from ταρφύς.

div1.head: ταρχύω
div1.sense: to bury solemnly, Il.

div1.head: τάσις
div1.sense: tension, intensity, force, Plut.; Ὀφρύων τ. a raising of the eye-brows, Anth.

div1.head: τάσσω
div1.sense: to arrange, put in order, Hdt., etc.: esp. to draw up in order of battle, to form, array, marshal, both of troops and ships, Hdt., Thuc., etc.:—Pass. to be drawn up, Hdt.; ἐπὶ τεττάρων ταχθῆναι in four lines, Xen.; κατὰ μίαν τεταγμένοι in single column, Thuc.: absol., τεταγμένοι in rank and file, opp. to ἄτακτοι, Thuc., etc.:—Mid. to fall in, form in order of battle, Thuc.
to post, station, Hdt., Aesch., etc.:—Pass., Hdt., etc.; ἐς τὸ πεζόν or ἐς π. τετάχθαι or ταχθῆναι to serve among the infantry, Hdt.; c. acc. cogn., τάξιν τινὰ ταχθῆναι Plat.

to appoint to any service, military or civil, τ. τινὰ ἐπί τινος one over a thing, to a service or task, Dem., etc.; ἐπί τινι Aesch., etc.; ἐπί τι Ar., etc.; πρός τι Xen.:—Pass., τετάχθαι ἐπί τινι to be appointed to a service, Hdt., etc.; ἐπί τι Ar.
c. acc. et inf. to appoint one to do a thing, Xen.; and in Pass. to be appointed to do Aesch., etc.:—also (sine inf.), οἱ τεταγμένοι βραβεῖς Soph.; πρέσβεις ταχθέντες Dem.

c. acc. et inf. also, to order one to do a thing, Hdt., Soph., etc.; also, τ. τινὶ ποιεῖν τι Hdt., etc.:—Pass., ἐτάχθην or τέταγμαι ποιεῖν τι Hdt.:—also impers., ἴωμεν, ἵνʼ ἡμῖν τέτακται (sc. ἰέναι) Soph.; οἷς ἐτέτακτο βοηθεῖν Thuc.
to assign to a class, τ. εἰς τάξιν τινά Xen.; τ. ἑαυτόν τινων to act as one of a set, Dem.:—Pass., πρὸς τὴν ξυμμαχίαν ταχθῆναι to join it, Thuc.
c. acc. rei, to place in a certain order, χωρὶς τ. τι Hdt.; πρῶτον τ. τι Xen.
to appoint, ordain, order, prescribe, Soph., Plat.:—Pass., τὸ ταχθέν Soph.; τὰ τεταγμένα Xen.

of taxes or payments, to appoint or fix a certain payment, τ. τινὶ φόρον Aeschin., etc.; with an inf. added, χρήματα τάξαντες φέρειν Thuc.; τάσσειν ἀργυρίου to fix the price, Thuc.:—Pass., τὸ ταχθὲν τίμημα Plat.:—Mid. to take a payment on oneself, i. e. agree to pay it, φόρον τάξασθαι Hdt.; χρήματα ἀποδοῦναι ταξάμενοι Thuc.
in Mid., also, generally, to agree upon, settle, Plat.
to impose punishments, τ. δίκην Ar.; τιμωρίαν Dem.:—so in Mid., Hdt.
in perf. part. pass. fixed, prescribed, ὁ τεταγμένος χρόνος Hdt., etc.; ἡ τετ. ἡμέρα, ἔτος Xen., etc.; ἡ τετ. χώρα Xen.

div1.head: Ταΰγετον
div1.sense: Mount Taygetus, between Laconia and Messenia, Od., Hdt., etc.

div1.head: τ
div1.sense: Τ, τ, ταῦ, τό, indecl., nineteenth letter of the Gr. alphabet: as numeral τʹ 300, but ͵τ 300,000.
τ is the tenuis dental mute, related to the medial δ and the aspirate θ.
Changes of τ:
Aeolic and Doric, τ for ς, as τύ (Lat. tu, thou) for σύ; τοί τέ τῦκον φατί for σοί σέ σῦκον φησί.
in new Attic, as in Doric and Boeot., ττ for σς, mostly in Verbs, πράττω for πράσσω, etc.
in Ionic the tenius τ for its aspirate θ, as αὖτις for αὖθις; so, the tenuis remains unchanged before an aspirate, as κατεῖλον, κατʼ ἡσυχίην.
the Poets, metri grat., insert τ after π at the beginning of some words, e. g. πτόλις, πτόλεμος.

div1.head: ταῦ
div1.sense: the letter τ, Plat.

div1.head: ταύρειος
div1.sense: of bulls, oxen, or cows, Lat. taurinus, Trag.
of bullʼs-hide, Il.

div1.head: ταυρελάτης
div1.sense: a bull-driver:—a Thessalian bull-fighter, tauridor, Anth.

div1.head: ταύρεος
div1.sense: epith. of Poseidon in Boeotia, because bulls were offered to him, Hes.

div1.head: ταυρηδόν
div1.sense: like a bull, savagely, Ar., Plat.

div1.head: ταυροβόλος
div1.sense: slaughtering bulls, τελετὴ τ. a sacrifice of a bull, Anth.

div1.head: ταυροβόρος
div1.sense: devouring bulls, Anth.

div1.head: ταυρογάστωρ
div1.sense: with bullʼs paunch: metaph. enormous, Anth.

div1.head: ταυροδέτης
div1.sense: bull-binder, in fem. -δέτις, ιδος, Anth.

div1.head: ταυρόκερως
div1.sense: bull-horned, Eur.

div1.head: ταυροκτονέω
div1.sense: to slaughter bulls, Aesch.

div1.head: ταυροκτόνος
div1.sense: slaughtering bulls, Soph.

div1.head: ταυρόμορφος
div1.sense: bull-formed, Eur.

div1.head: ταυρόομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to become savage as a bull, Aesch., Eur.; ταυροῦσθαι ὄμμα τινί to cast savage glances on one, Eur.

div1.head: ταυροπάτωρ
div1.sense: sprung from a bull, of bees, Theocr.

div1.head: ταυροπόλος
div1.sense: a name of Artemis, —either worshipped at Tauris, or hunting bulls, Eur.;—so ταυροπόλα (Doric for -πόλη) , Soph.

div1.head: ταυρόπους
div1.sense: bull-footed, Eur.

div1.head: ταῦρος
div1.sense: a bull, Hom., etc.: also ταῦρος βοῦς, like σῦς κάπρος, κίρκος ἵρηξ, Il.:— ἄπεχε τῆς βοὸς τὸν ταῦρον, oracularly of Agamemnon and his wife, Aesch.

div1.head: ταυροσφαγέω
div1.sense: to cut a bullʼs throat, τ. ἐς σάκος to cut its throat (so that the blood runs) into a hollow shield, Aesch.

div1.head: ταυροσφάγος
div1.sense: bull-slaughtering, sacrificial, Soph.

div1.head: ταυροφάγος
div1.sense: bull-eating, Ar.

div1.head: ταὐτοκλινής
div1.sense: under the same climate, Strab.

div1.head: ταὐτολόγος
div1.sense: tautologous, Anth.

div1.head: ταὐτόματον
div1.sense: a chance, ἀπὸ ταὐτομάτου spontaneously, by chance, Thuc., Plat.

div1.head: ταὐτοποιέω
div1.sense: to do the same with, τινί Arist.

div1.head: ταὐτότης
div1.sense: identity, Arist.

div1.head: ταφεύς
div1.sense: a burier, Lat. vespillo, Soph.

div1.head: ταφήϊος
div1.etym: Ionic for ταφεῖος which is not used.
div1.sense: of or for a burial, τ. φᾶρος a winding-sheet, shroud, Od.

div1.head: ταφή
div1.sense: burial, Lat. sepultura, Hdt.: mode of burial, Hdt.
in pl. also, a burial-place, Hdt., Soph.;—in sg., σῆς εἰ στερήσομαι ταφῆς, of the urn supposed to contain the ashes of Orestes, Soph.
payment for burial, a burial-fee, Dem.

div1.head: τάφιος
div1.sense: τ. λίθος a grave stone. Anth.

div1.head: τάφος
div1.sense: a burial, funeral, Lat. funus Hom., Soph., etc.; δαινύναι τάφον to give a funeral-feast, Hom.
the act of burying, Soph.
the grave itself, tomb, Hes., Hdt., etc.;—in pl. of a single grave, Hdt., Soph.; ὄντες ἐν τάφοις though dead and buried, Aesch.; οἱ πατρὸς τάφοι his being buried, Soph.
ἔμψυχός τις τ. a "living skeleton, " Luc.

div1.head: τάφος2
div1.sense: astonishment, amazement, Od.

div1.head: ταφρεία
div1.sense: a making of ditches or trenches, Dem.

div1.head: ταφρεύω
div1.sense: to make a ditch, Xen., Aeschin.

div1.head: τάφρος
div1.sense: a ditch, trench, Hom., etc.; τάφρον ὀρύσσειν Il., etc.; τ. ἐλαύνειν to draw a trench, Il.

div1.head: τάχα
div1.sense: quickly, presently, forthwith, Lat. statim, Hom., etc

perhaps, Plat., etc.:—so also τάχʼ ἄν probably, perhaps, may be, with opt., Hdt., Attic:— τάχʼ ἄν alone, in answers, Plat., etc.:— strengthd., ἴσως τάχα Xen.; τάχα τοίνυν ἴσως Dem.; τάχʼ ἂν ἴσως Soph., etc.
for comp. τάχιον, Sup. τάχιστα, v. ταχύς c.

div1.head: τάχος
div1.sense: swiftness, speed, fleetness, velocity, Il., Plat.
τ. φρενῶν quickness of temper, hastiness, Eur.

τάχος is often used in Adverbial phrases for ταχέως, absol. in acc., Aesch., etc.: —with Preps., ἀπὸ τάχους Xen.; διὰ τάχους Soph., etc.; ἐν τάχει Aesch., etc.; εἰς τάχος Xen., etc.; κατὰ τάχος Hdt., Thuc.; μετὰ τάχους Plat.; σὺν τάχει Soph.:—also with relatives, ὡς τάχος, like ὡς τάχιστα, Hdt., Aesch.; so, ὅ τι τάχος Hdt., Soph.; ὅσον τάχος Soph.:—also, ὡς τάχεος εἶχεν ἕκαστος as each was off for speed, i. e. as quickly as they could, Hdt.; ὡς εἶχον τάχους Thuc.

div1.head: ταχυάλωτος
div1.sense: conquered quickly or easily, Hdt.

div1.head: ταχυβάτης
div1.sense: fast-walking, Eur.

div1.head: ταχύβουλος
div1.sense: hasty in counsel, Ar.

div1.head: ταχύδακρυς
div1.sense: soon moved to tears, Luc.

div1.head: ταχυεργία
div1.sense: quickness in working, Xen.

div1.head: ταχύμηνις
div1.sense: swift to anger, Anth.

div1.head: ταχύμορος
div1.sense: quickly dying, shortlived, Aesch.

div1.head: ταχυναυτέω
div1.sense: to sail fast, Thuc.

div1.head: ταχύνω
div1.sense: to make quickly, Soph.; τοῖα σπερχόμενος ταχύνει such are the words which in his eager haste he speaks, Eur.
intr. to be quick, to make haste, speed, hurry, Aesch., Soph., Xen.

div1.head: ταχυπειθής
div1.sense: soon persuaded, credulous, Theocr.

div1.head: ταχύπορος
div1.sense: quick of motion, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: ταχύπους
div1.sense: swift-footed, Eur., Ar.

div1.head: ταχύπτερνος
div1.sense: swift-footed, Theogn.

div1.head: ταχύπτερος
div1.sense: swift-winged, Aesch.

div1.head: ταχύπωλος
div1.sense: with fleet, swift horses, Il.

div1.head: ταχύρροθος
div1.sense: swift-rushing, Aesch.

div1.head: ταχύρρωστος
div1.sense: swift-rushing, Soph.

div1.head: ταχύς
div1.sense: of motion, quick, swift, fleet, opp. to βραδύς, Hom., etc.; ταχὺς πόδας Il.; ταχὺς θείειν Hom.
of thought and purpose, quick, rapid, hasty, φρονεῖν γὰρ οἱ ταχεῖς οὐκ ἀσφαλεῖς Soph.; c. inf., βλάπτειν τ. Ar.; τὸ ταχύ speed, haste, Eur.
so of actions, events, quick, rapid, sudden, πήδημα Soph.; πόλεμος Thuc.; τ. ἐλπίδες fleeting hopes, Pind.
adv.,
regul. form ταχέως, quickly, Il., Attic
the adv. is also expressed by periphr., διὰ ταχέων in haste, Thuc., etc.; ἐκ ταχείας Soph.; cf. τάχος II.
neut. ταχύ as adv., Soph., etc.; more often τάχα (q. v.).
Degrees of Comparison:
comp.:
regul. form ταχύτερος, η, ον, Hdt.

θάσσων, neut. θᾶσσον, gen. ονος, new Attic θάττων, neut. θᾶττον, Hom., Attic:—neut. as adv., Hom., etc.; θᾶσσον ἂν κλύοιμι sooner, i. e. rather, would I hear, Soph.; θᾶσσον also, like Lat. ocius, often stands for the Positive, οὐ θᾶσσον οἴσεις; i. e. make haste and bring, Soph.; ὅ τι θᾶσσον, like ὅ τι τάχιστα, Theocr.; ἐπειδὰν θ. Plat.
the form ταχίων [ῑ], neut. ιον, is rare in good Attic
the regular Sup. ταχύτατος, is rare, Pind.; ταχύτατα as adv., Xen.

the usual form is τάχιστος, η, ον , mostly in neut. pl. τάχιστα as adv., ὅττι τάχιστα as soon as possible, Lat. quam celerrime, Il.; Attic ὅ τι τάχιστα Soph., etc.:—so, ὅσον τ. Aesch.; ὡς τ. Hdt., Attic; ὅπως τ. Aesch., etc.:—these are ellipt. phrases, for ὡς δυνατὸν τ. Hdt.; ὡς or ᾗ ἂν δύνωμαι τ. Xen., etc.:—also after Particles of Time, like Lat. quum primum, ἐπεί (Ionic ἐπείτε) τάχιστα Hdt., Attic; ἐπειδὴ τ. Plat., etc.; ἐπεάν or ἐπήν, ἐπάν, ἐπειδὰν τ. Hdt., etc.; ὅταν τ. Xen.
often also in Prose, τὴν ταχίστην (sc. ὁδόν) , as adv. by the quickest way, i. e. most quickly, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: ταχυτής
div1.note: τᾰχῠτής, ῆτος, Doric τᾰχῠτᾱς, ᾶτος, ἡ,
div1.sense: quickness, swiftness, Hom., Hdt., Plat.

div1.head: ταώνιος
div1.sense: of a peacock, Luc.

div1.head: ταώς
div1.sense: a peacock, Lat. pavo, Ar., etc.: metaph. of coxcombs, Ar.

div1.head: τέγγω
div1.sense: to wet, moisten, Pind., etc.; of tears, Trag.:—Pass. τέγγομαι, I weep, Aesch.; τ. βλέφαρα Eur.
c. acc. cogn., τ. δάκρυα to shed tears, Pind.; τέγγει δακρύων ἄχναν Soph.:—Pass., ὄμβρος ἐτέγγετο a shower fell, Pind.
to soften (properly, by soaking or bathing), Pind.:—metaph. in Pass., τέγγει γὰρ οὐδέν thou art no whit softened, Aesch.; οὔτε λόγοις ἐτέγγεθʼ ἥδε Eur.
to dye, stain, Lat. tingere; metaph., like Lat. imbuere, Pind.

div1.head: Τεγέα
div1.sense: Tegea in Arcadia, Il., Pind., etc.

div1.head: Τεγεάτης
div1.sense: of Tegea, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: Τεγεατικός
div1.sense: of or belonging to Tegea, Hdt.

div1.head: Τεγεᾶτις
div1.sense: the Tegeate country, Thuc.

div1.head: τέγεος
div1.sense: at or near the roof, τ. θάλαμοι, of the womenʼs chambers, = ὑπερῷον, Il.

div1.head: τέγος
div1.sense: like στέγος, a roof, Lat. tectum, Od., Ar., etc.; οὑπὶ τοῦ τέγους you on the roof! Od., Ar.
any covered part of a house, a hall, room, chamber, Od., Pind.

div1.head: τεθαρρηκότως
div1.etym: adverb from perf. part. of θαρρέω
div1.sense: boldly, Polyb.

div1.head: τέθηπα
div1.etym: perf. with pres. sense (no pres. is found)
div1.sense: intr. to be astonished, astounded, amazed, Od., Hdt.; mostly in part. τεθηπώς amazed, astonied, Il.:—to this belongs also aor2 ἔταφον, used by Hom. only in part. ταφών, in the phrases ταφὼν ἀνόρουσε, στῆ δὲ ταφών; but 3 sg. τάφε (for ἔταφε) occurs in Pind.; and 1st sg. ἔταφον in Aesch.
c. acc. to be amazed at, Luc.

div1.head: τέθμιος
div1.sense: settled, regular, Lat. solennis, Pind.:— τέθμιον, ου, τεθμός, Pind.

div1.head: τεθμός
div1.sense: a law, custom, Pind.

div1.head: τεθορυβημένως
div1.etym: adverb from part. perf. pass. of θορυβέω
div1.sense: tumultuously, Xen.

div1.head: τεθριπποβάμων
div1.sense: τ. στόλος, τέθριππον, Eur.

div1.head: τεθριπποβάτης
div1.sense: driver of a four-horse chariot, Hdt.

div1.head: τέθριππος
div1.sense: with four horses abreast, four-horsed, Pind., Eur.; ἅμιλλαι τ. the chariot-race, Eur.
τέθριππον (sc. ἅρμα) , a four-horse chariot, Hdt., Eur.; τ. ἵππων a team of four abreast, Ar.

div1.head: τεθριπποτροφέω
div1.sense: to keep a team of four horses, Hdt.

div1.head: τεθριπποτρόφος
div1.sense: keeping a team of four horses, τ. οἰκία, i. e. a wealthy family that could support this contest in the games, Hdt.

div1.head: τείνω
div1.sense: to stretch by main force, to stretch to the uttermost, τόξον ἔτεινεν stretched it to its full, Il.; ἐξ ἄντυγος ἡνία τείνας having tied the reins tight to the chariot-rail, Il.:—Pass., [ἱμὰς τέτατο the strap was made tight, Il.; ἱστία τέτατο the sails were stretched, Od.:—absol., μὴ τείνειν ἄγαν not to strain the cord too tight, Soph.

metaph., ἶσον τείνειν πολέμου τέλος to strain the even tug of war, Il.:—Pass., ἐπὶ ἶσα μάχη τέτατο Il.; ἵπποισι τάθη δρόμος their pace was strained to the utmost, Il.: also, to exert oneself, be anxious, Pind.
to stretch out, spread, Ζεὺς λαίλαπα τείνει Il.; νὺξ τέταται βροτοῖσιν night is spread over mankind, Od.; so, of light, τέτατο φάος Soph.; of sound, ἀμφὶ νῶτʼ ἐτάθη πάταγος Soph.
to aim at, direct towards a point, properly from the bow, τείνειν βέλη Soph.: then, metaph., τ. φόνον εἴς τινα to aim death to one, design it for him, Eur.; τ. λόγον εἴς τινα Plat.
to stretch out in length, Hdt.:—Pass. to lie out at length, lie stretched, ταθεὶς ἐπὶ γαίηι Il.; ταθεὶς ἐνὶ δεσμῶι lying stretched in chains, Od.
to stretch or hold out, present, τινὰ ἐπὶ σφαγάν Eur.:—Mid., τείνεσθαι χέρε to stretch out oneʼs hands, etc., Theocr.
to extend, lengthen, of Time, Aesch., Eur.; τείνειν λόγον Aesch.
intr., of geographical position, to stretch out or extend, Hdt., Xen.:—of Time, τείνοντα χρόνον lengthening time, Aesch.
to exert oneself, struggle, ἐναντία τινί Plat.: to hurry on, hasten, Eur., Xen.
to extend to, reach, Lat. pertinere, ἐπὶ τὴν ψυχήν Plat.
to tend, refer, belong to, Lat. spectare ad, τείνει ἐς σέ it refers to, concerns you, Hdt., Eur., etc.; ποῖ τείνει; to what tends it? Plat.; ἐγγύς τι τείνειν τοῦ θανάτου Plat.

div1.head: τεῖρος
div1.sense: the heavenly constellations, signs, only once in hom., τὰ τείρεα πάντα, τά τʼ οὐρανὸς ἐστεφάνωται Il.; ἐνὶ τείρεσιν αἰθέρος Hhymn.

div1.head: τείρω
div1.etym: only in pres. and imperf. act. and pass.
div1.sense: to rub hard: of the effects of pain, sorrow, to wear away, wear out, distress, Hom., Aesch.:—Pass., τείροντο καμάτῳ τε καὶ ἱδρῷ Il.; τείρετο δʼ αἰνῶς she was sore distressed, Il., etc.
intr. to suffer distress, ἦ μάλα δὴ τείρουσι υἷες Ἀχαιῶν Il.

div1.head: τειχεσιπλήτης
div1.sense: approacher of walls, i. e. stormer of cities, Il.

div1.head: τειχέω
div1.sense: to build walls, Hdt.; τεῖχος τ. Hdt.
trans. to fortify, τὸν Ἰσθμόν Hdt.

div1.head: τειχήρης
div1.sense: enclosed by walls, beleaguered, besieged, Hdt., Thuc., etc.

div1.head: τειχίζω
div1.sense: to build a wall, Ar., etc.: c. acc. cogn., τ. τεῖχος to build it, Thuc.; so in Mid., τεῖχος ἐτειχίσσαντο they built them a wall, Il.:—Pass. to be built, Pind.: 3rd sg. plup. τετείχιστο, impers., buildings had been erected, there were buildings, Hdt.
trans. to wall or fortify, τὸ οὖρος Hdt.; τὴν πόλιν Thuc., Dem.: in Mid., τειχίζεσθαι τὸ χωρίον Thuc.:—Pass. to be walled or fenced with walls, Thuc.; τὰ τετειχισμένα the fortified parts, Thuc.

div1.head: τειχιόεις
div1.sense: walled, high-walled, Il.

div1.head: τειχίον
div1.sense: a wall, Od.:—any dimin. sense it has consists in its being commonly limited to private buildings, as opp. to city-walls.

div1.head: τείχισις
div1.sense: the work of walling, wall-building, Thuc., Xen.

div1.head: τείχισμα
div1.sense: a wall or fort, fortification, Eur., Thuc.

div1.head: τειχοδομέω
div1.sense: to build a wall, Anth.

div1.head: τειχοδομία
div1.sense: a building of walls, Plut.

div1.head: τειχολέτις
div1.sense: destroyer of walls, ap. Plut.

div1.head: τειχομαχέω
div1.sense: to fight the walls, i. e. to besiege, Hdt., Thuc., etc.; τ. τινί Ar.; πρός τινα Plut.

div1.head: τειχομάχης
div1.sense: storming walls, an engineer, Ar.

div1.head: τειχομαχία
div1.sense: a battle with walls, i. e. a siege, Hdt.: the 12th Iliad was so called, Plat.

div1.head: τειχομελής
div1.sense: walling by music, of Amphionʼs lyre, Anth.

div1.head: τειχοποιός
div1.sense: building walls or forts, Luc.
οἱ τειχοποιοί, at Athens, officers chosen to repair the city-walls, Dem., Aeschin.

div1.head: τεῖχος
div1.sense: a wall, esp. a wall round a city, town-wall, in sg. and pl., Hom.; τειχέων κιθῶνες coats of walls, i. e. walls one within the other, Hdt.; τεῖχος ἐλαύνειν, δέμειν Il., etc.; οἰκοδομεῖν Hdt.; τ. περιβάλλεσθαι moenia sibi circumdare, Hdt.; also, τ. περιβάλλεσθαι τὴν πόλιν Hdt.; τ. ῥήξασθαι to breach the wall, Il.; so in Prose, τ. καθαιρεῖν, κατασκάπτειν Hdt., etc.

τὰ μακρὰ τείχη at Athens were lines of wall connecting the city-wall with the harbours, called respectively τὸ βόρειον or Peiraic, and τὸ νότιον or Phaleric wall.— τεῖχος, τείχη differ from τοῖχος, as Lat. murus, moenia from paries, city-walls from a house-wall; cf. τειχίον.
any fortification, a castle, fort, Hdt.: pl. of a single fort, fortifications, Hdt.
a fortified town, Hdt., Xen., etc.; so in pl.

div1.head: τειχοφυλακέω
div1.sense: to guard the walls, Plut.

div1.head: τειχοφύλαξ
div1.sense: a guard of the walls, Hdt.

div1.head: τεκμαίρομαι
div1.sense: to fix by a mark or boundary, to ordain, decree, Hom.: to lay a task upon a person, enjoin, appoint, Od.:—c. inf. to design, purpose to do, Hhymn.

to judge from signs and tokens, to form a judgment respecting a thing, calculate, Eur.: absol. to conjecture, Xen.:—the reason is added in the dat., ἐμπύροις τεκμαίρεσθαι to judge by the burnt-offering, Pind.; τεκμ. ἔργωι κοὐ λόγωι τ. Aesch.; τὰ καινὰ τοῖς πάλαι Soph., etc.:—c. inf., τ. τοῦτο οὕτω ἕξειν Xen.

an Act. τεκμαίρω occurs in Poets, to shew by a sign or token, τεκμαίρει χρῆμʼ ἕκαστον circumstance proves the man, Pind.; τεκμαίρει ἰδεῖν gives signs [for men] to see, Pind.; τέκμηρον, ὅ τι μʼ ἐπαμμένει παθεῖν shew me what it awaits me to suffer, Aesch.

div1.head: τέκμαρ
div1.sense: a fixed mark or boundary, goal, end, Il.; τέκμωρ Ἰλίου the end of Ilium, Il.
an end, object, purpose, Pind.

like τεκμήριον, a fixed sign, sure sign or token, as Zeus says that his nod is μέγιστον τέκμωρ ἐξ ἐμέθεν the highest, surest pledge I can give, Il.; ἦν δʼ οὐδὲν αὐτοῖς οὔτε χειμῶνος τ. οὔτʼ ἦρος Aesch., etc.

div1.head: τεκμήριον
div1.sense: like τέκμαρ II, a sure sign or token, Hdt., Attic
a positive proof, Aesch., Plat., etc.:—in Attic Prose τεκμήριον δέ as an independent clause, now the proof of it is this (which follows), Thuc., etc.

div1.head: τεκμηριόω
div1.sense: to prove positively, Thuc.; εἴ τῳ ἱκανὸς τεκμηριῶσαι if he seem a sufficient voucher, Thuc.; τοσαῦτα ἐτεκμηρίωσε ὅτι . . thus much evidence he gave to the fact that . . , Thuc.

div1.head: τεκμηριώδης
div1.sense: of the nature of a τεκμήριον, Arist.

div1.head: τεκνίον
div1.sense: a little child, Anth., NTest.

div1.head: τεκνογονέω
div1.sense: to bear young, bear children, Anth., NTest.

div1.head: τεκνογονία
div1.sense: child-bearing, NTest.

div1.head: τεκνογόνος
div1.sense: begetting or bearing children, Aesch.

div1.head: τεκνοκτόνος
div1.sense: murdering children, Eur.

div1.head: τεκνολέτειρα
div1.sense: having lost oneʼs young, of the nightingale, Soph.

div1.head: τέκνον
div1.sense: that which is borne or born, a child (cf. Scottish bairn, from Anglo-S. beran, to bear), Hom., etc.; my son, my child, sometimes with masc. adj., φίλε τέκνον Hom.; the relat. Pron. or Participle often follows in masc. or fem.
of animals, the young, Hom., etc.
metaph., flowers are γαίας τέκνα Aesch.; birds αἰθέρος τέκνα Eur.
div1.etym: The penult. is long in Hom., in Trag. more often short.

div1.head: τεκνοποιέω
div1.sense: in Act., of the woman, to bear children, in Mid., of the man, to beget them, Xen.: in Mid. of both parents, to breed children, Xen.

div1.head: τεκνοποιητικός
div1.sense: of or for the production of children: ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) Arist.

div1.head: τεκνοποιία
div1.sense: production of children, Xen.,

div1.head: τεκνόποινος
div1.sense: child-avenging, Aesch.

div1.head: τεκνοποιός
div1.sense: of the wife, child-bearing, Hdt.; of the husband, child-begetting, Eur.

div1.head: τεκνοσπορία
div1.sense: a begetting of children, Anth.

div1.head: τεκνοῦς
div1.note: τεκνοῦς, οῦσσα, οῦν, ξοντρ. for τεκνόεις, εσσα, εν
div1.sense: having borne children, Soph.

div1.head: τεκνοφαγία
div1.sense: a devouring of children, Luc.

div1.head: τεκνοφονέω
div1.sense: to murder children, Anth.

div1.head: τεκνόω
div1.sense: to furnish or stock with children, Eur.: —Pass. to be furnished with children, i. e. to have them, Eur.

Act., of the man, to beget children, Eur.;—Mid., of the female, to bear them: metaph., ὄλβος τεκνοῦται it has offspring, Aesch.; χθὼν ἐτεκνώσατο φάσματα Eur.:—Pass. to be born, Trag.; γάμον τεκνοῦντα καὶ τεκνούμενον, i. e. a marriage where husband and son are one, Soph.

div1.head: τέκνωσις
div1.sense: a begetting, bearing, τέκνωσιν ποιεῖσθαι to have children, Thuc.

div1.head: τέκος
div1.sense: poetic for τέκνον, Hom., etc.
of animals, Il., etc.; in pl. the young, Il.

div1.head: τεκταίνομαι
div1.sense: of a carpenter, to make, work, frame, Il.:—absol. to do joinersʼ work, opp. to smithsʼ work, Ar., Xen.
of other artificers, Hhymn., Plat.
metaph. to devise, plan, contrive, esp. by craft, Lat. machinari, ἐτεκτήναντʼ ἀπόφθεγκτόν μʼ they kept me from speech of them, Eur.; πᾶν ἐπʼ ἐμοὶ τεκταινέσθω (sc. Cleon) Ar.
later, Act. τεκταίνω, in same sense, Anth., Luc.; hence partic. pass. τεκταινόμενος, Ar., Dem.

div1.head: τεκτονεῖον
div1.sense: workshop of a carpenter, Aeschin.

div1.head: τεκτονία
div1.sense: carpentry, Anth.

div1.head: τεκτονικός
div1.sense: practised or skilled in building, Plat.: as Subst. a good carpenter or builder, opp. to a smith, Xen.: —ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) joinersʼ work, carpentry, Plat., etc.

div1.head: τεκτοσύνη
div1.sense: the art of a joiner, carpentry, ἀνὴρ εὖ εἰδὼς τεκτοσυνάων Od.; ἄτιμον χέρα τεκτοσύνας hand unhonoured in its art, Eur.

div1.head: τέκτων
div1.sense: any worker in wood, esp. a carpenter, joiner, Hom., etc.; opp. to a smith (χαλκεύς) , Plat., Xen.; to a mason (λιθολόγος) , Thuc., etc.
generally, any craftsman or workman, τ. κεραοξόος a worker in horn, Il.; of a metal-worker, Eur.; a sculptor, Soph., Eur.
a master in any art, Pind.; τ. νωδυνιᾶν, i. e. a physician, Pind.
metaph. a maker, author, νεικέων Aesch.; κακῶν Eur.

div1.head: τελαμών
div1.sense: a broad strap for bearing anything
div1.etym: from Root !τλα, *τλάω, whence also the hero Telamon took his name, cf. Ἄτλας
div1.sense: a leathern strap or belt, for bearing both shield or sword, Hom.
a broad linen bandage for wounds, Il., Hdt., Eur.; for swathing mummies, Hdt.

div1.head: τελέθω
div1.sense: to come into being, to be quite or fully so and so, νὺξ τελέθει Il.: —then simply to be so and so, ἀριπρεπέες τελέθουσι, μινυνθάδιοι τελ. Hom., Trag.

div1.head: τέλειος
div1.sense: having reached its end, finished, complete, Il., etc.: of victims, perfect, without spot or blemish, Il.; τὰ τέλεα τῶν προβάτων Hdt.; of sacrifices, ἱερὰ τέλεια of full tale or number, or performed with all rites, Thuc.; so, αἰετὸς τελειότατος πετεηνῶν is prob. the surest bird of augury, Il.
of animals, fullgrown, Xen., etc.
of persons, absolute, complete, accomplished, perfect in his or its kind, Plat., etc.: —so of things, φάρμακον τελεώτατον Plat.; τ. ἀρετή, φιλία, etc., Arist.
of prayers, vows, etc., fulfilled, accomplished, Pind., Aesch.; ὄψις οὐ τελέη a vision which imported nothing, Hdt.; τ. ψῆφος a fixed resolve, Soph.
in Arithm., those numbers are τέλειοι, which are equal to the sum of their divisors, as 6 = 3 + 2 + 1, Plat.

of the gods, fulfilling prayer, Ζεὺς τ. Zeus the fulfiller, Pind., Aesch.; of Hera ζυγία, Lat. Juno pronuba, the presiding goddess of marriage, Pind., Aesch., etc.:—so, τέλειος ἀνήρ, Lat. paterfamilias, the lord of the house, Aesch.
= τελευταῖος, last, Soph.
τέλειον (not τέλεον) , τό, a royal banquet, as a transl. of the Pers. tycta, Hdt.
adv. τελέως, at last, Aesch., Plat., etc.
perfectly, absolutely, thoroughly, Hdt.
the neut. τέλεον is also used as adv., Luc.
comp. and Sup.: Hom. uses τελεώτερος, -εώτατος or τελειότερος, -ειότατος, as his metre requires: in Attic τελεώτερος, -ώτατος prevail.

div1.head: τελειόω
div1.sense: to make perfect, complete:

of things, to make it perfect, complete, accomplish, Hdt., Thuc., etc.:—Pass. to be accomplished, Hdt., Soph.; τελεωθέντων ἀμφοτέροισι when both parties had their wishes accomplished, Hdt.:— of prophecies, to be fulfilled, NTest.
of persons, to bring one to perfection, Hdt.; τελειῶσαι λόχον to make the ambush successful, Soph.:—Pass. to attain perfection, come to the end of oneʼs labours, Soph.: to reach maturity, Plat.

div1.head: τελείωσις
div1.sense: accomplishment, fulfilment, NTest.

div1.head: τελειωτής
div1.sense: an accomplisher, finisher, NTest.

div1.head: τελεόμηνος
div1.sense: with full complement of months, τ. ἄροτος, i. e. a full twelvemonth, Soph.

div1.head: Τελέοντες
div1.sense: one of the four old Attic Tribes, prob. from τελέω III the Consecrators, Priests; or (from τελέω II) the Payers, Farmers, Hdt.

div1.head: τελεσιούργημα
div1.sense: an accomplished purpose, Polyb.

div1.head: τελεσιουργός
div1.sense: working out its end, effective, Plat.

div1.head: τέλεσμα
div1.sense: money paid or to be paid, a payment, outlay, Luc.

div1.head: τελεσσιδώτειρα
div1.sense: she that gives completeness or accomplishment, Eur.

div1.head: τελεσσίφρων
div1.sense: working its will, Aesch.

div1.head: τελεστήριον
div1.sense: a place for initiation, as the temple of Eleusis, Plut.
τελεστήρια, ων, τά, a thank-offering for success, Xen.

div1.head: τελεστικός
div1.sense: initiatory, mystical, Plat.

div1.head: τελέστωρ
div1.sense: a priest, Anth.

div1.head: τελεσφορέω
div1.sense: to bring fruit to perfection, NTest.
to pay toll or custom, Xen.

div1.head: τελεσφόρος
div1.sense: bringing to an end, τελεσφόρον εἰς ἐνιαυτόν for a year completing its round, for a complete year, Hom.; τελεσφόροι ἀραί, εὐχαί tending to accomplishment, Aesch., Eur.; φάσματα δὸς τελεσφόρα grant accomplishment to the visions, Soph.; τ. χάριν δοῦναι to grant the favour of fulfilment, Soph.
accomplishing oneʼs purpose, Μοῖρα Aesch.; Δίκη Soph.; πεσεῖν ἐς τὸ μὴ τελεσφόρον to fall powerless to the ground, Aesch.
bringing fruit to perfection, δένδρον Plut.: having the ordering of a thing, c. gen., Aesch.

div1.head: τελετή
div1.sense: initiation in the mysteries, Hdt., Plat., etc.; ἐς χεῖρας ἄγεσθαι τὴν τελετήν to take in hand the matter of initiation, Hdt.:—in pl. mystic rites at initiation, Eur., Ar., etc.
a festival accompanied by such rites, in pl., Pind.; in sg., Eur.

div1.head: τελευταῖος
div1.sense: last, Lat. ultimus, Hdt.; τὰ τ. the endings or terminations, Hdt.; τελευταίους στῆσαι to station in the rear ranks, Xen.
of Time, ἡ τελευταία, with or without ἡμέρα, the last day allowed for payment, Dem.; oneʼs last day, Soph.
last, uttermost, ὕβρις Soph.
τὸ τελευταῖον, as adv. the last time, last of all, Hdt., Xen., etc.; or τελευταῖον Plat., etc.; and τὰ τελευταῖα Thuc.
at last, in the last place, Ar., etc.: but,
the adj. is often used with Verbs, where we should use the adv., ὁ τελευταῖος δραμών Aesch.; παρελθόντες τελευταῖοι Thuc.

div1.head: τελευτάω
div1.sense: to complete, finish, accomplish, Lat. perficere, Hom.: to fulfil an oath or promise, Hom.; τελευτᾶν τινι κακὸν ἦμαρ to bring about an evil day for one, Od.:—so in Attic, ποῖ τελευτῆσαί με χρή; to what end must I bring it? Soph.; Ζεὺς ὅ τι νεύσῃ, τοῦτο τελευτᾷ Eur., etc.:—Pass. to be fulfilled, to come to pass, happen, Hom., Eur.

to bring to an end, esp., τ. τὸν αἰῶνα to finish life, i. e. to die, Hdt.; τ. βίον Aesch.:—also, c. gen., τελευτᾶν βίου to make an end of life, Xen.; so, λόγου τ. Thuc.: —also without βίον, to end life, to die, Hdt., Attic; τ. ὑπό τινος to die by anotherʼs hand or means, Hdt.
intr.
to be accomplished, Hdt.
to come to an end, to end, Lat. finire, Hdt., Attic:— foll. by a prep., τ. ἔς τι to come to a certain end, issue in, Hdt., Attic; ποῖ ( = ἐς τί) τελευτᾷ; in what does it end? Aesch.
to die, v. supr.

the part. τελευτῶν, ῶσα, ῶν, was used as adv., at the end, at last, τελευτῶν ἔλεγε Hdt.; κἂν ἐγίγνετο πληγὴ τελευτῶσα there would have been a fray to finish with, Soph.; τὰς ὀλοφύρσεις τελευτῶντες ἐξέκαμνον at last they got tired of mourning, Thuc.
of a country, to come to an end, Hdt.

div1.head: τελευτή
div1.sense: a finishing, completion, accomplishment, Od.
a termination, end, Il., Attic; τῆς ὁδοῦ Ar.; ἡ τ. τοῦ πολέμου Thuc.
esp. an end of life, βιότοιο τ. Il.; βίου Hdt., etc:—also periphr., θανάτοιο τ. the end that death brings, Lat. mortis exitus, Hes.
the end, event, issue, Pind., Aesch.
with Preps., in adv. sense, ἐς τελευτήν, at the end, at last, Hes., Soph.; ἐπὶ τελευτῆς Plat.; ἐν τελευτῇ Aesch.
the end, extremity of any thing, τελευταὶ Λιβύης the extremities of Libya, Hdt.
the end of a sentence, Arist.

div1.head: τελέω
div1.sense: to complete, fulfil, accomplish, and, generally, to execute, perform, Lat. perficere, Hom.: —Pass., Hom.; ἅμα μῦθος ἔην, τετέλεστο δὲ ἔργον "no sooner said than done, " Il.

to fulfil oneʼs word, Hom.: to grant one the fulfilment of anything, τί τινι Hom.; τ. νόον τινί to fulfil his wish, Il.; τελέσαι κότον, χόλον to glut his fury, wrath, Il.: c. inf., οὐδʼ ἐτέλεσσε φέρειν he succeeded not in bringing, Il.; ὅρκια τελεῖν, like ὅρκον τελευτᾶν, to complete or confirm an oath, Il.
to make perfect, ἀρετάν Pind.; τ. τινα to bless him with perfect happiness, Pind.; so, τελεσθεὶς ὄλβος Aesch.:—also, to bring a child to maturity, bring it to the birth, Eur.
to bring to an end, finish, end, ὁδόν Il., etc.; without ὁδόν, to finish oneʼs course to a place, arrive at it, Thuc.
of Time, Od., etc.:— Pass., ἤματα μακρὰ τελέσθη Od.: of men, to come to oneʼs end, Aesch.
intr. like Pass. to be fulfilled, turn out so and so, Aesch., Soph.
to pay what one owes, pay oneʼs dues, Il.: generally, to pay, present, Hom., Attic: absol. to pay tax, Hdt.:—Pass., of money, to be paid, Hdt.; of persons, to be subject to tax or tribute, Dem.
to lay out, spend, Hdt.:—Pass. to be spent or expended, Hdt.; ἐς τὸ δεῖπνον τετρακόσια τάλαντα τετελεσμένα laid out upon the supper, Hdt.

since, in many Greek cities, the citizens were distributed into classes acc. to their taxable property, τ. εἴς τινας meant to be rated as belonging to a class, Lat. censeri inter, τ. ἐς Ἕλληνας, ἐς Βοιωτούς to belong to the Greeks, the Boeotians, Hdt.; εἰς ἀστοὺς τ. to become a citizen, Soph.; εἰς γυναῖκας ἐξ ἀνδρῶν τ. to become a woman instead of a man, Eur.: hence, πρὸς τὸν πατέρα τελέσαι to compare with his father, Hdt.

like τελειόω II, to make perfect, i. e. to initiate in the mysteries, Plat., Dem.:—Pass. to have oneself initiated, Lat. initiari, Ar., Plat., etc.; Διονύσῳ τελεσθῆναι to be consecrated to Dionysus, initiated in his mysteries, Hdt.:—c. acc., τελεσθῆναι Βακχεῖα Ar.
metaph., στρατηγὸς τελεσθῆναι to be formally appointed general, Dem.; τετελεσμένος σωφροσύνῃ a votary of temperance, Xen.
also of sacred rites, to perform, Eur., Anth.

div1.head: τελήεις
div1.sense: perfect, complete, of victims, ἔρδειν or ῥέζειν τεληέσσας ἑκατόμβας to offer hecatombs, either of full tale or number, or of full-grown beasts, or of beasts without blemish, Il.; τελήεντες οἰωνοί birds of sure augury, Hhymn.
τελήεις ποταμός, of Ocean, the river in which all others end, or ever-circling, Hes.

div1.head: τέλλω
div1.sense: to make to arise, accomplish, Pind.:—Pass. to come forth, arise, Pind.
intr. in Act., ἡλίου τέλλοντος at sunrise, Soph.

div1.head: τέλμα
div1.sense: standing water, a pool, pond, marsh, swamp, Ar., Plat.: in pl. low land subject to inundation, water-meads, Hdt.
the mud of a pool, mud for building with, mortar, Hdt.

div1.head: τελματώδης
div1.sense: marshy, muddy, ὕδωρ Plut.

div1.head: τέλοσδε
div1.sense: towards the end or term, Il.

div1.head: τέλος
div1.sense: the fulfilment or completion of anything, Lat. effectus, i.e. its consummation, issue, result, end, Hom., etc.; τ. πολέμου its issue, Il.; τ. ἐπιτιθέναι τινί to put a finish to a thing, i. e. give it effect, Il.; τ. ἐπιγίγνεται ἀρῇσι oneʼs prayers are accomplished, Od.:— τέλος ἔχειν to have reached the end, to be finished or ready, Il.; τ. ἔχει δαίμων ὅπα θέλει the deity keeps the result in his own power, Eur.:— τ. λαβεῖν to be completed, Plat.
esp. of the end of life, τὸ τ. βίου, Soph., Eur.; and without βίου, the end, death, Hdt.
periphr. in various phrases, τέλος θανάτου the point or term of death, Lat. exitus mortis, Hom.; so, τ. γάμοιο γάμος, Od., etc.
Adverbial usages:
τέλος at last, Hdt., Thuc.: so, εἰς or ἐς τέλος Hdt.:— διὰ τέλους throughout, for ever, completely, Trag.:— τέλει, Lat. omnino, at all, Soph.
the end proposed, chief matter, μύθου τ. Il.
the end of action, Plat.:—hence = τὸ ἀγαθόν, the chief good, Ciceroʼs finis bonorum, Arist.
perfection, full age, ἀνδρὸς τ. manʼs full age, man hood, Plat.; τέλος ἔχειν or λαμβάνειν to be grown up, Plat.
a final decision, determination, Aesch.
the prize at games, Pind.
supreme authority, Eur., etc.
a magistracy, office, οἱ ἐν τέλει men in office, magistrates, Soph., Thuc., etc.; οἱ ἐν τέλει βεβῶτες Soph.:—then, τὸ τέλος the government, Aesch.; τὰ τέλη the magistrates, Thuc., Xen., etc.
generally, a task, office, Aesch.; ὀμμάτων τέλη the duties of the eyes, Eur.
a body of soldiers, Il.; ἐν τελέεσσιν in squadrons, Il.; so, κατὰ τέλεα Hdt.: —δίρρυμα τέλη troops of chariots, Aesch.; and of ships, τρία τέλη τῶν νεῶν Thuc.

that which is paid for state purposes, a toll, tax, duty, Ar., Plat., etc.; ἀγορᾶς τ. a market- due, Ar.; τέλος πρίασθαι, πωλεῖν to farm a tax, or let it, Dem., Aeschin.; for λύειν τέλη, v. λύω V. 2:—generally, outlay, expense, Thuc.:—hence, at Athens, the property at which a citizen was rated for taxation, Lat. census; and then, a class, order, of citizens, Dem., etc.
in pl. offerings or sacred rites due to the gods, Trag.:—esp. of the Eleusinian mysteries, Soph., Eur., etc.
of marriage, as the consummation of life, Aesch., Soph.

div1.head: τέλσον
div1.sense: a boundary, limit, τέλσον ἀρούρης Il.

div1.head: Τελχίς
div1.sense: one of the Telchines, the first inhabitants of Crete, and the first workers in metal, Aesch.
as appellat. τελχίν, a mischievous elf, Anth.

div1.head: τελωνέω
div1.sense: to be a tax-gatherer, Luc.

div1.head: τελώνης
div1.sense: a farmer or collector of the taxes, Ar., Aeschin.: in NTest. = Lat. publicanus.

div1.head: τελωνία
div1.sense: the office of τελώνης, Dem.

div1.head: τελωνιάς
div1.sense: of tolls or customs, μᾶζα τ. the good fare of the tax-gatherers, Anth.

div1.head: τελωνικός
div1.sense: of or for τελωνία, τ. νόμοι the excise and custom laws, Dem.

div1.head: τελώνιον
div1.sense: a custom-house, NTest.

div1.head: τέμαχος
div1.sense: a slice of salt-fish, Ar., Xen., etc.: generally, a slice of meat, Luc.

div1.head: τεμενίζω
div1.sense: to make a sacred grove (τέμενος) , to consecrate, Plat.

div1.head: τεμένιος
div1.sense: of or in the sacred precincts, Soph.

div1.head: τεμενίτης
div1.sense: = τεμένιος: at Syracuse Apollo of the Temenos, Thuc.:—fem., ἡ ἄκρα ἡ Τεμενῖτις the height on which was the Temenos of Apollo, Thuc.

div1.head: τέμενος
div1.sense: a piece of land cut off, assigned as a domain to kings and chiefs, Hom.

a piece of land dedicated to a god, the sacred precincts, Hom.: in it stood the temple, Hdt.:—metaph., the sacred valley of the Nile is the τέμ. Νείλοιο, Pind.; the Acropolis is the ἱερὸν τ. of Pallas, Ar.

div1.head: τέμνω
div1.sense: to cut, hew, Hom., etc.; ὀδόντας οἵους τέμνειν teeth fit for cutting, Xen.
to cut, wound, maim, Il.; πρὸς δέρην τ. to wound her in the neck, Aesch.
of a surgeon, to cut, Il.: absol. to use the knife, as opp. to cautery (κάειν), Aesch., Xen., etc.:—Pass. to be operated upon, Plat.
to cut up, cut to pieces, Hom., etc.:—to slaughter, sacrifice, Il., Eur.

ὅρκια τάμνειν to sacrifice in attestation of an oath, and so to take solemn oaths, Hom.; θάνατόν νύ τοι ὅρκιʼ ἔταμνον I made a truce which was death to thee, Il.:—Mid., of two parties, ὅρκια τάμνεσθαι Hdt.:—cf. Lat. foedus ferire.
φάρμακον τέμνειν to cut or chop up a plant for purposes of medicine or witchcraft, Aesch., etc.; ἄκος τέμνειν to contrive a means or remedy, Eur.
to divide, of a river, μέσην τ. Λιβύην to cut it in twain, Hdt.; δίχα τ. to cut in two, bisect, Plat.
to cut asunder, cut off, sever, κεφαλὴν ἀπὸ δειρῆς Il., etc.; with double acc., ἐρινεὸν τάμνε ὄρπηκας cut the branches off the fig-tree, Il.; and in Pass., τρίχας ἐτμήθην had them cut off, Eur.
to part off, mark off, τέμενος Il.
to cut down, fell trees, Il., etc.:—Mid., δοῦρα τάμνεσθαι to fell oneself timber, Od., Hdt.
λίθον τ. to hew stone, Plat.: Mid., λίθους τάμνεσθαι to have them wrought or hewn, Hdt.
to cut down for purposes of destruction, Eur., etc.; τ. τὴν γῆν to ravage the country by felling the trees and cutting the corn, Hdt., Thuc.; with partit. gen., τῆς γῆς τ. to waste part of it, Thuc.
to cut or hew into shape, δούρατα Od., etc.
to cut lengthwise, to plough, Solon.
τ. ὁδόν to cut or make a road, Thuc.:—Pass., τέτμηνται κέλευθοι Pind.
also to make oneʼs way, advance, τ. ὁδόν Eur.; τὴν μεσόγαιαν τ. τῆς ὁδοῦ to take the middle road, strike through the interior, Hdt.; μέσον τέμνειν to hold a middle course, Plat.
of ships, to cut through the waves, plough the sea, Od.:—so of birds, to cleave the air, Ar.
to bring to a decision, Lat. decidere, Pind., Eur.

div1.head: τεναγίζω
div1.sense: to be covered with shoal water, stand in pools, Plut.

div1.head: τεναγῖτις
div1.sense: fem. adj. shallow, Anth.

div1.head: τέναγος
div1.sense: shoal-water, a shoal, shallow, lagoon, Lat. vadum, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: τεναγώδης
div1.sense: covered with shoal-water, standing in pools, Polyb.

div1.head: τένδω
div1.sense: to gnaw, gnaw at, Hes.

div1.head: τενθεία
div1.sense: lickerishness, gluttony, Ar.

div1.head: τένθης
div1.sense: a dainty feeder, gourmand, Ar.

div1.head: τένων
div1.sense: any tight-stretched band, a sinew, tendon, Hom.; τ. ποδός the outstretched foot, Eur.:—absol. the foot, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: τεός
div1.sense: Lat. tuus, Hom., Hes., Hdt.: Doric, Pind., and Trag. Chorus.

div1.head: τε
div1.sense: and, answering to Lat. que, as καί to et. It may simply join clauses, as ὃς Χρύσην ἀμφιβέβηκας Κίλλαν τε ζαθέην, Τενέδοιό τε ἶφι ἀνάσσεις Il.; or it may be repeated as τε, . . τε . . , both . . and . . , as πατὴρ ἀνδρῶν τε θεῶν τε Hom. So also τε . . , καὶ . . , as διαστήτην Ἀτρείδης τε καὶ δῖος Ἀχιλλεύς Il., etc.: —used to show coincidence of Time, μεσαμβρίη τέ ἐστι καὶ τὸ κάρτα γίγνεται ψυχρόν Hdt., etc.
the combination καί τε is peculiar to Epic, and also, Hom.

in Epic Poetry, τε is attached to many relative Pronouns or Particles, without altering their sense, as ὅστε, ὅσος τε, γάρ τε, δέ τε, μέν τε, ἔνθα τε, ἵνα τε, etc.: in Attic, this τε was dropped, except in a few words, as ἅτε, ὥστε, ἐφʼ ᾧτε, οἷός τε, ἔστε.

div1.head: τεράζω
div1.sense: to interpret portents or prodigies, Aesch.

div1.head: τέραμνον
div1.sense: in pl., chambers, a house, Eur.

div1.head: τερασκόπος
div1.sense: καρδία τ. "my prophetic soul, " Aesch.

div1.head: τέρας
div1.sense: a sign, wonder, marvel, Lat. portentum, prodigium, Hom.; esp. of signs in heaven, Il. (cf. τεῖρος) , etc.
in concrete sense, a monster, Διὸς τ. αἰγιόχοιο, of the Gorgonʼs head, Il.; of a serpent, Il.; of Typhoeus, Aesch.; of Cerberus, Soph.

div1.head: τεράστιος
div1.sense: monstrous, Theophr., Luc.

div1.head: τερατεία
div1.sense: a talking marvels, jugglery, Ar.

div1.head: τερατεύομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to talk marvels, Lat. portenta loqui, Ar., Aeschin.; τ. τῷ σχήματι to indulge in marvellous gesticulation, Aeschin.

div1.head: τερατολογέω
div1.sense: to tell of marvels, Luc.

div1.head: τερατολογία
div1.sense: a telling of marvels, marvellous tales, Isocr., Luc.

div1.head: τερατολόγος
div1.sense: of which marvellous things are told, portentous, Plat.

div1.head: τερατουργός
div1.sense: a wonder-worker, Luc.

div1.head: τερατουργία
div1.sense: love of the marvellous, Luc.

div1.head: τερατώδης
div1.sense: portentous, Ar., Plat.

div1.head: τερατωπός
div1.sense: marvellous-looking, Hhymn.

div1.head: τερεβινθώδης
div1.sense: full of terebinth-trees, Anth.

div1.head: τερετίζω
div1.sense: to whistle, Babr.

div1.head: τερέτισμα
div1.sense: a whistling, trilling, Anth.

div1.head: τέρετρον
div1.sense: a borer, gimlet, Lat. terebra, Od.

div1.head: τερηδών
div1.sense: the wood-worm, Lat. teredo, Ar.

div1.head: τέρην
div1.sense: properly rubbed smooth, and so smooth, soft, delicate, Lat. tener, Hom., etc.; ὄψις τέρεινα a tender sight, i. e. one that causes tender feelings, Eur.:—comp. τερεινότερος, Sapph.

div1.head: τερθρεύομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to use claptraps, Dem.

div1.head: τέρθριος
div1.sense: the rope from the end of a sail-yard (τέρθρον) , the brace, Ar.

div1.head: τέρθρον
div1.sense: the end of the sail-yard, cornu antennae: generally, an extremity, summit, Hhymn.

div1.head: τέρμα
div1.sense: an end, boundary, Lat. terminus:
the goal round which chariots had to turn at races, Lat. meta, Il.; δρόμου τέρματα Soph.
the mark set to shew how far a quoit was thrown, Od.
metaph. an end, issue, event, Aesch.
generally, an end, limit, Aesch.; so in pl. boundaries, Hdt.
an end, πρὸς τέρμα εἶναι, ἐπὶ τέρμʼ ἀφικέσθαι to have reached the limit, be at the end, Aesch., Soph.; τ. βίου the term or end of life, death, Soph., Eur., etc.; ἐπὶ τέρματι at last, Aesch.
the end or highest point, κακῶν Eur.; πρὸς τέρμασιν ὥρας Ar.
periphr., τέρμα ὑγιείας ὑγιεία, Aesch.; τ. τῆς σωτηρίας Soph.
the highest power, supremacy, τ. Κορίνθου ἔχειν to be sovereign of Corinth, Simon.; θεοὶ ἁπάντων τέρμʼ ἔχοντες Eur.

div1.head: Τερμέρειον
div1.sense: Τερμέρειον, or Τερμέριον, κακόν, proverb. of a misfortune one brings on oneself, said to be derived from one Τέρμερος a highwayman, Plut.

div1.head: τερμίνθινος
div1.sense: of the terebinth-tree, Xen.

div1.head: τέρμινθος
div1.sense: the terebinth or turpentine tree, Theophr., Anth.

div1.head: τερμιόεις
div1.sense: going even to the end, ἀσπὶς τερμιόεσσα a shield that reaches from head to foot, Il.; so, χιτὼν τ. Od.

div1.head: τέρμιος
div1.sense: at the end, last, always of Time, τ. ἡμέραι the day of death, Soph.; τερμία χώρα the spot where one is destined to end life, Soph.

div1.head: τερμόνιος
div1.sense: at the worldʼs end, Aesch.

div1.head: τέρμων
div1.sense: a boundary, Eur.; and in pl., Eur.
= Lat. Terminus, Plut.
an end, βίου Eur.

div1.head: Τερπιάδης
div1.sense: son of delight, name of the minstrel Phemius, Od.

div1.head: τερπικέραυνος
div1.sense: delighting in thunder, Il., Hes.

div1.head: τερπνός
div1.sense: delightsome, delightful, pleasant, agreeable, glad, Theogn., Aesch., etc.; τὸ τερπνόν delight, pleasure, Thuc.; τὰ τερπνά delights, pleasures, Xen.
of persons, αὑτῷ τερπνός with joy to himself, Soph.:—comp. and Sup. τερπνότερος, -ότατος, Theogn.; later, -ιστος:—adv. τερπνῶς, Theogn.

div1.head: τέρπω
div1.sense: to satisfy, delight, gladden, cheer, Hom., Hdt., Attic:—absol. to give delight, Od.; τὰ τέρποντα delights, Soph.
Pass. and Mid.,
c. gen. rei, to have full enjoyment of a thing, have enough of it, Hom.; metaph., τεταρπώμεσθα γόοιο let us take our fill of lamentation, Hom.

to enjoy oneself, make merry, c. dat. modi, φόρμιγγι, μύθοισι, etc., Hom., etc.; so, τ. ἐν θαλίῃς Od., etc.:— also c. part., τέρψει κλύων Soph.; τέρπεται τιμώμενος Eur.:—absol., πῖνε καὶ τέρπου drink and be merry, Hdt.
c. acc. cogn. to enjoy, τ. ὄνησιν Eur.

div1.head: τερσαίνω
div1.sense: to dry up, wipe up, Il.

div1.head: τέρσομαι
div1.etym: Epic aor2 inf. τερσῆναι, τερσήμεναι, as if from ἐτέρσην
fut 3rd sg τέρσει as if from τέρρω.
div1.sense: to be or become dry, to dry up, ἕλκος ἐτέρσετο the wound dried up, Il.; θειλόπεδον τέρσεται ἠελίωι the plain is baked by the sun, Od.; c. gen., ὄσσε δακρυόφιν τέρσοντο eyes became dry of tears, Od.
Act. intr. in 3rd sg. fut. τέρσει (as if from τέρρω), Theocr.

div1.head: τερψίμβροτος
div1.sense: gladdening the heart of man, Ἥλιος Od.

div1.head: τερψίνοος
div1.sense: heart-gladdening, Anth.

div1.head: τέρψις
div1.sense: enjoyment, delight, τινός from or in a thing, Hes., Trag.; τέρψις ἐστί μοι, c. inf., it is my pleasure to do, Soph.:—absol. gladness, joy, delight, pleasure, Theogn., Aesch.

div1.head: Τερψιχόρη
div1.sense: Terpsichore, dance-enjoying, one of the nine Muses, Hes.

div1.head: τερψίχορος
div1.sense: enjoying the dance, Anth.

div1.head: τεσσαράβοιος
div1.sense: worth four steers, Il.

div1.head: τεσσαρακαιδεκάδωρος
div1.sense: fourteen hand-breadths long, Anth.

div1.head: τεσσαρακονταετής
div1.sense: forty years old, Hes.:— Attic fem. τετταρακονταετίς, ίδος, Plat.

div1.head: τεσσαράκοντα
div1.sense: forty, Hom., etc.
οἱ τ. the Forty, a body of justices who went round the Attic demes to hear causes, Dem.

div1.head: τεσσαρακοντόργυιος
div1.sense: forty fathoms high, Hdt.

div1.head: τεσσαρακοστός
div1.sense: fortieth, Lat. quadragesimus, Thuc.
τεσσαρακοστή μοῖρα, a fortieth, a coin of Chios, Thuc.

div1.head: τεσσαρεσκαίδεκα
div1.sense: fourteen, Lat. quatuordecim, the first part remaining unaltered with a neut. Subst., as, τεσσερεσκαίδεκα ἔτη Hdt.

div1.head: τεσσαρεσκαιδέκατος
div1.sense: fourteenth, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: τεσσαρεσκαιδεκέτης
div1.sense: fourteen years old, Plut.

div1.head: τέσσαρες
div1.sense: four, Lat. quatuor, Hom., etc.

div1.head: τεταγμένως
div1.etym: adverb from part. perf. pass. of τάσσω
div1.sense: in orderly manner, Xen.

div1.head: τεταγών
div1.etym: From Root !ταγ, cf. Lat. tango, tetigi.
τεταγών, όντος, ὁ, Epic redupl. aor2 part., with no pres. in use
div1.sense: ῥῖψε ποδὸς τεταγών having seized him by the foot, Il.; ῥίπτασκον τεταγών Il.

div1.head: τετανόθριξ
div1.sense: with long straight hair, Plat.

div1.head: τετανός
div1.sense: straightened, smooth, Anth.

div1.head: τεταραγμένως
div1.sense: confusedly, Isocr.

div1.head: τεταρταῖος
div1.sense: on the fourth day, τ. γενέσθαι to be four days dead, Hdt.; ἀφικνεῖσθαι τεταρταίους Plat.
τ. πυρετός a quartan fever, Plat.

div1.head: τεταρτημόριον
div1.sense: a fourth part, quadrans, Hdt.

div1.head: τέταρτος
div1.sense: fourth, Lat. quartus, Hom.
τὸ τέταρτον, as adv. the fourth time, Hom.: as adv., without Art., fourthly, Plat.
ἡ τετάρτη:
(sub. ἡμέρα) , the fourth day, Hes., Xen.
(sub. μοῖρα) , a liquid measure (cf. our quart), Hdt.

div1.head: τετευχῆσθαι
div1.sense: from the Subst. τεύχεα
div1.etym: Epic perf. pass. inf. with pres. sense, formed
div1.sense: to be armed, Od.

div1.head: τετίημαι
div1.etym: Epic perf. formed as if from τιέω, but with no pres. in use
div1.sense: to be sorrowful, to sorrow, mourn, τετίησθον Il.; τετιημένος (τετιημένη) ἦτορ sorrowful at heart, Hom.
so also in act. perf. part., τετιηότι θυμῶι with sorrowing heart, Il.; δὴν δʼ ἄνεῳ ἦσαν τετιηότες they were long silent from grief, Il.

div1.head: τέτμον
div1.sense: to overtake, reach, come up to, find, Hom.; of old age, to come upon one, Od.
c. gen. to partake of, Hes.

div1.head: τετολμηκότως
div1.etym: adverb from perf. part. of τολμάω, Polyb.

div1.head: τετραβάμων
div1.sense: four-footed, Eur.; τ. χηλαί, ψάλια the hoofs, trappings of horses, Eur.; τετραβάμοσι γυίοις in the shape of a quadruped, Eur.

div1.head: τετραγλώχις
div1.sense: with four angles, square, Anth.

div1.head: τετράγυος
div1.sense: containing four measures of land, Od.

div1.head: τετραγωνίζω
div1.sense: to make square, Plat.

div1.head: τετραγωνοπρόσωπος
div1.sense: square-faced, Hdt.

div1.head: τετράγωνος
div1.sense: with four equal angles, rectangular or square, Lat. quadratus, Hdt.; δοκοί τ. squared beams, Thuc.:— τετράγωνον, ου, a square, Plat.: a body of men drawn up in square, Lat. agmen quadratum, Xen.
τ. ἀριθμός a square number, i. e. a number multiplied into itself, Plat.
metaph. square, i. e. perfect, Simon. ap. Plat.

div1.head: τετράδιον
div1.sense: a number of four, a quarternion, NTest.

div1.head: τετράδραχμον
div1.sense: a coin of four drachms, a tedradrachm, worth about s. 2d., Plut.

div1.head: τετραέλικτος
div1.sense: four times wound round, Anth.

div1.head: τετραένης
div1.sense: of four years, four years old, Lat. quadrimus, Theocr.

div1.head: τετραετής
div1.sense: four years old, Hdt.
of four years, χρόνος Hdt.

div1.head: τετραετία
div1.sense: a term of four years, Plut.

div1.head: τετράζυγος
div1.sense: four-yoked, Eur.

div1.head: τετραθέλυμνος
div1.sense: of four layers, τ. σάκος a shield of four ox-hides, Hom.

div1.head: τετραίνω
div1.sense: to bore through, pierce, perforate, Hom.:—Pass., λίθος τετρημένος Hdt.; ὁ οὐρανὸς τέτρηται the sky has holes in it, Hdt.; χάσμα τῆς γῆς τετρημένον a chasm formed by perforating the earth, Plat.

div1.head: τετρακαιδεκαέτης
div1.sense: of fourteen years: fem. τετρακαιδεκέτις, ιδος, fourteen years old, Isocr.

div1.head: τετράκερως
div1.sense: four-horned, Anth.

div1.head: τετρακισμύριοι
div1.sense: four times ten thousand, forty thousand, Xen.

div1.head: τετράκις
div1.sense: four times, Lat. quater, Od., Hdt., Attic:— τετράκι, Pind.

div1.head: τετρακισχίλιοι
div1.sense: four thousand, Hdt., Attic

div1.head: τετράκλινος
div1.sense: with four couches, Luc.

div1.head: τετράκνημος
div1.sense: four-spoked, of a wheel, Pind.

div1.head: τετρακόρυμβος
div1.sense: with four clusters, i. e. thick clustering, Anth.

div1.head: τετρακόσιοι
div1.sense: four hundred, Hdt., etc.; in sg., τετρακοσία ἀσπίς Xen.
οἱ τ., at Athens, the oligarchy established in 411 B. C., Thuc.

div1.head: τετράκυκλος
div1.sense: four-wheeled, Hom., Hdt.

div1.head: τετρακωμία
div1.sense: a union of four villages, Strab.

div1.head: τετραλογία
div1.sense: a series of four dramas, three Tragedies and one Satyric play, exhibited at the festivals of Dionysus: the three Tragedies were called τριλογία, as the Oresteia of Aesch.

div1.head: τετράμετρος
div1.sense: consisting of four metres, i. e. in iambic or trochaic verse, consisting of four double feet or syzygies: τὸ τετράμετρον is generally the trochaic tetrameter, Ar., Xen.

div1.head: τετράμηνος
div1.sense: of four months, lasting four months, Thuc.

div1.head: τετραμοιρία
div1.sense: a four-fold portion, Xen.

div1.head: τετράμοιρος
div1.sense: fourfold, Eur.

div1.head: τέτραξ
div1.sense: perh. the pheasant, Ar.

div1.head: τετραορία
div1.sense: a four-horsed chariot, Pind.

div1.head: τετράορος
div1.sense: yoked four together, Od.; τ. ἅρμα a four-horsed chariot, Pind.
four-legged, Soph.

div1.head: τετραπάλαστος
div1.sense: four spans long or broad, Hdt.

div1.head: τετράπηχυς
div1.sense: gen. εως, four cubits (six feet) long, Hdt., Plat.; of men, six feet high, Ar.

div1.head: τετραπλάσιος
div1.sense: fourfold, four times as much, Lat. quadruplex, Plat.

div1.head: τετράπλεθρος
div1.sense: consisting of four plethra, Polyb.

div1.head: τετράπλευρος
div1.sense: four-sided, Anth.

div1.head: τετραπλῇ
div1.sense: in a fourfold manner, fourfold, Il.

div1.head: τετραπλόος
div1.sense: fourfold, Lat. quadruplus, Plut.; τὸ τ., τετραμοιρία, Xen.

div1.head: τετραποδηδόν
div1.sense: on four feet, Ar.

div1.head: τετραποδιστί
div1.sense: on all fours, Luc.

div1.head: τετράπολις
div1.sense: of or with four cities, λαὸς τ., of the northern part of Attica, Eur.

div1.head: τετράπολος
div1.sense: turned up or ploughed four times, Theocr.

div1.head: τετράπορος
div1.sense: with four passages or openings, Anth.
coming four ways, Anth.

div1.head: τετράπους
div1.sense: four-footed, Lat. quadrupes, Hdt.:— τετράπουν, a quadruped, pl. τετράποδα Hdt., Ar., etc.
of things, four feet in length, Plat.

div1.head: τετραπτερυλλίς
div1.sense: a four-wing, i. e. a grasshopper or locust, Ar.

div1.head: τετράπτιλος
div1.sense: four-winged, Ar.

div1.head: τετράρρυμος
div1.sense: with four poles, i. e. eight-horsed, Xen.

div1.head: τετραρχέω
div1.sense: to be tetrarch, τῆς Γαλιλαίας NTest.

div1.head: τετράρχης
div1.sense: a tetrarch, i. e. a ruler of one of four provinces, Strab., etc.

div1.head: τετραρχία
div1.sense: a tetrarchy, the province of a tetrarch, esp. in Thessaly, the four provinces being Thessaliotis, Phthiotis, Pelasgiotis, Hestiaeotis, Eur., Dem.
under the Romans the name tetrarchy was given to any division of a country, as to Palestine, which after Herod was divided into three tetrarchies, Plut., etc.

div1.head: τετρασκελής
div1.sense: four-legged, four-footed, τ. οἰωνός, of a kind of griffin, Aesch.; τ. ὕβρισμα the wanton violence of Centaurs, Eur.

div1.head: τετράς
div1.sense: the fourth day of the month, Hes., Ar.

div1.head: τετραστάδιος
div1.sense: four stades in length, Strab.: τετραστάδιον, ου, a length of four stades, Strab.

div1.head: τετράσχοινος
div1.sense: four σχοῖνοι long, Strab.

div1.head: τέτρατος
div1.sense: fourth, Hom., etc.; τὸ τέτρατον the fourth time, Il., Hes.

div1.head: τετράτρυφος
div1.sense: broken into four pieces, Hes.

div1.head: τετραφάληρος
div1.sense: epith. of a helmet, prob. with four crests or plumes, Il.

div1.head: τετράφυλος
div1.sense: divided into four tribes, Hdt.

div1.head: τέτραχα
div1.sense: in four parts, Plat.

div1.head: τετράχοος
div1.sense: holding four χόες, Anth.

div1.head: τετράχυτρος
div1.sense: made of four pots, Batr.

div1.head: τετρήμερος
div1.sense: of four days: μετὰ τὴν τετρήμερον (sc. ἡμέραν) after the fourth day, Arist.

div1.head: τετρήρης
div1.sense: (sc. ναῦς) , a quadrireme, Polyb.

div1.head: τετρόργυιος
div1.sense: of four fathoms, Anth.

div1.head: τετρώβολον
div1.sense: a four-obol piece, a soldierʼs daily pay, Ar.

div1.head: τετρώροφος
div1.sense: of four stories, Hdt.

div1.head: τέττα
div1.sense: a friendly or respectful address of youths to their elders, Father, Il.

div1.head: τεττιγοφόρας
div1.sense: wearing a τέττιξ: epith. of the Athenians (cf. τέττιξ 1. 2), Ar.

div1.head: τεττιγώδης
div1.sense: like a τέττιξ, Luc.

div1.head: τέττιξ
div1.sense: a kind of grasshopper, the cicala, Lat. cicada, an insect fond of basking on bushes, when the male makes a chirping noise by striking the wing against the breast, Il., etc.
χρύσεος τ. a golden cicada, worn by the Athenians before Solon.ʼs time, as an emblem of their claim to being αὐτόχθονες (for such was the supposed origin of the insect), Ar., Thuc.

div1.head: τετυφωμένως
div1.etym: adverb from pass. perf. part. of τυφόω
div1.sense: stupidly, Dem.

div1.head: τεῦγμα
div1.sense: that which is made, a work, Anth.

div1.head: τευθίς
div1.sense: a cuttle-fish, Ar.

div1.head: τευκτικός
div1.sense: able to gain, τινός Arist.

div1.head: τεῦξις
div1.sense: attainment: also = ἔντευξις, Anth.

div1.head: τευτάζω
div1.sense: to say or do the same thing, τ. περί τι to dwell upon a thing, be wholly engaged in it, Plat.

div1.head: τευτλόεις
div1.sense: of or full of beet: hence Τεύτλουσσα, Beet-island, Thuc.

div1.head: τεῦτλον
div1.sense: beet, Lat. beta, Batr., Ar., etc.

div1.head: τευχεσφόρος
div1.sense: wearing armour, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: τευχηστήρ
div1.sense: an armed man, warrior, Aesch.

div1.head: τεῦχος
div1.sense: a tool, implement:—mostly in pl. τεύχεα,
implements of war, armour, arms, harness, Hom., Hes.;—so τεύχη in Trag.
in pl., also, the gear of a ship, tackle, Od.

in sg. a vessel of any kind, a bathing-tub, Aesch.; a cinerary urn, Aesch., Soph.; a balloting-urn, Aesch.; a vase for libations, Aesch.; a vase or ewer for water, Eur.; a pot or jar, Xen.; ξύλινα τ. chests, Xen.
the human frame, body, Arist.
a book, Anth.; hence πεντάτευχος, the Pentateuch.

div1.head: τευχοφόρος
div1.sense: bearing arms, armed, Eur.

div1.head: τεύχω
div1.sense: to make ready, make, build, work, Hom., Hes., Trag.;—of a cook, δεῖπνον τετυκεῖν to dress or prepare a meal, Od.; and in Mid., δεῖπνον τετυκέσθαι to have a meal prepared, Hom.:—Pass., δώματα τετεύχαται Il.; θεῶν ἐτετεύχατο βωμοί Il.; c. gen., χρυσοῖο τετεύχαται are wrought of gold, Il.; also, τετυγμένα δώματα λάεσσιν built with stones, Od.; but, δόμος αἰθούσηισι τετυγμένος built or furnished with vestibules, Il.

the perf. part. τετυγμένος often passes into the sense of an adj., = τυκτός, well-made, well-wrought, Hom.; ἀγρὸς καλὸν τετ. well wrought, well tilled, Od.;—metaph., νόος τετυγμένος a ready, constant mind, Hom.
perf. act. part. once in pass. sense, ῥινοῖο τετευχώς made of hide, Hom.

of events, to cause, make, bring to pass, bring about, ὄμβρον ἠὲ χάλαζαν Il.; τ. βοήν to make a cry, Od.; τ. γάμον to bring it about, Od.:—Pass., esp. in perf., to be caused, and so to arise, occur, happen, exist, Hom., etc.

c. acc. pers. to make so and so, ἄγνωστον τ. τινά Od.; τ. τινὰ μέγαν, εὐδαίμονα Aesch., Eur.; c. dupl. acc., τί σε τεύξω; what shall I make of thee? Soph.;—hence in perf. pass. simply for γίγνεσθαι or εἶναι, Ζεὺς ταμίης πολέμοιο τέτυκται Il.; γυναικὸς ἄφʼ ἀντὶ τέτυξο thou wast like a woman, Il.

div1.head: τέφρα
div1.sense: ashes, Il., Ar.: also a kind of pungent dust or snuff, Ar.

div1.head: τεφρός
div1.sense: ash-coloured, Babr.

div1.head: τεχνάζω
div1.sense: to employ art, Arist.
to use art or cunning, deal subtly, use shifts or subterfuges, Hdt., Ar., etc.;—c. inf. to contrive cunningly that, Arist.: so aor1 mid. ἐτεχνασάμην, Hdt.

div1.head: τεχνάομαι
div1.sense: to make by art, to execute skilfully, Od.
also as Pass. to be made by art, Xen.
to contrive or execute cunningly, Il., Soph.:—absol., θεοῦ τεχνωμένου if God contrives, Soph.:—c. inf. to contrive how to do, Thuc.

div1.head: τέχνασμα
div1.sense: anything made or done by art, a handiwork, κέδρου τεχνάσματα, of a cedar-coffin, Eur.
an artifice, trick, Eur., Xen.

div1.head: τεχνήεις
div1.sense: cunningly wrought, Od.: —adv. τεχνηέντως, artfully, skilfully, Od.
of persons, γυναῖκες ἱστὸν τεχνῆσσαι (contr. from -ήεσσαι) skilful at the loom. Od.

div1.head: τέχνημα
div1.sense: = τέχνασμα, Soph.
of a man, the abstr. for the concr., πανουργίας τέχνημα a masterpiece of villainy, Soph.
an artful device, trick, artifice, Eur.:—generally a device, invention, Plat.

div1.head: τεχνήμων
div1.sense: cunningly wrought, αὐλοί Anth.

div1.head: τέχνη
div1.sense: art, skill, craft in work, cunning of hand, esp. of metal-working, Od.; of a shipwright, Il.; of a soothsayer, Aesch., Soph.
art, craft, cunning, in bad sense, δολίη τ. Od.; in pl. arts, wiles, cunning devices, Od., etc.
the way, manner or means whereby a thing is gained, without any sense of art or craft, μηδεμιῇ τέχνῃ in no wise, Hdt.; πάσῃ τέχνῃ by all means, Ar.; παντοίῃ τ. Soph.

an art, craft, trade, ἐπίστασθαι τὴν τ. to know his craft, Hdt.; ἐν τῇ τέχνῃ εἶναι to practise it, Soph.; ἐπὶ τέχνῃ μανθάνειν τι to learn a thing professionally, Plat.; τέχνην ποιεῖσθαί τι to make a trade of it, Dem.
an art, i. e. a system or method of making or doing, Plat., Arist.; ἢ φύσει ἢ τέχνῃ Plat.; μετὰ τέχνης, ἄνευ τέχνης Plat.
= τέχνημα, a work of art, handiwork, Soph.

div1.head: τεχνητός
div1.sense: artificial, Plut.

div1.head: τεχνικός
div1.sense: of persons, artistic, skilful, workmanlike, Plat., etc.
of things, made or done by art, artistic, systematic, Plat.
adv. -κῶς, by rules of art, in a workmanlike manner, Plat.

div1.head: τεχνίτης
div1.sense: an artificer, artisan, craftsman, skilled workman, Plat., etc.:—c. gen. rei, skilled in a thing, Xen.; also τι or περί τι Xen.
a trickster, intriguer, Luc.

div1.head: τεχνολογέω
div1.sense: to bring under rules of art, to systematize, Arist.

div1.head: τέως
div1.sense: so long, meanwhile, the while, correlat. to ἕως, ἕως ἐγὼ ἠλώμην, τείως . . while I was wandering, meantime . . Od.; ἐσθίων τέως, ἕως . . Ar.
for a time, a while, τείως μὲν . . , αὐτὰρ νῦν Od.; τέως μὲν . . , εἶτα δὲ . . Ar., etc.
up to this time, hitherto, Hdt., Ar.

div1.head: τῇδε
div1.etym: dat. fem. of ὅδε, as adv.
div1.sense: here, thus, Hom.

div1.head: τήθη
div1.sense: a grandmother, Ar., Plat., etc.

div1.head: τηθίς
div1.sense: a fatherʼs or motherʼs sister, aunt, Dem.

div1.head: τῆθος
div1.sense: an oyster, τήθεα διφῶν diving for oysters, Il.

div1.head: Τηθύς
div1.sense: Tethys, wife of Oceanus, Il.; daughter of Uranus and Gaia, mother of the river-gods and Oceanides, Hes.
in Virgil, Tethys is the sea itself.

div1.head: τηκεδών
div1.sense: a melting away: a wasting away, consumption, decline, Od.

div1.head: τηκτός
div1.sense: melted, molten, Eur.
soluble, Plat.

div1.head: τήκω
div1.etym: in classic Gr. the perf. and plup. pass. are supplied by the intr. act. perf. τέτηκα, ἐτετήκειν
