div1.sense: Act. to melt, melt down (trans.), of metals, Hdt., etc.: to dissipate clouds, Hdt.
metaph. to cause to waste or pine away, Od., Eur.

Pass., with intr. perf. act. τέτηκα, to be dissolved, melt away, of snow, to thaw, Od., Hdt., Attic; of metals, Hes.; ἄλφιτα πυρὶ τ. is consumed, Theocr.; of a corpse, to fall away, Soph.; πῦρ τετακός a dead fire, Eur.
metaph. to melt or waste away, pine, Hom., Hdt., Attic; βλέμμα τηκόμενον a languishing look, Plut.

div1.head: τηλαυγής
div1.sense: far-shining, far-beaming, Hhymn., Ar.
of distant objects, far-seen, conspicuous, Theogn., Soph.
adv. -γῶς, clearly, distinctly, NTest.

div1.head: τηλεβόλος
div1.sense: striking from afar, Pind.

div1.head: τηλέγονος
div1.sense: born far from oneʼs father or fatherland, Hes.

div1.head: τηλεδαπός
div1.sense: from a far country, Od.: of places, far off, distant, Il.

div1.head: τηλεθάω
div1.sense: luxuriant-growing, blooming, flourishing, ὕλη τηλεθόωσα Il.; ἐλαῖαι τηλεθόωσαι Od.; χαίτη τηλεθόωσα luxuriant hair, Il.

div1.head: τηλεκλειτός
div1.sense: far-famed, Hom.

div1.head: τηλεκλητός
div1.sense: summoned from afar, Il.

div1.head: τηλεμάχος
div1.sense: as prop. n. proparox., Τηλέμαχος, son of Ulysses, Od.

div1.head: τηλέπλανος
div1.sense: far-wandering, devious, Aesch.

div1.head: τηλέπομπος
div1.sense: far-sent, far-journeying, Aesch.

div1.head: τηλέπορος
div1.sense: far-travelling, far-reaching, ap. Ar.
far-distant, Soph.

div1.head: τηλέπυλος
div1.sense: with gates far apart, Od.

div1.head: τῆλε
div1.sense: at a distance, far off, far away, Hom., Hes.:—c. gen. far from, Hom.

div1.head: τηλεσκόπος
div1.sense: far-seeing, Ar.

div1.head: τηλέσκοπος
div1.sense: pass. far-seen, conspicuous, Hes., Anth.

div1.head: τηλεφανής
div1.sense: appearing afar, far-seen, conspicuous, Od., Ar.
of sound, heard plainly from afar, Soph.

div1.head: τηλέφιλον
div1.sense: faraway-love, love-in-absence, a plant used by lovers to try whether their love was returned; the leaf being laid on the hand was struck smartly, and a loud crack was a favourable omen, Theocr.

div1.head: τηλία
div1.sense: a board or table with a raised edge, a bakerʼs board, ap. Arist.
a table or stage whereon gamecocks and quails were set to fight, Aeschin.
a chimney-board, Ar.
the hoop of a corn-sieve, Ar.

div1.head: τηλικόσδε
div1.etym: strengthd. forms of τηλίκος as ὅδε, οὗτος of ὁ
div1.sense: of persons, of such an age, τηλικόσδʼ ὤν Soph., etc.; old as I am, Eur.; νοῦς τηλικοῦτος the mind of one so old as he is, Soph.:—of extreme youth, so young, τηλικάσδʼ ὁρῶν πάντων ἐρήμους girls of so tender age, Soph., etc.:—repeated in opp. senses, οἱ τηλικοίδε καὶ διδαξόμεσθα δὴ φρονεῖν ὑπʼ ἀνδρὸς τηλικοῦδε we old as we are shall take lessons forsooth from one so young, Soph.
of things, so great, so large, Lat. tantus, Plat., etc.

div1.head: τηλίκος
div1.sense: of such an age, so old or so young, antecedent to the relat. ἡλίκος, Hom.:—c. inf., οὐ ἐπὶ σταθμοῖσι μένειν τηλίκος not so young as to stay at home, Od.
so great, Lat. tantus, Anth.

div1.head: τηλόθεν
div1.sense: from afar, from a foreign land, Il., Soph.;— τηλόθε in Pind.
sometimes = τῆλε, τηλοῦ, Hom.; c. gen., τηλόθεν Πελειάδων far from them, Pind.

div1.head: τηλόθι
div1.sense: c. gen., τηλόθι πάτρης Il.

div1.head: τηλοπέτης
div1.sense: far-flying, Anth.

div1.head: τηλόσε
div1.sense: to a distance, far away, Il., Eur.

div1.head: τηλοτάτω
div1.sense: farthest away, Od.

div1.head: τηλοῦ
div1.sense: afar, far off or away, in a far country, Hom., Hes.; τηλοῦ ἀγρῶν in a far corner of the country, Ar.
c. gen., mostly, far from, Od.; τ. σέθεν far from thee, Eur.

div1.head: τηλουρός
div1.sense: with distant boundaries; hence far-away, distant, remote, Aesch., Eur.

div1.head: τηλύγετος
div1.sense: an only child, a darling child, Hom.; once of two sons, perhaps twins, Il.:—in Eur., τηλύγετος χθονὸς ἀπὸ πατρίδος, it means born far away, living away from, as if a compd. of τῆλυ ( = τῆλε) , γενέσθαι: but the Homeric sense is opposed to this; and the deriv. remains uncertain.

div1.head: τηλωπός
div1.sense: seen from afar, far away, Soph.
metaph. of sound, heard from afar, Soph.

div1.head: τημελέω
div1.sense: to protect, look after, c. acc., Eur.; c. gen. to take care of, Eur.

div1.head: τῆμος
div1.sense: then, thereupon, of past time, answering to the relat. ἦμος, Il., Soph., Theocr.

div1.head: τηνάλλως
div1.sense: elliptic for τὴν ἄλλως ἄγουσαν ὁδόν in the way leading differently, i. e. in no particular way, Plat.
to no purpose, in vain, Dem.

div1.head: τηνεῖ
div1.sense: there, Theocr.:—also = ὧδε, here, Theocr.

div1.head: τήνελλα
div1.sense: a word formed by Archilochus to imitate the twang of a guitar-string: from his hymn beginning with τήνελλα καλλίνικε, these words became the mode of saluting conquerors, Ar.
so in adj. form, ἐὰν νικᾷς, τήνελλος εἶ you will be greeted with huzzas, Ar.

div1.head: τηνικάδε
div1.sense: at this time of day, so early, Plat.

div1.head: τηνίκα
div1.sense: antec. to Relat. ἡνίκα, at that time, then; also with the Art. (often written τοτηνίκα) , Soph.
absol. at that time [of day], Theocr.

div1.head: τηνικαῦτα
div1.sense: at that time, then, Hdt., Soph., Xen.; c. gen., τ. τοῦ θέρους at this time of summer, Ar.
under these circumstances, in this case, Ar., Xen.

div1.head: τηνόθι
div1.sense: in that case, then, Theocr.

div1.head: τῆνος
div1.sense: he, she, it, Theocr.
like Lat. ille, iste, the famous, or the notorious, Theocr.

div1.head: τηνῶθεν
div1.etym: adverb of τῆνος, Doric for ἐκεῖθεν, Ar., Theocr.

div1.head: τηνῶ
div1.sense: there, Theocr.

div1.head: τηξιμελής
div1.sense: wasting the limbs, νοῦσος Anth.

div1.head: τῆ
div1.sense: take, in Hom. always followed by a second imperat., τῆ, σπεῖσον Διί Il.; τῆ, πίε οἶνον Od.; τῆ νῦν, καί σοι τοῦτο κειμήλιον ἔστω Il.

div1.head: τῇ
div1.sense: like ταύτῃ, here, there, Hom.

div1.head: τηρέω
div1.sense: to watch over, protect, guard, Pind., Ar.:—Pass. to be constantly guarded, Thuc.; fut. mid. τηρήσομαι in pass. sense, Thuc.
to take care that . . , Arist., Ar., Plat.
to give heed to, watch narrowly, observe, Ar.; τὰς ἁμαρτίας Thuc.
to watch for, c. acc., Soph., Ar.; παραστείχοντα τηρήσας having watched for him as he was passing by, Soph.
absol. to watch, keep watch, Arist.:—c. inf. to watch or look out, so as to . . , Thuc.
to observe or keep an engagement, Isocr., etc.; τ. εἰρήνην Dem.

div1.head: τήρησις
div1.sense: a watching, keeping, guarding, Arist.
vigilance, Thuc.
a means of keeping, a place of custody, Thuc.

div1.head: τηρητέος
div1.sense: one must watch, Plat.

div1.head: τηρός
div1.sense: a warden, guard, Aesch.

div1.head: τητάομαι
div1.sense: Pass., to be in want, suffer want, Hes.; τὸ τητᾶσθαι privation, Soph.
c. gen. to be in want of, be deprived or bereft of, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: τῆτες
div1.sense: this year, of or in this year, Ar. (τῆτες is related to σῆτες, ἔτος, as τήμερον to σήμερον, ἡμέρα.)

div1.head: τηΰσιος
div1.sense: idle, vain, undertaken to no purpose, Od.:—adv. τηυσίως, Theocr.

div1.head: τιάρα
div1.sense: a tiara, the Persian head-dress, Hdt.; worn by the great king, Aesch., Xen.

div1.head: τιαροειδής
div1.sense: shaped like or like a tiara, Xen.

div1.head: τίγρις
div1.sense: a tiger, unknown in Greece till after Alexanderʼs time.

div1.head: τίη
div1.sense: why? wherefore? Hom., Hes., and Attic Comedy; cf. ὁτιή.

div1.head: τιθαιβώσσω
div1.sense: of bees, to store up honey, Od.

div1.head: τιθασευτής
div1.sense: one who tames, Ar.

div1.head: τιθασεύω
div1.sense: to tame, domesticate, Plat., Xen.
of trees, to reclaim, cultivate, Plut.

div1.head: τιθασός
div1.sense: of animals, tame, domestic, Lat. cicur, Plat.; of plants, cultivated, Plut.
metaph. domestic, intestine, Ἄρης Aesch.

div1.head: τιθάς
div1.sense: τιθὰς ὄρνις, barn-door fowl, hen, Anth.

div1.head: τίθημι
div1.sense: in local sense, to set, put, place, Hom., etc.:—in Attic, πόδα τ. to plant the foot, i. e. walk, run, Aesch.; τετράποδος βάσιν θηρὸς τίθεσθαι, i. e. to go on all fours, Eur.: θεῖναί τινί τι ἐν χερσίν to put it in his hands, Il.; ἐς χεῖρά τινος into his hand, Soph.
θέσθαι τὴν ψῆφον to lay oneʼs voting-pebble on the altar, put it into the urn, Aesch.; so, τίθεσθαι τὴν γνώμην to give oneʼs opinion, Hdt.; and τίθεσθαι absol. to vote, Soph.

θεῖναί τινί τι ἐν φρεσί, ἐν στήθεσσι to put or plant it in his heart, Hom.; ἐν στήθεσσι τιθεῖ νόον Il., etc.: Mid., θέσθαι θυμὸν ἐν στήθεσσι to lay up wrath in oneʼs heart, Il.; θέσθαι τινὶ κότον to harbour enmity against him, Il.

to deposit, as in a bank, Hdt., Xen.; also, ἐγγύην θέσθαι Aesch.:—Pass., τὰ τεθέντα the deposits, Dem.:—metaph., χάριν or χάριτα θέσθαι τινί to deposit a claim for favour with one, to lay an obligation on one, Hdt., etc.
to pay down, pay, Dem.
to place to account, put down, reckon, in rationes referre, Dem.
in military language, τίθεσθαι τὰ ὅπλα has three senses,
to pile arms, as in a camp, to bivouac, Thuc.:—hence, to take up a position, draw up in order of battle, Hdt., etc.
to lay down oneʼs arms, surrender, Xen.; so, πόλεμον θέσθαι to settle, end it, Thuc.
εὖ θέσθαι ὅπλα to keep oneʼs arms in good order, Xen.; like εὖ ἀσπίδα θέσθω, Il.
to lay in the grave, bury, Il., Aesch., etc.
τιθέναι τὰ γόνατα to kneel down, NTest.
to set up prizes in games, Lat. proponere, Il., etc.:— Pass., τὰ τιθέμενα the prizes, Dem.
θεῖναι ἐς μέσον, Lat. in medio ponere, to lay before people, Hdt.; so, τ. εἰς τὸ κοινόν Xen.
to set up ina temple, to devote, dedicate, Hom., Eur.
to assign, award, τιμήν τινι Il.:—Mid., ὄνομα θέσθαι to give a name, Od., Hdt., etc.

τιθέναι νόμον to lay down or give a law, of a legislator, Soph., etc.: Mid., of republican legislatures, to give oneself a law, make a law, Hdt., etc.:—so, θεῖναι θεσμόν Aesch.; σκῆψιν θεῖναι to allege an excuse, Soph.
to establish, institute, ἀγῶνα Aesch., Xen.
to ordain, command, c. acc. et inf., Xen.; γυναιξὶ σωφρονεῖν θήσει Eur.; so, with Advs., οὕτω νῦν Ζεὺς θείη so may he ordain, Od.; ὣς ἄρʼ ἔμελλον θησέμεναι Il.

to put in a certain state, to make so and so, θεῖναί τινα αἰχμητήν, μάντιν Hom.; θεῖναί τινα ἄλοχόν τινος to make her anotherʼs wife, Il.; τοῖόν με ἔθηκε ὅπως ἐθέλει has made me such as she will, Od.; σῦς ἔθηκας ἑταίρους thou didst make my comrades swine, Od.; ναῦν λᾶαν ἔθηκε Od.:—so, with an adj., θεῖναί τινα ἀθάνατον to make him immortal, Od.; also of things, ὄλεθρον ἀπευθέα θῆκε left it unknown, Od.:—often in Mid., γυναῖκα or ἄκοιτιν θέσθαι τινά to make her oneʼs wife, Od.; παῖδα or υἱὸν τίθεσθαί τινα, like ποιεῖσθαι, to make her oneʼs child, adopt him, Plat.
c. inf. to make one do so and so, τιθέναι τινὰ νικῆσαι to make him conquer, Pind., etc.
in reference to mental action, mostly in Mid., to lay down, assume, hold, reckon or regard as so and so, τί δʼ ἐλέγχεα ταῦτα τίθεσθε; Od.; εὐεργέτημα τ. τι Dem.
foll. by Advs., ποῦ χρὴ τίθεσθαι ταῦτα; in what light must we regard these things? Soph.; οὐδαμοῦ τιθέναι τι to hold of no account, nullo in numero habere, Eur.
foll. by Preps., τ. τινὰ ἐν τοῖς φίλοις Xen.; τίθεσθαί τινα ἐν τιμῆι Hdt.; θέσθαι παρʼ οὐδέν to set at naught, Aesch., etc.
with an inf., οὐ τίθημʼ ἐγὼ ζῆν τοῦτον I hold not that he lives, count him not as living, Soph.
to lay down, assume, Plat., etc.
to make, work, execute, Lat. ponere, of an artist, ἐν δʼ ἐτίθει νεῖον Il.
to make, cause, bring to pass, ἔργα Il.; ὀρυμαγδόν Od., etc.
in Mid. to make for oneself, θέσθαι κέλευθον to make oneself a road, Il.; μεγάλην ἐπιγουνίδα θέσθαι to get a large thigh, Od.; θέσθαι πόνον to work oneself annoy, Aesch.
periphr. for a single Verb. σκέδασιν θεῖναι σκεδάσαι, to make a scattering, Od.; so in Mid., θέσθαι μάχην for μάχεσθαι, Il.; σπουδήν, πρόνοιαν θέσθαι Soph.
εὖ θέσθαι to settle, arrange, or manage well, τὰ σεωυτοῦ Hdt.; τὸ παρόν Thuc.:—also, καλῶς θεῖναι or θέσθαι Soph., Eur.; εὖ θέσθαι Soph.

div1.head: τιθηνέω
div1.sense: to nurse, suckle, tend as nurse, Theogn., Xen.
to keep up, maintain, Soph.

div1.head: τιθήνη
div1.sense: a nurse, Il., Soph.

div1.head: τιθηνητήριος
div1.sense: nursing, Anth.

div1.head: τιθηνητήρ
div1.sense: = τιθηνός, Anth.:—fem. -τειρα, τιθήνη, Anth.

div1.head: τιθηνός
div1.sense: nursing, πόνων τιθηνοὺς ἀποδιδοῦσά σοι τροφάς repaying thee nursing tendance for nursing labours, Eur.

div1.head: τιθύμαλλος
div1.sense: spurge, euphorbia; heterocl. pl. τιθύμαλα, Anth.

div1.head: Τιθωνός
div1.sense: Tithonus, brother of Priam, husband of Eos (Aurora), and father of Memnon, Hom.:—metaph. of a decrepit old man, because Aurora begged Zeus to grant immortality to Tithonus, but forgot to ask for eternal youth, Ar.; ὑπὲρ τὸν Τιθωνὸν ζῆν Luc.

div1.head: τίκτω
div1.sense: to bring into the world; of the father, to beget, of the mother, to bring forth, Hom., Attic; so also in Mid., Il.; οἱ τεκόμενοι of the mother, Aesch.
the 3rd pl. aor2 τέκον, ἔτεκον is used of both parents, Hom.: hence οἱ τεκόντες the parents, Aesch., Soph.
separately, ὁ τεκών the father, Aesch.; ἡ τεκοῦσα the mother, Aesch.; and as Subst., c. gen., ὁ κείνου τεκών Eur.
of female animals, to bear young, breed, Hom.; ὠιὰ τ. to lay eggs, Hdt.
of vegetable produce, to bear, produce, [γαῖα τίκτει ἔμπεδα μῆλα Od.:—so in Mid., γαῖαν ἣ τὰ πάντα τίκτεται Aesch.
metaph. to generate, produce, τὸ δυσσεβὲς ἔργον πλείονα τίκτει Aesch.; of Night as the mother of Day, τῆς τεκούσης φῶς τόδʼ εὐφρόνης Aesch.; τ. ἀοιδάς Eur.; πόλεμον Plat.

div1.head: τίλλω
div1.sense: to pluck or pull out hair, Lat. vello, Il.; so in Mid., χαίτας τίλλεσθαι to pluck out oneʼs hair, Od.
with acc. of that from which the hair or feathers are plucked, τίλλειν πέλειαν Od.; κάρα τ. Aesch.; τ. πλάτανον to pluck its leaves off, Plut.:— Pass. to have oneʼs hair plucked out, Ar.
Mid., τίλλεσθαί τινα to tear oneʼs hair in sorrow for any one, Il.
metaph. to pluck, vex, annoy, Lat. vellicare, Pass., Ar.

div1.head: τίλσις
div1.sense: a plucking out, Arist.

div1.head: τίλων
div1.sense: a fish of the Thracian lake Prasias, Hdt.

div1.head: τιμαλφέω
div1.sense: to do honour to, Aesch.

div1.head: τιμαλφής
div1.sense: fetching a prize, costly, precious, Plat.

div1.head: τιμάοχος
div1.sense: having honour, Hhymn.

div1.head: τιμάω
div1.sense: to pay honour to, hold in honour, to honour, revere, reverence, Hom., Hdt., Attic:— absol. to bestow honours, Dem.:—hence, simply, to reward, Hdt., Xen.:—Pass. to be honoured, held in honour, Hdt.; c. gen. rei, τιμῆς τετιμῆσθαι to be held worthy of honour, Il.
of things, to hold in honour, value, prize, Pind., Eur.:—also = προτιμάω, to prefer, Aesch.
c. gen. pretii, to estimate, value or assess at a certain price, Thuc.:—so in Mid., Xen., etc.
rarely, to give as an honour, Pind., Soph.
as Attic law-term:

in Act., of the judge, to estimate the amount of punishment due to the criminals, award the penalty, Lat. litem aestimare, Plat.; τ. τὴν μακράν τινι to award him the long line, i. e. sentence of death, Ar.; absol., τιμᾶν βλέπω I carry penalty in my eyes, Ar.:—the sentence awarded in gen., τ. τινί θανάτου (sc. δίκην) to give sentence of death against a man, i. e. to condemn him to death, Plat., Dem.; τίνος τιμήσειν αὐτῶι προσδοκᾶις τὸ δικαστήριον; at what do you expect the court to fix his penalty? Dem.:—Pass., τιμᾶσθαι ἀργυρίου to be condemned to a fine, τινος for a thing, Lex ap. Dem., etc.
Mid., of the parties before the court (cf. τίμημα 2),
of the accuser, τιμᾶταί μοι ὁ ἀνὴρ θανάτου (sc. τὴν δίκην) he estimates the penalty due to me at death (gen. pretii), Plat., etc.
of the person accused, τιμήσεσθαι τοιούτου τινὸς ἐμαυτῶι to estimate the penalty due to me at so high a rate, Plat.
with acc. of the penalty or offence, πέντε μυριάδων τιμησάμενος τὴν δίκην Plut., etc.

div1.head: τιμήεις
div1.sense: honoured, esteemed, Hom.:—comp., τιμηέστερος Od.
of things, prized, costly, Hom.: Sup. τιμηέστατος Od.

div1.head: τίμημα
div1.sense: an estimate, valuation, Eur., Dem.
an estimate of damages, a penalty, Lat. litis aestimatio, Ar., Plat.:—generally a payment, τύμβου for neglect of his tomb, Aesch.
estimate of property for taxation, rateable property, Lat. census, Plat., etc.; ἡ ἀπὸ τιμημάτων πολιτεία, τιμοκρατία, Xen.

div1.head: τιμή
div1.sense: that which is paid in token of worth or value:
worship, esteem, honour, and in pl. honours, Hom., etc.; ἐν τ. ἄγεσθαι, τίθεσθαι τινά Hdt.; ἀπονέμειν, ἀποδοῦναι Soph., Plat.:—c. gen., ἡ τ. θεῶν the honour due to them, Aesch.
honour, dignity, lordship, Hom.:— the prerogative of a king, and in pl. prerogatives, Od., Trag.
a dignity, office, magistracy, and in pl., like Lat. honores, civil honours, Hdt., Attic; οἱ ἐν τιμαῖς men in office, Eur.; τιμὴ ἄχαρις a thankless office, Hdt.
an authority, magistracy, τ. δίσκηπτρος, of the Atridae, Aesch., Soph.
a present of honour, offering, Hes., Aesch.: a reward, present, Lat. honorarium, Soph.
of things, worth, value, or price, Lat. pretium, ἐξευρίσκειν τιμῆς τι to get a thing at a price (i. e. a high price), Hdt.; ἐμοὶ δὲ τιμὰ τᾶσδε πᾶ γενήσεται; how shall I get payment for this? Ar.
an estimate of damages, compensation, ἄρνυσθαί τινι τιμήν to get one compensation, Il.; τίνειν or ἀποτίνειν τιμήν τινι to pay or make it, Il.; οὐ σὴ ἡ τιμή not yours the penalty, Plat.
a valuation, estimate, for purposes of assessment, τοῦ κλήρου Plat.

div1.head: τίμησις
div1.sense: a valuation of property, value, Plat.
an assessment of damages, Aeschin., etc.; a rating or assessment, Arist.

div1.head: τιμητεία
div1.sense: the censorship, Lat. censura, Plut.

div1.head: τιμητέος
div1.sense: to be honoured, valued, Eur., Plat., etc.
τιμητέον, one must honour, esteem, estimate, Xen., etc.

div1.head: τιμητεύω
div1.sense: to be censor, Plut.

div1.head: τιμητής
div1.sense: a valuer, estimater, Plat.
at Rome, the censor, who assessed the property of the citizens, Polyb.

div1.head: τιμητικός
div1.sense: forming an estimate,
for determining the amount of punishment, πινάκιον τ. Ar.
for determining the amount of property, ἡ τιμητικὴ ἀρχή τιμητεία, Plut.: τιμητικός, οῦ, Lat. vir censorius, one who has been censor (τιμητής) , Plut.

div1.head: τιμητός
div1.sense: rateable, v. ἀτίμητος.

div1.head: τίμιος
div1.sense: valued:
of persons, held in honour, honoured, worthy, Od., Hdt., Attic
of things, costly, prized, Trag.: also costly, dear, Hdt.
conferring honour, honourable, Aesch., Xen.:— τὰ τιμιώτατα τὰ φίλτατα, Dem.

div1.head: τιμιότης
div1.sense: worth, value, preciousness, Arist.

div1.head: τιμοκρατία
div1.sense: a state in which the love of honour is the ruling principle, Plat.
a state in which honours are distributed according to property, timocracy, Arist.

div1.head: τιμοκρατικός
div1.sense: of or for a τιμοκρατία 1, Plat.
ἡ τ. πολιτεία, τιμοκρατία II, Arist.

div1.head: τῖμος
div1.etym: poetic form of τιμή II, Aesch.

div1.head: τιμωρέω
div1.sense: to help, aid, succour, τινί Hdt., Soph., etc.:—absol. to lend aid, give succour, Hdt.

to assist one who has suffered wrong, to avenge him, c. dat., Hdt.:—so in Mid., Soph., Eur.:—in full construction the person avenged is in dat., the person on whom vengeance is taken in acc., and the crime avenged in gen., τιμωρεῖν τινι τοῦ παιδὸς τὸν φονέα to avenge him on the murderer for [the murder of] his son, Xen.:—also, c. acc. rei, τ. τὸν φόνον to avenge his slaughter, Plat.:—Pass. to be visited with vengeance, Soph., etc.; impers., τετιμώρηται τῶι Λεωνίδηι vengeance has been taken for him, he has been avenged, Hdt.

τιμωρεῖν τινά to take vengeance on him, Soph.:—in Mid. to exact vengeance from, visit with punishment, τινά Hdt., Attic; Ἑαυτὸν τιμωρούμενος Self-tormentor, name of a play by Menander:—c. gen. rei, τιμωρεῖσθαί τινά τινος to take vengeance on one for a thing, Hdt., Attic:—so, also, τ. τινὰ ἀντί τινος Hdt.: —c. acc. rei, σʼ ἀδελφῆς αἷμα τιμωρήσεται will visit thy sisterʼs blood on thee, Eur.

in Mid. also absol. to avenge oneself, seek vengeance, Hdt., Xen., etc.; τὸ τιμωρησόμενον the probability of vengeance, Dem.; ἐς Λεωνίδεα τετιμωρήσεαι thou wilt have vengeance taken in respect to Leonidas, Hdt.

div1.head: τιμώρημα
div1.sense: help, aid, succour given, c. dat., Hdt.
an act of vengeance: a penalty, Plat.

div1.head: τιμωρητέος
div1.sense: one must assist, Hdt.; so in pl. τιμωρητέα, Thuc.
one must visit with vengeance, punish, τινά Isocr.
τιμωρητέος, α, ον, that ought to be punished, Dem.

div1.head: τιμωρητήρ
div1.sense: an avenger, Hdt.

div1.head: τιμωρητικός
div1.sense: revengeful, Arist.; τὰ τιμωρητικά acts of revenge, Arist.

div1.head: τιμωρία
div1.sense: help, aid, assistance, succour, Hdt., Thuc.

assistance to one who has suffered wrong, retribution, vengeance, punishment, Hdt., etc.; πατρὸς τ. vengeance taken for him, Eur.; ἐπὶ τῇ ἡμετέρᾳ τ. for the purpose of punishing us, Thuc.; ποιεῖσθαι τιμωρίαν to execute vengeance, Dem.; τ. εὑρεῖν τινος to find vengeance at his hand, Aesch.; τιμωρίαν λαμβάνειν, τιμωρίας τυγχάνειν are used both of the avenger and the sufferer, Plat., Thuc.:—in pl., penalties, Plat.

div1.head: τιμωρός
div1.sense: upholding honour; and so,
helping, aiding, succouring, and as Subst. a helper, aider, Hdt., Thuc.; τὸν ἐμὸν τιμάορον my tutelary god, Aesch.

assisting one who has suffered wrong, avenging, and as Subst. an avenger, Aesch., Soph., etc.; c. gen. rei, helping one to vengeance for a thing, Soph.:— λόγος τ. a plea or argument for vengeance, Hdt.

div1.head: τίναγμα
div1.sense: a shake, quake, Anth.

div1.head: τινάκτειρα
div1.sense: a shaker, τῆς τινάκτειρα νόσος, of Poseidonʼs trident, Aesch.

div1.head: τινάκτωρ
div1.sense: a shaker, τ. γαίας, of Poseidon, Soph.

div1.head: τινάσσω
div1.sense: to shake or brandish a weapon or shield, Il., Aesch., etc.

generally, to shake, τ. γαῖαν, of Poseidon, Il.; θρόνον ἐτίναξε upset the seat, Od.: of wind, to scatter, Od.:—Mid., τιναξάσθην πτερά they shook their wings, Od.:—Pass., ἐτινάσσετο Ὄλυμπος shook or quaked, Hes.

div1.head: τίνυμαι
div1.sense: to punish, chastise, c. acc. rei, λώβην τινύμενος chastising insolence, Od.: absol. to avenge oneself, Hdt.
to avenge, take vengeance for a thing, c. acc., Hes., Eur.
to exact as penalty, δὶς τόσα Hes.

div1.head: τίνω
div1.sense: Act. to pay a price by way of return, to pay a penalty (whereas τίω means to pay, honour), Hom., Soph., etc.:—also to pay a debt, acquit oneself of an obligation, τίσειν αἴσιμα πάντα Od.; τ. χάριν τινί to render one thanks, Aesch.; τ. ἰατροῖς μισθόν Xen.:—also to pay for, repay, εὐαγγέλιον Od.; τροφάς τινι Eur.:—with gen. of the thing for which one pays, τ. ἀμοιβὴν βοῶν τινί to pay compensation for the oxen, Od.; also, τ. πληγὴν ἀντὶ πληγῆς Aesch.:—but also with acc. of the thing for which one pays, the price being omitted, to pay or atone for a thing, τίνειν ὕβριν Hom.; τ. μητρὸς δίκας for thy mother, Eur.:—more rarely c. acc. pers., τίσεις γνωτὸν τὸν ἔπεφνες thou shalt make atonement for the son thou hast slain, Il.
absol. to make return or requital, Solon, Soph.
Mid. to have a price paid one, make another pay for a thing, avenge oneself on him, to chastise, punish, Lat. poenas sumere de aliquo, c. acc. pers., Hom., Trag., etc.
c. gen. criminis, τίσεσθαι Ἀλέξανδρον κακότητος to punish him for his wickedness, Hom., Hdt.
c. acc. rei, to take vengeance for a thing, Hom.
c. dupl. acc. pers. et rei, ἐτίσατο ἔργον ἀεικὲς ἀντίθεον Νηλῆα he made Neleus pay for the misdeed, visited it on his head, Od.; also, τίσασθαί τινα δίκην to exact retribution from a person, Eur.
absol. to repay oneself, take vengeance, Hom.

div1.head: τιό
div1.sense: τιό, τιό, imitation of a birdʼs note, also τιοτίγξAr.

div1.head: τίποτε
div1.sense: τίποτε, or τί ποτε; what or why, tell me? Lat. quid tandem? Soph.

div1.head: τίπτε
div1.etym: Epic syncop. form for τίποτε; Hom., Aesch.

div1.head: τίσις
div1.sense: payment by way of return or recompense, retribution, vengeance, Hom., etc.; τίσιν δοῦναί τινος to suffer punishment for an act, Lat. poenas dare, Hdt.; κασιγνήτου τίσις for him, Soph.; in pl., Ὀροίτεα τίσιες μετῆλθον (where it may be personified, avengers, like Ἐρίνυες) , Hdt.
power to repay or requite, both in bad and good sense, Theogn.

div1.head: τίς
div1.sense: in direct questions, who? which? neut. what? which? Lat. quis, quae, quid?, Hom., etc.: relating to other words in the same case, τίς δʼ οὗτος ἔρχεαι; who art thou that comest? Il.; τίνʼ ὄψιν σὴν προσδέρκομαι; what face is this I see of thine? Eur.:— τίς ἄν or κεν, with the opt., expresses doubt, who could, who would do so? Hom.: —in double questions, τί λαβόντα τί δεῖ ποιεῖν; what has one received and what must one do? Dem.; so, τίς πόθεν εἶς ἀνδρῶν; who and whence art thou? Od.
τίς with Particles: τίς γάρ; Lat. quisnam? why who? who possibly? Il., etc.; τίς δή; who then? Theogn.; τίς δῆτα; Soph.; τίς ποτε; who in the world? who ever? Xen.

neut. τί; as a simple question, what? Aesch.; also, why? Il. b. τί μοι; τί σοι; what is it to me? to thee? Soph., etc.; c. gen., τί μοι ἔριδος; what have I to do with the quarrel? Il.; τί ἐμοὶ καὶ σοί; what is there (in common) to me and thee? what have I to do with thee? NTest. c. τί with Particles:— τί γάρ; why not? how else? Lat. quid enim? quidni? i. e. of course, no doubt, Aesch., etc.; τί δέ; Lat. quid vero? Plat.; τί δέ, εἰ . .; but what, if . .? Eur.; τί δή; τί δήποτε; why ever? why in the world? Plat.:— τί μή; why not? Lat. quidni? Trag.:— τί μή; i. e. yes certainly, Plat., etc.
τίς is sometimes used for ὅστις in indirect questions, ἠρώτα δὴ ἔπειτα, τίς εἴη καὶ πόθεν ἔλθοι Od.; οὐκ ἔχω τί φῶ Aesch.

τίς; τί; with part., followed by a verbal clause, forms one sentence in Greek where we use two, εἴρετο τίνες ἐόντες προαγορεύουσι; who they were that proclaim? Hdt.; καταμεμάθηκας τοὺς τί ποιοῦντας τοὔνομα τοῦτʼ ἀποκαλοῦσιν; have you learnt what they do whom men call so and so? Xen.
τί was never elided; but the hiatus is allowed in Attic, τί οὖν; Ar.; τί ἔστιν; Soph.; τί εἶπας; Soph.

div1.head: τις
div1.sense: Indef. Pron. any one, any thing, some one, some thing; and as adj. any, some, and serving as the Indef. Art. a, an: in the latter case it agrees with its Subst., φίλος τις a friend, θεός τις a god, i. e. not a man; in the former it is followed by gen. pl., φίλων τις one of thy friends, θεῶν τις one of the gods.
special usages:
some one (of many), i. e. many a one, ὧδε δέ τις εἴπεσκεν so men said, Hom.

any one concerned, each one, Il.; τοὺς ξυμμάχους αὐτόν τινα κολάζειν that every man should himself chastise his own allies, Thuc.; ἄμεινόν τινος better than any others, Dem.:—this is more fully expressed by adding other pronominal words, τις ἕκαστος Od., etc.; πᾶς τις Hdt., etc.; οὐδείς or μηδείς τις Eur., Xen.
in reference to a person, whom one avoids naming, δώσει τις δίκην some one I know will suffer, Ar.; so euphem. for something bad, ἤν τι ποιῶμεν, ἤν τι πάθωμεν Thuc.
indefinitely, where we say they, French on, μισεῖ τις ἐκεῖνον they hate him, Dem.

τις, τι, emphat. of a person or thing, some great one, some great thing, ηὔχεις τις εἶναι you boasted that you were somebody, Eur.; δοκοῦσι τινὲς εἶναι Dem.; κἠγών τις φαίνομαι ἦμες I too seem to be somebody, Theocr.; so in neut., οἴονταί τι εἶναι Plat.; so, λέγειν τι to be near the mark, opp. to οὐδὲν λέγειν, Plat.
emphat. a man, opp. to a brute, τις ἢ κύων Ar.: reversely, with sense of contempt, Θερσίτης τις ἦν there was one Thersites, Soph.
with prop. names τις commonly signifies one of the same sort, as, ἤ τις Ἀπόλλων ἢ Πάν either an Apollo or a Pan, Aesch.; Ἀφροδίτη τις Eur.
with Adjs. τις takes a restrictive sense, ὥς τις θαρσαλέος ἐσσι a bold kind of fellow, i. e. very bold, Od.; δυσμαθής τις a dull sort of person, Plat.

with numerals, ἑπτά τινες some seven, seven or so, Thuc.; ἐς διακοσίους τινάς Thuc.; so without numeral, ἡμέρας τινάς some days, i. e. several, Thuc.; ἐνιαυτόν τινα a year or so, Thuc.; so, οὐ πολλοί τινες, τινες οὐ πολλοί, ὀλίγοι τινές Thuc.:—so also ὅσος τις χρυσός what a store of gold, Od.

with Pronominal words, οἷός τις what sort of a man, Il.; ποῖός and ὁποῖός τις Soph., Xen., etc.; τις τοιόσδε Hdt.; τοιοῦτός τις Xen.:— ὅταν δʼ ὁ κύριος παρῇ τις when the lord, whoever he be, is here, Soph.:—in opposed clauses, ὁ μέν τις . . , ὁ δὲ . . Eur., Plat., etc.
the neut. τι is used as adv. somewhat, in any degree, at all, Il., etc.
ἤ τις ἢ οὐδείς few or none, next to none, Hdt.; ἤ τι ἢ οὐδέν little or nothing, Plat.

div1.head: τιταίνω
div1.sense: to stretch, τόξα τιταίνων bending his bow, Il.; so in Mid., ἐτιταίνετο τόξα was bending his bow, Hom.
to stretch out, ἐτίταινε τάλαντα was holding them out, Il.; ἐτίταινε τραπέζας was laying them out, Od.
to draw at full stretch, of horses, etc., ἅρμα τιταίνειν Il.; ἄροτρον τιταίνετον Il.; absol., τιταίνετον haste along, Il.

Pass. to strain or exert oneself, chiefly in part., τιταινόμενος with vehement effort, Od.; of a horse galloping, τιταινόμενος πεδίοιο stretching over the plain (ventre à terre), Il.; so of birds, τιταινομένω πτερύγεσσιν Od.

div1.head: Τιτανοκράτωρ
div1.sense: conqueror of the Titans, Luc.

div1.head: Τιτανοκτόνος
div1.sense: slaying Titans, Batr.

div1.head: τίτανος
div1.sense: a white earth, chalk or gypsum, Hes.

div1.head: Τιτάν
div1.sense: the Titans, a race of gods placed beneath Tartarus, Il. (where two are named—Iapetus and Cronus), acc. to Hes., six sons and six daughters of Uranus and Gaia; hurled from Olympus into nether darkness, Hes.: other names are given by later Poets, as Atlas, Aesch.; Prometheus, Soph.; Θέμις Aesch.; and in Lat. Poets Titan is the Sun-god.
div1.etym: The oldest deriv. of the name is given in Hes., the stretchers, strivers; others connect it with τίτας (from τίνω), avengers.

div1.head: Τιτανώδης
div1.sense: Titan-like, Titanic, Τιτανῶδες βλέπειν Luc.

div1.head: τίτης
div1.sense: = τιμωρός, avenger, Aesch.

div1.head: τιτθεία
div1.sense: an acting as a nurse, nursing, Dem.

div1.head: τιτθεύω
div1.sense: to be a nurse, act as a nurse, Dem.
trans. to suckle, nurse, Dem.

div1.head: τίτθη
div1.sense: a nurse, Ar.

div1.head: τιτθός
div1.sense: a teat, nipple, Lys..

div1.head: τίτλος
div1.sense: the Lat. titulus, a title, inscription, NTest.

div1.head: τιτρώσκω
div1.etym: Root !τρω, whence the tenses are formed
div1.sense: to wound, Hom.:—Pass., τετρῶσθαι τὸν μηρόν to have a wound in the thigh, Hdt.: —c. acc. cogn., τιτρώσκειν φόνον to inflict a death wound, Eur.
generally, to damage, cripple, of ships, Hdt., Thuc.
metaph., of wine, to do one a mischief, Eur., Xen.

div1.head: Τιτυοκτόνος
div1.sense: slaying Tityus, Anth.

div1.head: Τιτυός
div1.sense: Tityus, son of Gaia, a giant, Od.

div1.head: Τίτυρος
div1.sense: an ape, Theophr.

div1.head: τιτύσκομαι
div1.etym: combines the senses of τεύχω, τυγχάνω
div1.sense: like τεύχω, to make, make ready, prepare, τιτύσκετο πῦρ Il.; ὑπʼ ὄχεσφι τιτύσκετο ἵππω he put two horses to the chariot, Il.
like τυγχάνω, to aim, shoot, τινός at a person, Il.:—absol., βάλλε τιτυσκόμενος Od.; ἄντα τιτύσκεσθαι to aim at a mark right opposite, Od.; so, of one putting a key into a lock, ἄντα τιτυσκομένη Od.
metaph., φρεσὶ τιτύσκεσθαι to aim at doing a thing, i. e. to purpose, design, c. inf., Hom.

div1.head: τίφη
div1.sense: an insect, perh. the water-spider, that runs on the top of smooth water, Lat. tipula, Ar.

div1.head: τῖφος
div1.sense: standing water, a pond, pool, marsh, Theocr.

div1.head: τίω
div1.sense: to pay honour to a person (whereas τίνω means to pay a price), to honour, Hom., Aesch., Eur.:—Pass., perf. pass. part. τετιμένος honoured, Hom.
= τιμάω II, τὸν δὲ τρίποδα to value, τρίποδα δωδεκάβοιον τῖον they valued the tripod at twelve steersʼ worth, Il.; τῖον δέ ἑ τεσσαράβοιον valued her at four steersʼ worth, Il.
for fut. and aor1 τίσω, ἔτισα, v. τίνω.

div1.head: τλάω
div1.etym: perfect forms are used with pres. sense
div1.sense: to take upon oneself, to bear, suffer, undergo: c. acc. rei, ἔτλην οἷʼ οὔπω καὶ ἄλλος Il.; ἔτλην ἀνέρος εὐνήν I submitted to be wedded to a man, Il.; τλῆ ὀϊστόν submitted to be wounded by it, Il.; ἔτλα πένθος Pind., etc.
absol. to hold out, endure, be patient, submit, Hom.; esp. in imperat., τέτλαθι, μῆτερ ἐμή Il.; τλῆτε, φίλοι Od.; in part., τετληότι θυμῶι with patient soul, Od.; κραδίη τετληυῖα Od.

c. inf. to dare or venture to do, Od., Pind., etc.:—in Attic Poets, to dare to do a thing good or bad, hence either to have the courage, hardihood, effrontery, cruelty, or to have the grace, patience, to do anything, ἔς τε δὴ ἔτλην γεγωνεῖν till I took courage to tell, Aesch.; ἔτλα ἀλλάξαι submitted to exchange, Soph.; οὐδʼ ἔτλης ἐφυβρίσαι nor hadst thou the cruelty to insult, Soph.; οὐ γὰρ ἂν τλαίην ἰδεῖν I could not bear to see, Ar.
c. acc. rei, to dare a thing, i. e. dare to do it, ἄτλητα τλᾶσα Aesch.; εἰ καὶ τοῦτʼ ἔτλη Soph.
c. part., τάδε τέτλαμεν εἰσορόωντες Od.

div1.head: τλήθυμος
div1.sense: stout-hearted, Anth.

div1.head: τλημοσύνη
div1.sense: that which is to be endured, misery, distress, in pl., Hhymn.
endurance, Plut.

div1.head: τλήμων
div1.note: τλήμων, Doric τλάμων, ονος, ὁ, ἡ,
div1.sense: suffering, enduring, patient, stout-hearted, of Ulysses, Il.; so Pind., etc.
bold, daring, hardy, reckless, Il., Trag.
suffering, wretched, miserable, Trag., Xen.
adv. τλημόνως, patiently, Aesch., Eur., etc.

div1.head: τλησικάρδιος
div1.sense: hard-hearted, Aesch.
miserable, Aesch.

div1.head: τλητός
div1.sense: act. suffering, enduring, patient, steadfast, Il.
pass., with a negat., οὐ τλ. not to be endured, intolerable, Trag.

div1.head: τμήγω
div1.sense: to cut, cleave: Mid., ὁδὸν ἐτμήξαντο cut their way, Anth.
metaph. in aor2 pass. to be divided or dispersed, to part, Il.

div1.head: τμήδην
div1.sense: by cutting, so as to cut, Il.

div1.head: τμῆμα
div1.sense: a part cut off, a section, piece, Plat.
a cut, incision, wound, Plat.

div1.head: τμῆσις
div1.sense: a cutting: ἡ τμ. τῆς γῆς the ravaging of a country, Plat.
= τμῆμα, a section, Plat.

div1.head: τμητέος
div1.sense: one must cut, Plat.

div1.head: τμητοσίδηρος
div1.sense: cut down with iron, Anth.

div1.head: τμητός
div1.sense: cut, shaped by cutting, Soph., Eur.
that can be cut or severed, Theocr.

div1.head: Τμῶλος
div1.sense: Mt. Tmolus in Lydia, Il., etc.

div1.head: τόθεν
div1.sense: antecedent to relat. ὅθεν (being an old gen. of ὁ) :— hence, thence, Hes.
for relat. ὅθεν, Aesch.
thereafter, thereupon, Aesch.

div1.head: τόθι
div1.sense: antecedent to relat. ὅθι (being an old locat. case of ὁ) :— there, in that place, Od., Pind.
also for relat. ὅθι, where, Pind.

div1.head: τοιγάρ
div1.sense: so then, wherefore, therefore, accordingly, Hom., Attic
strengthd. τοιγαροῦν, Ionic τοιγαρῶν, so for example, Xen.: also in Poets, Soph.
τοιγάρτοι, Plat.

div1.head: τοίνυν
div1.sense: therefore, accordingly, Hdt., Trag.
to resume or continue a speech, moreover, Soph., Xen.

div1.head: τοιόσδε
div1.sense: anteced. to οἷος, as ἀοιδοῦ τοιοῦδʼ οἷος ὅδʼ ἐστί of such a minstrel as is this one, Od.; absol., ἀλλʼ ὅδʼ ἐγὼ τοιόσδε here am I such as you see, Od.:—also, so great, so noble, so bad, τοιάδε λαίφη such clothes, i. e. so bad, Od.; τοσόσδε καὶ τοιόσδε Hdt.:—also with a qualifying word, τοιόσδʼ ἠμὲν δέμας ἠδὲ καὶ ἔργα such both in form and works, Od.:—with the Art., ὁ τ. ἀνήρ Aesch., etc.; οἱ τοιοίδε Soph.; ἐν τῷ τοιῷδε in such circumstances, Hdt.:—the sense is made more indef. in τοιόσδε τις such a one, Thuc.:—neut. pl. τοιάδε as follows, τοιαῦτα as aforesaid, Hdt.

div1.head: τοῖος
div1.sense: demonstr. Pron., antecedent to relat. οἷος, Lat. talis, of such kind or quality, such, such-like, τοῖος ἐών, οἷος οὖτις Ἀχαιῶν (sc. ἐστίν) Il., etc.:— τοῖος in Hom. mostly refers to something gone before, such as is said, Hom.
with qualifying words, τοῖος χεῖρας such in his hands, Od.; τεύχεσι τοῖος Il.; τοῖος, c. inf., such as to do, i. e. fit or able to do, Od.
with an adj. of the same gender and case, it increases the sense of the adj., ἐπιεικὴς τοῖος just of moderate size, Il.; πέλαγος μέγα τοῖον a sea so large, Od.; κερδαλέος τοῖος so very crafty, Od.
neut. τοῖον as adv. so, thus, so very, so much, Hom.; —so, τοίως, Theocr.

div1.head: τοιοῦτος
div1.sense: such as this, anteced. to οἷος, Od., etc.; to ὅσος, Il.: absol., with an intensive sense, so great, so noble, so bad, etc., Il., Attic; τοιοῦτος ὤν being such a wretch, Soph.:—c. gen., τοιοῦτος Ἀχαιῶν such a man among them, Il.:— τοιοῦτός ἐστι or γίγνεται εἴς or περί τινα he is so disposed towards any one, Xen., etc.:—strengthd., τ. ἕτερος just such another, Hdt.; ἄλλους τοιούτους Hdt.: —with the Art., οἱ τοιοῦτοι Aesch., etc.
the sense is made more indef. in τοιοῦτός τις or τις τοιοῦτος such a one, Pind., Thuc., etc.; τοιαῦτʼ ἄττα Plat.
τοιοῦτον or τὸ τ. such a proceeding, Thuc.; διὰ τὸτ. for such a reason, Thuc., etc.
in narrative, τοιαῦτα properly refers to what goes before, Aesch., etc.:—after a question, τοιαῦτα affirms like ταῦτα, just so, even so, Eur.
τοιαῦτα absol., τὰ πλοῖα, τὰ τοιαῦτα ships and such-like, Dem.
τοιαῦτα as an adv., in such wise, Soph.

div1.head: τοιουτότροπος
div1.sense: of such kind, such like, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: τοιουτώδης
div1.sense: of such kind, Luc.

div1.head: τοι
div1.sense: enclit. Particle, serving to express belief in an assertion, let me tell you, surely, verily, used to express an inference, then, consequently, Hom.; and in Trag., to introduce a general sentiment.
to strengthen other Particles, γάρ τοι, ἤτοι, καίτοι, μέντοι, τοιγάρτοι, etc.: cf. τἆρα, τἄν, μεντἄν.

div1.head: τοῖχος
div1.sense: the wall of a house or court, Lat. paries, Hom., Attic:—in pl. the sides of a ship, Od., Eur., etc.:—of the human body, Eur.
proverb., ὁ εὖ πράττων τοῖχος "the right side of the hedge, " Ar.

div1.head: τοιχωρυχέω
div1.sense: to dig through a wall like a thief, to be a housebreaker, Ar., Xen.
metaph., οἷα ἐτοιχωρύχησαν περὶ τὸ δάνειον what thievish tricks they played with their loan, Dem.

div1.head: τοιχωρύχος
div1.sense: one who digs through the wall, i. e. a housebreaker, burglar, robber, Ar.

div1.head: τοκάς
div1.sense: of or for breeding, Od.
having just brought forth, Lat. feta, τ. λέαινα a lioness with cubs, Eur.; also of women, Eur.:— τοκάδα τὴν κεφαλὴν ἔχειν, of Zeus in labour of Athena, Luc.

div1.head: τοκετός
div1.sense: birth, delivery, Anth.

div1.head: τοκεύς
div1.sense: one who begets, a father, Hes.; generally, a parent, Aesch.:—mostly, in pl. τοκεῖς Epic τοκῆες, parents, Hom., Hdt., Trag., etc.;—in dual, τοκῆε δύω Od.

div1.head: τοκίζω
div1.sense: to lend on interest, Lat. faenerari, Dem.; τ. τόκον to practise usury, Anth.

div1.head: τοκισμός
div1.sense: the practice of usury, Xen.

div1.head: τοκιστής
div1.sense: an usurer, Plat., Arist.

div1.head: τοκογλυφέω
div1.sense: to practise sordid usury, Luc.

div1.head: τοκογλύφος
div1.sense: one who carves out interest, a sordid usurer, Luc.

div1.head: τόκος
div1.sense: a bringing forth, childbirth, parturition, Il.; in pl., Soph., Eur.
the time of parturition, Hdt.
the offspring, young, a child, son, Hom., Aesch., etc.
metaph. the produce of money lent out, interest, Lat. usura, Ar., etc.; ἐπὶ τόκῳ or ἐπὶ τόκον δανείζεσθαι to borrow at interest, Dem.; τόκοι τόκων compound interest, Ar.
the produce of land, Xen.

div1.head: τοκοφορέω
div1.sense: to bring in interest, Dem.

div1.head: τόλμα
div1.sense: courage, to undertake or venture a thing, boldness, daring, hardihood, courage, Pind., Hdt., Attic; τῶνδε τόλμαν σχεθεῖν to have courage for this business, Aesch.
in bad sense, over-boldness, recklessness, Lat. audacia, Trag., etc.
a bold or daring act, Trag.

div1.head: τολμάω
div1.sense: to undertake, take heart either to do or bear anything terrible or difficult, Hom., etc.:—absol. to hold out, endure, be patient, submit, Hom., Attic:—c. acc. rei, to endure, undergo, Theogn., Eur.
c. inf. to have the courage, hardihood, effrontery, cruelty, or the grace, patience, to do a thing in spite of any natural feeling, to venture, dare to do, Hom., Attic
sometimes c. part., ἐτόλμα βαλλόμενος he submitted to be struck, Od.; τόλμα ἐρῶσα Eur.
c. acc., τολμᾶν πόλεμον to undertake, venture on it, Od.; τοιαῦτα, πάντα τ. Trag.; also, τ. τὰ βέλτιστα Thuc.: Pass., οἷʼ ἐτολμήθη πατήρ such things as my father had dared (or done) against him, Eur.

div1.head: τόλμημα
div1.sense: an adventure, enterprise, deed of daring, Eur., etc.

div1.head: τολμηρός
div1.sense: τὸ τολμηρόν τινος his hardihood, Thuc.; adv. -ρῶς, Thuc.; comp. -ότερον, Thuc.

div1.head: τολμητέος
div1.sense: one must venture, Eur.

div1.head: τολμητής
div1.sense: a bold, venturous man, Thuc.

div1.head: τολμητός
div1.sense: to be ventured; ἔστʼ ἐκείνῳ πάντα τολμητά all things are within the compass of his daring, Soph.; ἐλπὶς τ. Eur.

div1.head: τολοιπόν
div1.sense: for the rest, for the future:—better divisim τὸ λοιπόν.

div1.head: τολυπεύω
div1.sense: properly, to wind off wool into a clew for spinning: metaph. to wind off, achieve, accomplish, ἐγὼ δὲ δόλους τολυπεύω, of Penelopeʼs web (where there is a play on the literal sense), Od.; τ. πόλεμον Hom.

div1.head: τολύπη
div1.sense: a clew or ball of wool, Lat. glomus, Ar., Anth.

div1.head: τομαῖος
div1.sense: cut, cut off, Aesch., Eur.
cut in pieces, cut or shredded ready for use, Aesch.

div1.head: τομάω
div1.sense: to need cutting, πρὸς τομῶντι πήματι for a disease that needs the knife, Soph.

div1.head: τομεύς
div1.sense: one that cuts, a shoemakerʼs knife, Plat.: the edge of a knife, Xen.

div1.head: τομή
div1.sense: the end left after cutting, the stump of a tree, Il.; δοκοῦ τ. the end of a beam, Thuc.; λίθοι ἐν τομῇ ἐγγώνιοι stones cut square, Thuc.; so, τομῇ προσθεῖσα βόστρυχον having fitted the lock to the place from which it was cut, Aesch.
a cutting, hewing, cleaving, ἐν τομᾷ σιδήρου by stroke of iron, Soph.; φασγάνου τομαί Eur.:—as a surgical operation, τομῇ χρῆσθαι Plat.; διὰ καύσεών τε καὶ τομῶν by cautery and the knife, Plat.

div1.head: τόμιον
div1.sense: a victim cut up for sacrifice; τὰ τόμια the parts of the victim, Dem.

div1.head: τομός
div1.sense: cutting, ἕστηκεν ᾗ τομώτατος is placed as it will cut sharpest, Soph.

div1.head: τόμος
div1.sense: a cut, slice, Batr., Ar.
part of a book, a tome, volume,

div1.head: τονάριον
div1.sense: a pitch-pipe, Plut.

div1.head: τονθορύζω
div1.sense: to speak inarticulately, mutter, babble, Ar.

div1.head: τόνος
div1.sense: that by which a thing is stretched, a rope, cord, brace, οἱ τόνοι τῶν κλινέων the cords of beds, Hdt.; ἐκ τριῶν τόνων of three plies or strands, of ropes, Xen.:—in machines, straining-cords, Plut.
a stretching, tightening, straining, strain, tension, Hdt.
of sounds, a straining, raising of the voice, Aeschin., Dem.:— the pitch of the voice, Plat., etc.
measure, metre, Hdt.
in Music, τόνοι were modes or keys differing in pitch, of which in early Greek music there were three, the Dorian, Lydian, and Phrygian.
exertion of force, mental exertion, energy, Luc.:— generally, force, strength, intensity, Plut.
metaph. the tenour of oneʼs way, a course, Pind., Plut.

div1.head: τονῦν
div1.sense: for the present, v. νῦν 1.

div1.head: τοξάζομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to shoot with a bow, Od.; c. gen. to shoot at, Od.

div1.head: τοξαλκέτης
div1.sense: mighty with the bow, Anth.

div1.head: τόξαρχος
div1.sense: lord of the bow, bowman, archer, Aesch.
captain of the archers, Thuc.

div1.head: τόξευμα
div1.sense: that which is shot, an arrow, Hdt., Eur., etc.; ὅσον τ. ἐξικνέεται the distance of a bowshot, Hdt.; πρὶν τ. ἐξικνεῖσθαι before an arrow reached them, Xen.; ἐντὸς τοξεύματος within bow-shot, Xen.; ἔξω τοξεύματος Thuc.:—metaph., καρδίας τοξεύματα Soph.
collective in pl. for οἱ τοξόται, the archery, Hdt.

div1.head: τοξευτός
div1.sense: struck by an arrow, Soph.

div1.head: τοξεύω
div1.sense: to shoot with the bow, τινός at a mark, Il., Soph.; εἴς τινα Hdt.:—metaph. to aim at, c. gen., Eur.:—absol. to use the bow, Hdt., Thuc., etc.; καθʼ ὑπερβολὰν τοξεύσας having shot too high, Soph.
c. acc. to shoot or hit with an arrow, τινά Eur., Xen.:—Pass. to be struck by an arrow, Thuc.
c. acc. rei, to shoot from a bow: metaph., to discharge, send forth, ὕμνους Pind.; ταῦτα ἐτόξευσεν μάτην hath shot these arrows in vain, Eur.: —Pass., πᾶν τετόξευται βέλος Aesch.

div1.head: τοξήρης
div1.sense: furnished with the bow, Eur.
= τοξικός, Eur.; τ. ψαλμός the twang of the bowstring, Eur.

div1.head: τοξικός
div1.sense: of or for the bow, Aesch.:— ἡ τοξική (sc. τέχνη) archery, Plat.
of persons, skilled in the use of the bow, τοξικώτατος Xen.

div1.head: τοξοβόλος
div1.sense: shooting with the bow, Anth.

div1.head: τοξόδαμνος
div1.sense: subduing with the bow, τ. Ἄρης the war of archers, i. e. the Persians, Aesch.; τ. Ἄρτεμις Eur.

div1.head: τόξον
div1.sense: a bow, Hom.; often in pl., because the ancient bow was of two pieces of horn joined by the πῆχυς in the middle; τόξα τιταίνειν or ἕλκειν to draw the bow, Il.:—as the bow was specially the Oriental weapon, τόξου ῥῦμα meant the Persians, opp. to λόγχης ἰσχύς (the Greek spearmen), Aesch.: —metaph., τόξῳ by guess, Aesch.
in pl. also, bow and arrows, Hom., Hdt., etc.
metaph., τόξα ἡλίου its rays, Eur.

div1.head: τοξοποιέω
div1.sense: to make like a bow, to arch, τ. τὰς ὀφρῦς, of a supercilious person, Ar.

div1.head: τοξοσύνη
div1.sense: bowmanship, archery, Il., Eur.

div1.head: τοξότης
div1.sense: a bowman, archer, Il., Hdt., Trag., etc.
the Archer, Sagittarius, a sign in the Zodiac, Luc.
at Athens, οἱ τοξόται were the city-guard, also called Σκύθαι, because they were slaves bought from the parts north of Greece, Ar., etc.

div1.head: τοξουλκός
div1.sense: drawing the bow, Aesch.
αἰχμὴ τ. the bowstretching arrow, Aesch.

div1.head: τοξοφορέω
div1.sense: to bear a bow, of Eros, Anth.

div1.head: τοξοφόρος
div1.sense: bow-bearing, Il., Eur., etc.: — ὁ τοξοφόρος τοξότης, Hdt.

div1.head: τόπαζος
div1.sense: the topaz, Anth.

div1.head: τοπάζω
div1.sense: to aim at, guess, Aesch., Ar.

div1.head: τοπάλαι
div1.sense: better written divisim τὸ πάλαι, τὸ παλαιόν, etc.

div1.head: τόπαρχος
div1.sense: ruling over a place, γυνὴ τ. the mistress, Aesch.

div1.head: τοπικός
div1.sense: concerning τόποι or common-places, Arist.

div1.head: τοπογραφέω
div1.sense: to determine the site, Strab.

div1.head: τοποθετέω
div1.sense: to mark the site of a place, Strab.

div1.head: τοπομαχέω
div1.sense: to wage war by holding strong positions, Plut.

div1.head: τόπος
div1.sense: a place, Lat. locus, Aesch., etc.; periphr., χθονὸς πᾶς τόπος, i. e. the whole earth, Aesch.; Πέλοπος ἐν τόποις in Peloponnesus, Aesch., etc.; ὁ τόπος τῆς χώρας the local circumstances of the district, Dem.
place, position, Aeschin.
a place or passage in an author, NTest., etc.
a topic, Aeschin.: a common-place in Rhetoric, Arist.
metaph. a place, occasion, opportunity, Thuc.

div1.head: τοπρίν
div1.sense: better written divisim τὸ πρίν, etc.

div1.head: τορεία
div1.sense: a carving in relief, Plut.

div1.head: τορεύς
div1.sense: a borer, piercer, Anth.

div1.head: τορευτός
div1.sense: worked in relief: metaph. elaborate, Anth.

div1.head: τορεύω
div1.sense: to work in relief, Strab.:—c. acc. to represent in this manner, Anth.

div1.head: τορέω
div1.sense: to bore through, pierce, Il.
metaph. to proclaim in shrill piercing tones, in redupl. fut. τετορήσω, Ar.: cf. τορός.
like τορνεύω, to work, shape, Anth.

div1.head: τόρμος
div1.sense: any hole or socket, in which a pin or peg is stuck, Hdt.

div1.head: τορνευτολυρασπιδοπηγός
div1.sense: lyre-turner and shield-maker, Ar.

div1.head: τορνεύω
div1.sense: to work with a lathe-chisel: metaph. of verses, to turn neatly, to round off, Ar.
to turn round, as an auger, Eur.

div1.head: τορνόομαι
div1.sense: Dep. to mark off with the τόρνος, to make round, τορνώσαντο σῆμα they rounded off the barrow, Il.; ὅσσον τίς τʼ ἔδαφος νηὸς τορνώσεται large as the bottom of a ship which a man shall round off, with allusion to the round shape of a merchant-vessel (cf. γαυλός) , Od.

div1.head: τόρνος
div1.sense: a carpenterʼs tool for drawing a circle, compasses, Theogn., Hdt., Eur.

div1.head: τορός
div1.sense: piercing:
of the voice, piercing, thrilling, Luc.; so in adv., τορῶς γεγωνεῖν Eur.:—metaph., τ. φόβος thrilling fear, Aesch.
metaph. clear, distinct, plain, Aesch.:—so in adv., τορῶς τεκμαίρειν, λέγειν Aesch., etc.
of persons, sharp, ready, smart, Xen.:—so in adv., ἐπερείδεσθαι τορῶς Ar.

div1.head: τοροτίξ
div1.sense: imitation of a birdʼs note, Ar.

div1.head: τορύνη
div1.sense: a stirrer, ladle, Ar.

div1.head: τορύνω
div1.sense: to stir, stir up or about, Ar.

div1.head: τοσάκις
div1.sense: so many times, so often, Il.

div1.head: τοσήμερον
div1.sense: to-day, Bion.

div1.head: τοσόσδε
div1.sense: c. inf. so strong, so able, to do a thing, Od.
neut. τοσόνδε, Epic τοσσόνδε, as adv. so very, so much, Hom., etc.; of Time, so long, Aesch.
as Subst., τοσόνδʼ ἔχεις τόλμης Soph.

div1.head: τόσος
div1.sense: antecedent to relat. ὅσος; Lat. tantus: of Size, Space, Quantity, so great, so vast: of Time, so long: of Number, in pl., so many: of Sound, so loud: of Degree, so much, so very:— often in Hom. and Hes., οὔτι τόσος γε ὅσος Αἴας not so huge as Ajax, Il.: absol. just so much or just so many, Od.; τρὶς τόσσα δῶρα thrice as many gifts, Il.; δὶς τόσα κακά Soph.
used for ὅσος, Lat. quantus, Pind.
τόσον and τόσσον as adv., so much, so far, so very, Lat. tantum, τ. πλέες so many more, Il., etc.
ἐκ τόσου so long since, Hdt.
τόσῳ with a comp., and by so much more, Thuc.
regul. adv., δὶς τόσως Eur.

div1.head: τοσουτάριθμος
div1.sense: of so large a number, Aesch.

div1.head: τοσουτοσί
div1.sense: later Attic for τοσοῦτος, with a stronger demonstr. force, Ar., Plat., etc.

div1.head: τοσοῦτος
div1.sense: = τόσος in all senses, but with a stronger demonstr. force, Hom., etc.; of persons, so large, so tall, καί σε τοσοῦτον ἔθηκα Il.; so great in rank, skill,or character, Soph., etc.:—in pl. so many, Hom.,etc.:—also τοσοῦτος μέγαθος so large, Hdt.; τοσοῦτος τὸ βάθος so deep, Xen.:—with numeral Advs., δὶς τ.,πολλάκις τ., etc., Thuc., etc.; ἕτερον τοσοῦτο as large again, Hdt.

neut. as Subst., so much, thus much, τοσσοῦτον ὀνήσιος Od.; τοσαῦτʼ ἔλεξε Aesch.; —with Preps., διὰ τοσούτου at so small a distance, Thuc.;— ἐς τοσοῦτο so far, Lat. hactenus, eatenus, Hdt., etc.;— ἐκ τ. from so far, so far off, Xen.;— ἐν τοσούτῳ in the meantime, Ar.;— ἐπὶ τοσοῦτο so far, Hdt.;— κατὰ τοσοῦτον so far, Plat.;— μέχρι τοσούτου so far, so long, Thuc.;— παρὰ τοσοῦτον κινδύνου into such imminent danger, Thuc.
neut. also as adv., so much, so far, Od., Soph., etc.
so much, Hom., Thuc., etc.:—but τοσούτῳ is more common with Comparatives, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: τόσσαις
div1.etym: aor1 part. of an unknown pres.
div1.sense: to happen to be, Pind.

div1.head: τοσσάτιος
div1.sense: so great, much, Anth.: in pl. so many, Anth.

div1.head: τοτελευταῖον
div1.sense: better written divisim τὸ τελευταῖον, etc.

div1.head: τοτέ
div1.sense: at times, now and then, τοτὲ μὲν . . , τοτὲ δὲ . . , at one time . . , at another . . , Od., Aesch., etc.; τοτʼ ἄλλος, ἄλλοθʼ ἅτερος Soph.; τοτὲ μὲν . . , αὖθις δὲ . . , Plat.

div1.head: τότε
div1.sense: at that time, then, Lat. tunc, Antec. to Relat. ὅτε or ὁπότε, opp. to νῦν, Il., Hom., etc.:—also in indef. sense, in those times, formerly, Soph., etc.; τότʼ ἢ τότε at one time or other, Aesch., Eur.
joined with other Particles, καὶ τότε δή Hom.; καὶ τότʼ ἔπειτα Il.; τότε δή ῥα Od., etc.; τότʼ ἤδη then at length, Hes.
with the Article, οἱ τότε the men of that time, Il., etc.; οἱ τότε ἄνθρωποι Hdt.; τῇ τόθʼ ἡμέρᾳ Soph.; ἐν τῷ τότε (sc. χρόνῳ) Thuc.
εἰς τότε until then, Dem.; ἐκ τότε or ἐκτότε since then, Plut.

div1.head: τοτοβρίξ
div1.sense: imitation of a birdʼs note, Ar.

div1.head: τοτοῖ
div1.sense: an exclam., Aesch.; τοτοτοῖ, Soph.

div1.head: τοτρίτον
div1.sense: better written divisim τὸ τρίτον.

div1.head: τοὔνεκα
div1.sense: for that reason, therefore, Hom., etc.
interrog., for τίνος ἕνεκα; wherefore? Anth.

div1.head: τουτόθεν
div1.sense: hence, thence, Theocr.

div1.head: τόφρα
div1.sense: demonstr. adv. of Time, up to or during that time, so long, antecedent to relat. ὄφρα, Il.
absol. meanwhile, Hom.

div1.head: Τραγασαῖος
div1.sense: of or from the Epirotic city Τραγασαί, Strab.:—of swine, Τραγασαῖα in Tragasaean fashion, with a play on τραγεῖν, Ar.; Τραγασαίου πατρός, with a play on τράγος, Ar.

div1.head: τράγειος
div1.sense: of or from a he-goat: ὁ τραγείη (sc. δορά) a goatʼs skin, Theocr.

div1.head: τραγέλαφος
div1.sense: the goat-stag, as the Greeks called a fantastic animal, represented on Eastern carpets and the like, Ar.

div1.head: τράγημα
div1.sense: properly that which is eaten for eatingʼs sake, mostly in pl., dried fruits or sweetmeats, eaten as dessert, Lat. bellaria, Ar., Xen.

div1.head: τραγηματίζω
div1.sense: to eat sweetmeats, Arist.: so Mid., τραγηματίζομαι, Theophr.

div1.head: τραγικός
div1.sense: of or like a goat, goatish, Plut., etc.
of or for tragedy, tragic (cf. τραγῳδία) , Hdt., Xen., etc.; τρ. λῆρος tragic trumpery, Ar.
generally, tragic, stately, majestic, Ar., Plat.
in bad sense, in tragic style, plaintive, Dem.
adv. -κῶς, in tragic style or fashion, Plat.
οἰκεῖν τρ. to live in splendour, Plut.

div1.head: τράγινος
div1.sense: of a he-goat, Anth.

div1.head: τραγίσκος
div1.sense: a young he-goat, Theocr., Anth.

div1.head: τραγοκουρικός
div1.sense: for shearing he-goats, Luc.

div1.head: τραγόκτονος
div1.sense: of slaughtered goats, Eur.

div1.head: τραγομάσχαλος
div1.sense: with armpits smelling like a he-goat, Ar.

div1.head: τραγόπους
div1.sense: goat-footed, Anth.

div1.head: τραγοσκελής
div1.sense: goat-shanked, Hdt., Luc.

div1.head: τράγος
div1.sense: a he-goat, Lat. hircus, Od., etc.

div1.head: τραγοφαγέω
div1.sense: to eat he-goats, Strab.

div1.head: τραγῳδέω
div1.sense: to act a tragedy, Ar.
c. acc. objecti, to represent in tragedy, Luc.:—Pass. to be the subject of a tragedy, Isocr., etc.
metaph. to tell in tragic phrase, to declaim, Dem.

div1.head: τραγῳδία
div1.sense: a tragedy, invented by the Dorians, and at first of lyric character (τραγικοὶ χοροί Hdt.); then transplanted to Athens, where it assumed its dramatic form, Ar., etc. Its proper sense is goat-song, because in early times a goat was the prize, or because the actors were clothed in goat-skins.
generally, any grave, serious poetry, Plat.

div1.head: τραγῳδικός
div1.sense: befitting tragedy, χοροί Hdt., Ar.; τραγῳδικὸν βλέπειν to look tragic, Ar.; ὠδυνήθην τραγῳδικόν suffered a tragic woe, Ar.

div1.head: τραγῳδιογράφος
div1.sense: writing tragedies, Polyb.

div1.head: τραγῳδοδιδάσκαλος
div1.sense: a tragic poet, who trained his own chorus and actors, Ar.

div1.head: τραγῳδοποιός
div1.sense: a maker of tragedies, a tragic poet, tragedian, Ar., Plat., etc.

div1.head: τραγῳδός
div1.sense: properly, a goat-singer (v. τραγῳδία) , i. e. a tragic poet and singer, these characters being orig. one, Ar.:—later, when the poets ceased to act, the term meant a tragedian or tragic actor, the tragic poet being called τραγῳδοποιός or τραγῳδοδιδάσκαλος.
of members of the tragic chorus, Ar.
the pl. is often used = τραγῳδία, ἐν τοῖσι τραγῳδοῖς in tragedy, Ar., Dem., etc.

div1.head: Τράλλεις
div1.sense: Trallians, Thracian barbarians, Plut.

div1.head: τρανής
div1.sense: piercing: metaph. clear, distinct:—adv., τρανῶς εἰδέναι, μανθάνειν Aesch., Eur.; comp. τρανότερον, Anth.

div1.head: τρανόω
div1.sense: to make clear, plain, distinct, Anth.

div1.head: τράπεζα
div1.sense: four-legged a table, esp. a dining-table, Hom., Hdt., etc.; ξενίη τρ. the hospitable board, Od.; τραπέζῃ καὶ κοίτῃ δέκεσθαι to entertain at bed and board, Hdt.; Περσικὴν τράπεζαν παρετίθετο he kept a table in the Persian fashion, Thuc.; εἰς ἀλλοτρίαν τράπεζαν βλέπειν to live at other menʼs table, Xen.
a table, as implying what is upon it, a dinner, meal, Hdt., etc.; Συρακοσία τρ., proverb. of luxurious living, Hor. Siculae dapes, Plat.
a money-changerʼs table, a bank, Lat. mensa argentaria, Plat., etc.; ἡ ἐγγύη ἡ ἐπὶ τὴν τρ. security given to the bank, Dem.; οἱ ἐπὶ ταῖς τραπέζαις bankers, Isocr.

div1.head: τραπεζεύς
div1.sense: at, of a table, κύνες τραπεζῆες (Ionic for τραπεζεῖς) dogs fed from their masterʼs table, Hom.

div1.head: τραπεζιτεύω
div1.sense: to be engaged in banking, Dem.

div1.head: τραπεζίτης
div1.sense: one who keeps a bank, a banker, Lat. argentarius, Dem.

div1.head: τραπεζιτικός
div1.sense: of or for the banker, Isocr.

div1.head: τραπεζοποιία
div1.sense: table-making, Strab.

div1.head: τραπέω
div1.sense: to tread grapes, Od., Hes.

div1.head: τραπητέος
div1.sense: one must turn, Luc.

div1.head: τρασιά
div1.sense: a crate, whereon to dry figs, Ar.

div1.head: τραυλίζω
div1.sense: to lisp, Lat. balbutire, as Alcibiades made r into l, Ar.; of children, Ar.

div1.head: τραυλός
div1.sense: lisping, Lat. balbus, esp. of children, Hdt.
of the swallow, twittering, Anth.

div1.head: τραυλότης
div1.sense: a lisping, Plut.

div1.head: τραῦμα
div1.note: τραῦμα, Ionic and Doric τρῶμα, ατος, τό,
div1.sense: a wound, hurt, Hdt., Attic; τραῦμα λαβεῖν ὑπό τινος Dem.; λαβεῖν καὶ δοῦναι Plut.
of things, a hurt, damage, as of ships, Hdt.
in war, a blow, defeat, Hdt.
ἡ τραύματος γραφή an indictment for wounding (with intent to murder), Aeschin.

div1.head: τραυματίζω
div1.sense: to wound, Hdt., Attic

div1.head: τραυματίας
div1.sense: a wounded man, οἱ τρ. the wounded of an army, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: τραφερός
div1.sense: properly, well-fed, οἱ τραφεροί or τὰ τραφερά the fat ones, i.e. fishes, Theocr.
τραφερή (sub. γῆ) , as Subst. the dry land, land, ἐπὶ τραφερήν τε καὶ ὑγρήν Hom.

div1.head: τραχηλιαῖος
div1.sense: of, on, or from the neck, Strab.

div1.head: τραχήλια
div1.sense: scraps of meat and gristle about the neck, scraps, offal, Ar.

div1.head: τραχηλίζω
div1.sense: of wrestlers, to bend the neck back, and so to overpower, Theophr.:—Pass. to have oneʼs neck bent back so that the throat gapes when cut: hence, to be laid open, NTest.

div1.head: τραχηλοδεσμότης
div1.sense: chaining the neck, Anth.

div1.head: τράχηλος
div1.sense: the neck, throat, Hdt., Eur., etc.

div1.head: Τραχίς
div1.sense: Trachis, in Thessaly, named from the ruggedness (τραχύτης) of the district, Il., etc.:—adj. Τρᾱχί_νιος, η, ον, Ionic Τρηχ-, Hdt., etc.; also ος, ον, Theocr.:— οἱ Τραχίνιοι the people of Trachis, Hdt., etc.:— ἡ Τραχινία the country, Hdt., Soph., etc.; also called Τραχίς, Thuc.

div1.head: τραχύνω
div1.sense: to make rough, rugged, uneven, Plat.:—Pass. to become rough, Plat.; τρ. τῇ φωνῇ to use rough harsh tones, Plut.
in Aesch. Theb., τράχυνε refers to τραχύς γε μέντοι δῆμος (just before) call them rough, I care not.
metaph. in Pass. to be exasperated, Plat.
intr. to be rough, Plut.

div1.head: τραχύς
div1.sense: rugged, rough, Lat. asper, Hom., etc.; as epith. of Ithaca, Od.; cf. Τραχίς:—also, rough, shaggy, Xen.:—of a bit, rough, sharp, Xen.: of the voice of boys, when it breaks, Plut.
rough, harsh, savage, Pind., Aesch., etc.
adv. τρᾱχέως, Ionic τρηχέως, roughly, Hdt.; τραχέως ἔχειν to be rough, Isocr.; τρ. φέρειν, Lat. aegre ferre, Plut.

div1.head: τραχύστομος
div1.sense: of rough speech or pronunciation, Strab.

div1.head: τραχύτης
div1.sense: roughness, ruggedness, Xen.; sharpness, of a bit, Xen.
of persons, roughness, harshness, ὀργῆς Aesch.

div1.head: τραχών
div1.sense: a rugged, stony tract, Luc.; so Τραχωνῖτις, ιδος, NTest., etc.

div1.head: τρεισκαίδεκα
div1.sense: thirteen, Hdt., Attic; also written divisim, gen. τριῶν καὶ δέκα, dat. τρισὶ καὶ δέκα, etc.:—an indecl. form τρισκαίδεκα occurs, in all genders and cases, Hom., Ar., etc.

div1.head: τρεῖς
div1.sense: Lat. tres, tria, three, Hom., etc.

div1.head: τρέμω
div1.sense: Lat. tremo, to tremble, quake, quiver, Il., Eur.:—c. inf. to tremble or fear to do, Aesch., Soph.: —c. acc. to tremble at, fear, Soph., Eur., etc.

div1.head: τρεπτέος
div1.sense: one must turn, Ar.

div1.head: τρέπω
div1.sense: to turn or direct towards a thing, Hom., etc.; mostly followed by a prep., τρ. τινὰ εἰς εὐνήν to shew him to bed, Od.; τρ. πόλεις ἐς ὕβριν Thuc.; τρ. κεφαλὴν πρὸς ἠέλιον Od.
Pass. to turn oneʼs steps, turn in a certain direction, τραφθῆναι ἀνʼ Ἑλλάδα to roam up and down Greece, Od.; c. acc. cogn., τρέπεσθαι ὁδόν to take a course, Hdt.
Pass. also to turn or betake oneself, εἰς ἀοιδήν Od.; ἐπὶ ἔργα Il.; ἐφʼ ἁρπαγήν Thuc.; πρὸς ληιστείαν Thuc.
Pass. and Mid., of places, to be turned or look in a certain direction, πρὸς ζόφον Od.; πρὸς ἄρκτον, πρὸς νότον Hdt., etc.

to turn, i. e. turn about, τρέπειν ἵππους Il.; τὰ καλὰ τρ. ἔζω to turn the best side outmost, Pind.:—Pass., αἰχμὴ τράπετο the point bent back, Il.; of the solstice, ἐπειδὰν ἐν χειμῶνι τράπηται ἥλιος (v. τροπή I) Xen.
τρ. τὴν αἰτίαν, τὴν ὀργὴν εἴς τινα to divert the blame, the anger upon another, Isae., Dem.:—Pass., in imprecations, ἐς κεφαλὴν τρέποιτο ἐμοί on my head be it! Ar.
to turn another way, to alter, change, νόον, φρένας Hom., etc.; ἐς γέλων τρ. τὸ πρᾶγμα Ar.:—Pass. to be changed, change, Hom., etc.; c. acc. cogn., τρεπόμενος τροπάς undergoing changes, Aeschin.

to turn or put to flight, rout, defeat, Il., Hdt., etc.; τρ. φύγαδε, Lat. convertere in fugam, Il.; τρ. ἐς φυγήν Eur.;—so, in aor1 mid., to put an enemy to flight, Xen.:—Pass. to be put to flight, turn and flee, Aesch., Xen., etc.; so in Mid., ἐς φυγὴν τραπέσθαι Hdt., Thuc.:—also intr. in Act., φύγαδʼ ἔτραπε Il.
to turn away, keep off, hinder, τρ. τινὰ ἀπὸ τείχεος Il.; βέλος ἔτραπεν ἄλληι Il.
to overturn, like ἀνατρέπω, Aesch.
to turn, apply, τρ. τι ἐς ἄλλο τι Hdt.; ποῦ τέτροφας τὰς ἐμβάδας; what have you made of your shoes? Ar.:—Pass., ποῖ τρέπεται τὰ χρήματα; Ar.

div1.head: τρέφω
div1.sense: to thicken or congeal a liquid, γάλα θρέψαι to curdle it. Od.; τυρὸν τρέφειν Theocr.:—Pass., with intr. perf. act. τέτροφα, to become firm, περὶ χροῒ τέτροφεν ἄλκη Od.

to make to grow or increase, to bring up, breed, rear, Hom., etc.; c. acc. cogn., τρ. τινὰ τροφήν τινα to bring up in a certain way, Hdt.:—Mid. to rear for oneself, Od., etc.:—Pass. to reared, grow up, Hom.; κάρτιστοι τράφεν ἄνδρες grew up the strongest men, Il.; ἐξ ὅτου ʼτράφην ἐγώ from the time when I left the nursery, Ar.; μιᾶς τρέφει πρὸς νυκτός, i. e. art a child of night, Soph.

of slaves, horses, dogs and the like, to rear and keep them, Hom., etc.; τρ. παιδαγωγούς Aeschin.; τρ. γυναῖκα Eur.;—metaph., αἰγιαλὸν ἔνδον τρέφει he keeps quite a sea-beach in the house, Ar.:—Pass. to bred, reared, Soph.
to let grow, cherish, foster, χαίτην τρέφε Il.; τρ. ὑπήνην Ar.; τρ. κόμην κομᾶν, Hdt.;—also, τάδʼ ὕεσσι τρέφει ἀλοιφήν this is what puts fat on swine, Od.
of earth and sea, to produce, teem with, χθὼν τρέφει φάρμακα Od.; θάλασσα τρέφουσα πορφύραν Aesch.

to have within oneself, to contain, keep, have, ὅ τι πόλις τέτροφεν ἄφιλον Soph.; τρέφειν τὴν γλῶσσαν ἡσυχωτέραν to keep his tongue more quiet, Soph.; νόσον τρ. Soph.; οἵας λατρείας τρέφει what services she constantly performs, Soph.
maintain, support, τρ. Ἥλιος χθονὸς φύσιν Aesch.; τρ. τὸν πατέρα Aeschin.: esp. to maintain an army or navy, Thuc., Xen.
aor2 act. in intr. sense, ἔτραφον pass. ἐτράφην, ὃς ἔτραφʼ ἄριστος Il.; τραφέμεν (Ionic for τραφεῖν) Hom.
so perf. τέτροφα, v. supr. I.

div1.head: τρέχνος
div1.sense: a twig, Anth.

div1.head: τρέχω
div1.etym: δραμοῦμαι and ἔδραμον from Root !δρεμ or !δραμ
div1.sense: to run, Lat. curro, Hom., etc.:—of horses, Il.:—of things, to run, move quickly, Hom., etc.
c. acc. loci, to run over, Eur., Xen.

c. acc. cogn., τρ. δρόμον, ἀγῶνα to run a course, a heat, Eur., etc.: often metaph., ἀγῶνα δρ. to run a risk, Eur.; πολλοὺς ἀγῶνας δραμεῖν περὶ σφέων αὐτέων to run many risks for their lives, Hdt.:—sometimes the acc. is omitted, τρ. περὶ ἑωυτοῦ to run the risk of his life, Eur.; τρ. περὶ τῆς νίκης Xen.
παρʼ ἓν πάλαισμα ἔδραμε νικᾶν he was within one bout of carrying off the victory, Hdt.

div1.head: τρέω
div1.etym: this Verb is never contracted, except when the contraction is into ει
div1.sense: to flee from fear, flee away, Il.; μὴ τρέσας without fear, Aesch.; οὐδὲν τρέσας Plat.:— τρέσας is used like a Subst., a runaway, coward, Il.; Ἀριστόδημος ὁ τρέσας Hdt.
trans. to flee from, fear, dread, be afraid of, c. acc., Il., Trag., Xen.

div1.head: τρῆμα
div1.sense: a perforation, hole, aperture, orifice, Lat. foramen, Ar., Plat.

div1.head: τρηματόεις
div1.sense: porous, Anth.

div1.head: τρήρων
div1.sense: timorous, shy, Hom.

div1.head: τρητός
div1.sense: perforated, with a hole in it, Od.; τρητὰ λέχεα, prob. inlaid bedsteads, or having holes through which the cords that supported the bedding were drawn:— τρητὸς μελισσῶν πόνος, i. e. the honeycomb, Pind.; τρ. λίθαξ pumice-stone, Anth.

div1.head: τρίαινα
div1.sense: a trident, the badge of Poseidon, Hom.

div1.head: τριαινόω
div1.sense: to heave with the trident: generally, to heave or prise up, overthrow, Eur.
τρ. τὴν γῆν δικέλλῃ to break it up with a mattock, Ar.

div1.head: τριακάς
div1.sense: the number thirty, Aesch.
the thirtieth day of the month, Hes.: hence, a month, containing 30 days, Luc.

trans.i: a political division, containing thirty families.

div1.head: τριακονθάμματος
div1.sense: with or of thirty knots, Xen.

div1.head: τριακονθήμερος
div1.sense: of thirty days, Hdt.

div1.head: τριακονταέτης
div1.sense: thirty years old, Plat.; in contr. form, οἱ τριακοντοῦται the men of thirty years, Plat.; fem. τριακοντοῦτις Isae.
τριακονταέτης, ες, of or for thirty years, Thuc.;—in fem. form, σπονδαὶ τριηκοντουτίδες Hdt.; αἱ τριακοντούτιδες σπονδαί Ar.

div1.head: τριακοντάζυγος
div1.sense: with thirty benches, Theocr.

div1.head: τριακοντάκις
div1.sense: thirty times, Plut.

div1.head: τριάκοντα
div1.etym: indecl., with a gen. τριηκόντων in Hes.; dat. τριηκόντεσσιν Anth.
div1.sense: thirty, Lat. triginta, Hom., etc.
οἱ τριάκοντα,
at Sparta, the council of thirty, assigned to the kings, Xen.
at Athens, the Thirty, commonly called the thirty tyrants, appointed on the taking of Athens (B C. 404), Plat., etc.

div1.head: τριακονταρχία
div1.sense: the rule of the Thirty, at Athens, Xen.

div1.head: τριακοντάχους
div1.sense: producing thirtyfold, Strab.

div1.head: τριακόντορος
div1.sense: (sc. ναῦς) , a thirty-oared ship, Thuc., Xen.; in Hdt. written τριηκόντερος.,

div1.head: τριακοντώρυγος
div1.sense: of thirty fathoms, Xen.

div1.head: τριακόσιοι
div1.sense: three hundred, Hom., Hdt., etc.; also with collective noun in sg., ἵππος τρ. Xen.
οἱ τρ. at Athens, the richest members of the συμμορίαι, who managed their affairs, Dem.
the Three Hundred, who fell at Thermopylae, Hdt.

div1.head: τριακοσιομέδιμνοι
div1.sense: those whose property produced 300 medimni, i. e. the Ἱππεῖς.

div1.head: τριακοσιόχους
div1.sense: bearing three hundredfold, Strab.

div1.head: τριακοστός
div1.sense: the thirtieth, Hdt., etc.
τριακοστή, a duty of one-thirtieth, Dem.

div1.head: τριακτήρ
div1.sense: a victor, Aesch.

div1.head: τριάζω
div1.sense: to vanquish, of a wrestler, who did not win until he had conquered in three bouts (παλαίσματα) .

div1.head: τριάρμενος
div1.sense: with three sails or masts, Luc.

div1.head: τριάς
div1.sense: the number three, a triad, Plat.

div1.head: τριβακός
div1.sense: rubbed, worn, Anth., Luc.

div1.head: Τριβαλλοί
div1.sense: the Triballi, a people on the borders of Thrace; as a Comic name for barbarian gods, Ar.:—adj. Τριβαλλικός, ή, όν, Hdt.

div1.head: τριβελής
div1.sense: three-pointed, Anth.

div1.head: τριβή
div1.sense: a rubbing or wearing away, wasting, Aesch.
practice, as opp. to theory, Xen.: also mere practice, routine, as opp. to true art, Plat.
that about which one is busied, an object of care, Lat. cura, Aesch.
of Time, a spending, Soph., Plat.; ἀξίαν τριβὴν ἔχει ʼtis time well spend, Aesch.; βίος οὐκ ἄχαρις ἐς τὴν τριβήν a life pleasant enough in the spending, Ar.
delay, putting off, ἐς τριβὰς ἐλᾶν to seek delays, Soph.; τριβὰς πορίζειν Ar.; and with the Verb omitted, μὴ τριβὰς ἔτι no more delays, Soph.

div1.head: τριβολεκτράπελος
div1.sense: in Ar. τριβολεκτράπελα στωμύλλειν to deal in coarse rude jests.

div1.head: τρίβολος
div1.sense: as Subst. a caltrop, i. e. a three-spiked implement, formed so that one of the spikes must point upwards, used to lame the enemyʼs horses, Plut.
a prickly plant, a burr, thistle, NTest.
τρίβολοι, οἱ, a threshing-machine, boards with sharp stones fixed in the bottom, Anth.

div1.head: τρίβος
div1.sense: a worn or beaten track, the high road, highway, Hdt., Eur.: a footpath, Xen.
rubbing, attrition, Aesch.
metaph. delay, Aesch.

div1.head: τριβωνικῶς
div1.sense: like a τρίβων, cloak-wise, Ar.

div1.head: τρίβων
div1.sense: as adj. practised or skilled in a thing, c. gen., Hdt., Eur., etc.
absol., a hackneyed, crafty fellow, rogue, Ar.

div1.head: τρίβω
div1.sense: to rub: to rub or thresh corn, Il.; μοχλὸν τρῖψαι ἐν ὀφθαλμῶι to work round the stake in his eye, Od.; χρυσὸν βασάνωι τρ. to rub it on a touchstone, so as to test its purity (cf. παρατρίβω), Theogn.:—Mid., χρηστηρίοις ἐν τοῖσδε τρίβεσθαι μύσος to rub oneʼs pollution upon these shrines, pollute them with it, Aesch.
to rub down, grind, pound, Ar., etc.
to crush, βότρυν Ar.
to wear out by rubbing: Pass., of a road, to wear or tread it smooth, ἀτραπὸς τετριμμένη Ar.
of Time, to wear away, spend, Lat. terere vitam, Soph., Eur.:— absol. to waste time, tarry, Aesch.
to waste or ravage a country, Eur.
metaph.,
of persons, to wear out, Hes.: Pass. to be worn out, Il., Thuc.:—Mid., τρίψεσθαι αὐτὴν περὶ αὑτήν to wear itself out by internal struggles, Thuc.:—Pass., τριβόμενος ληός an oppressed people, Hdt.
of money and property, to waste, squander it, Hdt.
to use constantly, Ar.
Pass. to be much busied or engrossed with a thing, Hdt.

div1.head: τριγένεια
div1.sense: a third generation, Strab.

div1.head: τριγέρων
div1.sense: triply old, τρ. μῦθος τάδε φωνεῖ ʼtis a thrice-told tale, Aesch.

div1.head: τριγίγας
div1.sense: a triple (i. e. huge) giant, Orph.

div1.head: τρίγληνος
div1.sense: with three pupils: then, of earrings, with three bright drops, Hom.

div1.head: τρίγλη
div1.sense: the red mullet: also τρίγλα, Anth.

div1.head: τριγλοφόρος
div1.sense: bearing mullets, τρ. χιτών a net for catching them, Anth.

div1.head: τρίγλυφος
div1.sense: in Doric architecture, the triglyph, a three-grooved tablet placed at equal distances along the frieze, Eur.:—also τρίγλυφον, ου, τό, Arist.
div1.head: τρίγλυφος
τριγλώχις
div1.sense: three-barbed, Il.

div1.head: τριγμός
div1.sense: a scream, squeak, Plut.

div1.head: τριγονία
div1.sense: the third generation, Dem.

div1.head: τρίγονος
div1.sense: thrice-born: in pl. simply = τρεῖς, three, Eur.

div1.head: τριγωνοειδής
div1.sense: triangular-shaped, Polyb.

div1.head: τρίγωνος
div1.sense: three-cornered, triangular, Aesch.
as Subst., τρίγωνον, ου, a triangle, Plat.: name of a musical instrument, Plat.

div1.head: τρίδουλος
div1.sense: a slave through three generations, thrice a slave, Soph.

div1.head: τρίδραχμος
div1.sense: worth or weighing three drachms, Ar.

div1.head: τριέλικτος
div1.sense: thrice coiled, Orac. ap. Hdt., Anth.

div1.head: τριέμβολος
div1.sense: like three shipsʼ beaks, Ar.

div1.head: τριετηρίς
div1.sense: (sc. ἑορτή) a triennial festival, Hdt., Eur.
(sub. περίοδος) , a period of three years, Hhymn., Arist.

div1.head: τριέτης
div1.sense: of or for three years, Hdt., Theocr.: netut. τριέτες as adv. for three years, Od.

div1.head: τριζυγής
div1.sense: and τρίζυξ, three yoked, three in union, of the Graces, Eur., Anth.

div1.head: τρίζω
div1.sense: of animals, to utter a shrill cry, to scream, cry, of young birds, Il.; of bats, Od.; of ghosts (which, in Shaksp., "squeak and gibber"), Hom., etc.
of other sounds, νῶτα τετρίγει (Epic plup.) the wrestlersʼ backs cracked, Il.; τρ. τοὺς ὀδόντας to gnash the teeth, NTest.; of a musical string, to twang, Anth.

div1.head: τριημιπόδιον
div1.sense: a length of three half-feet, a foot and a-half, Xen.

div1.head: τριηραρχέω
div1.sense: to be a τριήραρχος, to command a trireme, Hdt., Thuc.: c. gen., τρ. νηός Hdt.

at Athens, to be trierarch, i. e. fit out a trireme for the public service, Ar.; Pass., τριηραρχοῦσιν οἱ πλούσιοι, ὁ δὲ δῆμος τριηραρχεῖται the rich find trierarchs, the people has trierarchs found it, Xen.

div1.head: τριηράρχημα
div1.sense: the trierarchʼs crew, Dem.

div1.head: τριηραρχία
div1.sense: the command of a trireme, Arist.
at Athens, the fitting out of a trireme for the public service, a trierarchy, Xen.

div1.head: τριηραρχικός
div1.sense: of or for the trierarchy, Dem.

div1.head: τριήραρχος
div1.sense: the captain of a trireme, Hdt., Attic
at Athens, a trierarch, who had to fit out a trireme for the public service, Ar., Thuc.

div1.head: τριηραύλης
div1.sense: the flute-player, who gave the time to the rowers in the trireme, Dem.

div1.head: τριήρης
div1.sense: Lat. triremis, a galley with three banks of oars, the common form of the Greek ship-of-war, Hdt., etc.: first built by the Corinthians, Thuc.:—cf. θαλάμιος, ζυγίτης, θρανίτης.

div1.head: τριηρικός
div1.sense: of or for a trireme, Dem.

div1.head: τριηρίτης
div1.sense: a trireme-man, Hdt., Thuc.

div1.head: τριηροποιός
div1.sense: building triremes, Dem.

div1.head: τριθάλασσος
div1.sense: touching on or connected with three seas, Strab.

div1.head: Τρικάρανος
div1.sense: the Three-headed, a satirical attack on three cities, Sparta, Athens, Thebes, Luc.

div1.head: τρικάρηνος
div1.sense: three-headed, Hes., Hdt.

div1.head: τρικέφαλος
div1.sense: three-headed, Luc.

div1.head: τρίκλινος
div1.sense: with three couches: as Subst., τρίκλινος (sub. οἶκος) , a dining-room with three couches, the Roman triclinium.

div1.head: τρίκλωστος
div1.sense: thrice-spun, three-twisted, Anth.

div1.head: τρικόλωνος
div1.sense: three-hilled, Orac. in Strab.

div1.head: τρικόρυθος
div1.note: τρῐ-κόρῠθος, ον; and τρί-κορυς, ῠθος, ὁ,
div1.sense: with triple plume, Eur.

div1.head: τρικόρυφος
div1.sense: three-topped, Strab.

div1.head: τρικόρωνος
div1.sense: thrice a crowʼs age, Anth.

div1.head: τρίκρανος
div1.sense: three-headed, of Cerberus, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: τρικυμία
div1.sense: the third wave, a huge wave, for the third was supposed to be the largest (as in Lat. the fluctus decumanus), Plat.:—metaph., τρ. κακῶν Aesch.

div1.head: τρίλλιστος
div1.sense: thrice (i. e. often or earnestly) prayed for, Il.

div1.head: τριλογία
div1.sense: a trilogy, v. τετραλογία.

div1.head: τριλοφία
div1.sense: a triple crest, Ar.

div1.head: τριμάκαιρα
div1.sense: thrice-blest, Anth.

div1.head: τρίμετρος
div1.sense: of verses, consisting of three metres; i. e. in iambics, trochaics, and anapaestics, of three syzygies (of two feet each); but in dactylics of three single feet: τρ. ἴαμβος an iambic verse of three metres or six feet, versus senarius, Hdt.; so τόνος τρίμετρος trimeter verse, Hdt.; τρίμετρον, ου, Ar.

div1.head: τρίμηνος
div1.sense: of three months, Soph.; so, ἡ τρίμηνος a period of three months, Hdt.

div1.head: τρῖμμα
div1.sense: that which is rubbed: metaph., like τρίβων II. 2, a practised knave, Ar.

div1.head: τριμμός
div1.sense: a beaten road, Xen.

div1.head: τριμοιρία
div1.sense: a triple portion, triple pay, Xen.

div1.head: τρίμοιρος
div1.sense: threefold, triple, Aesch.

div1.head: τρίμορφος
div1.sense: three-formed:—in pl. = τρεῖς, Μοῖραι τρ. the three fates, Aesch.

div1.head: Τρινακρία
div1.sense: Sicily, a later form of Θρινακίη, Thuc.

div1.head: τρίναξ
div1.sense: a trident or three-pronged mattock, Anth.

div1.head: τρίοδος
div1.sense: a meeting of three roads, Lat. trivium, Theogn., Eur., etc.
Hecate, Lat. Trivia, ἁ θεὸς ἐν τριόδοισι Theocr.; οἷος ἐκ τριόδου i. e. vulgar, Luc.

div1.head: τριόδους
div1.sense: with three teeth, three-pronged: as Subst., a trident, Pind.

div1.head: Τριόπιον
div1.sense: a headland of Caria, on which was a temple consecrated to Apollo, τὸ Τριοπικὸν ἱρόν, ὁ Τριόπιος Ἀπολλών Hdt.

div1.head: τριόρχης
div1.sense: a kind of hawk, perh. the buzzard, Ar.

div1.head: τριοτό
div1.sense: a sound imitative of a birdʼs voice, Ar.

div1.head: τρίπαις
div1.sense: having three children, Plut.

div1.head: τρίπαλαι
div1.sense: long long ago, Ar.

div1.head: τριπάλαστος
div1.sense: three hands broad, long, etc., Hdt.

div1.head: τρίπαλτος
div1.sense: thrice-brandished; metaph. threefold, manifold, Aesch.

div1.head: τριπάνουργος
div1.sense: triply-base, an arch-rogue, Anth.

div1.head: τριπάχυιος
div1.sense: thrice-fattened, thrice-gorged, Aesch.

div1.head: τρι-
div1.sense: Prefix, from τρίς or τρία, in compds. three times, thrice, Lat. ter.

div1.head: τριπέτηλος
div1.sense: three-leafed, Hhymn.

div1.head: τρίπηχυς
div1.sense: three cubits long or tall, Hdt., Attic

div1.head: τριπιθήκινος
div1.sense: thrice or thoroughly apish, Anth.

div1.head: τρίπλαξ
div1.sense: triple, threefold, Lat. triplex, Il.

div1.head: τριπλασιάζω
div1.sense: to triple, take three times, Plut.

div1.head: τριπλάσιος
div1.sense: thrice as many, thrice as much, thrice as great as, c. gen., Ar., Plat., etc.: —absol., τριπλασίαν δύναμιν εἶχε (sc. τῆς προτέρας) Xen.
τριπλάσιον as adv., τριπλάσιον thrice as much, Ar.

div1.head: τρίπλεθρος
div1.sense: three πλέθρα wide, Xen.

div1.head: τριπλόος
div1.sense: triple, threefold, ἐν τριπλαῖς ἀμαξιτοῖς ἐν τριόδῳ, Soph.; ὄνομα τρ. compounded of three, Arist.:—Attic neut. pl. τριπλᾶ, Aesch.:—dat. fem. τριπλῇ as adv., Il., Luc.

div1.head: τριπόδης
div1.sense: three feet long, Hes.

div1.head: τριποδηφορέω
div1.sense: to bring a tripod, offer it as a sign of victory, Strab.

div1.head: τριπόθητος
div1.sense: thrice (i. e. much)longed for, Bion., Mosch.

div1.head: τρίπολις
div1.sense: with three cities, Pind.

div1.head: τριπόλιστος
div1.sense: thrice-repeated, Soph.

div1.head: τρίπολος
div1.sense: thrice ploughed, Hom., Hes.

div1.head: τριπόνητος
div1.sense: τριπόνητος, ἔρις, ἡ, a contest between three labouring women, Anth.

div1.head: τρίπορθος
div1.sense: thrice-wasted, Anth.

div1.head: τρίπους
div1.sense: three-footed, of or with three feet: and so
measuring three feet, Hdt., Plat.
going on three feet, of an old man who leans on a staff, Hes.; so, τρίποδας ὁδοὺς στείχει Aesch.
with three feet, three-legged:
a tripod, a three-footed brass kettle or caldron, Hom.: —from a tripod of this kind (Lat. cortina) the Delphic Priestess delivered her oracles, Eur., Ar.
a three-legged table, Xen.

div1.head: τριπτήρ
div1.sense: the vat into which the oil runs when pressed out: metaph., τρ. δικῶν a vat to receive the juice of law-suits, Ar.

div1.head: τρίπτης
div1.sense: a rubber, shampooer, Plut.

div1.head: τρίπτυχος
div1.sense: threefold, Lat. triplex, Il., Eur.

div1.head: τρίπωλος
div1.sense: of or with three horses: τρ. ἅρμα δαιμόνων, of the three goddesses on Mount Ida, Eur.

div1.head: τρίρρυμος
div1.sense: with three poles, i. e. with four horses abreast, Aesch.

div1.head: τρισάθλιος
div1.sense: thrice-unhappy, Soph., etc.

div1.head: τρισάλαστος
div1.sense: thrice-tormented, Anth.

div1.head: τρισάριθμος
div1.sense: thrice-numbered, Orac. ap. Luc.

div1.head: τρισάσμενος
div1.sense: thrice-pleased, most willing, Xen.

div1.head: τρισάωρος
div1.sense: thrice-untimely, Anth.

div1.head: τρισεινάς
div1.sense: (sc. ἡμέρα) , -άδος, the third ninth day in a month; i. e. the ninth day (ἡ ἐννεάς) of the third decad, the 29th, Hes.

div1.head: τρισέπαρχος
div1.sense: thrice an ἔπαρχος, i. e. Praetor, Anth.

div1.head: τρισευδαίμων
div1.sense: thrice-happy, Luc.

div1.head: τρεισκαιδεκάπηχυς
div1.sense: thirteen cubits high, ἀνὴρ τρ., of a long lazy loon, Theocr.

div1.head: τρεισκαιδεκαστάσιος
div1.sense: of thirteen times the value of silver, Hdt.

div1.head: τρεισκαιδέκατος
div1.sense: thirteenth, Hom., etc.; ἡ τρισκαιδεκάτη (sc. ἡμέρα) the 13 th day, Od.

div1.head: τρεισκαιδεκαφόρος
div1.sense: fruiting thirteen times, Luc.

div1.head: τρεισκαιδεκέτης
div1.sense: thirteen years old, Lys.

div1.head: τρισκακοδαίμων
div1.sense: thrice unlucky, Ar.

div1.head: τρίσκαλμος
div1.sense: with three oarpins; but νᾶες αἱ τρ. are simply = τριήρεις, Aesch.

div1.head: τρισκατάρατος
div1.sense: thrice-accursed, Dem.

div1.head: τρισκελής
div1.sense: three-legged, ξόανον Theocr.

div1.head: τρισκοπάνιστος
