div1.sense: thrice-kneaded, Batr.

div1.head: τρίσμακαρ
div1.sense: thrice-blest, Od., Ar., etc.

div1.head: τρισμύριοι
div1.sense: thrice ten thousand, 30, 000, Hdt., Ar., etc.:—in sg. with a collective Subst., τρισμυρία ἵππος thirty thousand horse, Aesch.

div1.head: τρισμυριόπαλαι
div1.sense: thirty thousand times long-ago, Ar.

div1.head: τρισόλβιος
div1.sense: thrice happy or fortunate, Anth.

div1.head: τρισολυμπιονίκης
div1.sense: thrice victorious at Olympia, Pind.

div1.head: τρισπίθαμος
div1.sense: three spans long, Hes., Xen.

div1.head: τρίσπονδος
div1.sense: thrice-poured, τρ. χοαί a triple drink-offering, of honey, milk, and wine, Soph.

div1.head: τρίς
div1.sense: thrice, three times, Lat. ter, Hom., etc.; τρὶς τόσος thrice as much or many, Il., etc.; ἐς τρίς up to three times, even thrice, Hdt., Attic: —used to add force to a word in compds., such as τρισάθλιος, τρίσμακαρ, like Lat. ter beatus, thrice blest: — proverb., τρὶς ἓξ βάλλειν to throw thrice six, i. e. the highest throw (there being three dice), Aesch.

div1.head: τρισσόθεν
div1.sense: from three sides, Anth.

div1.head: τρισσός
div1.sense: threefold, Lat. triplex, Eur., etc.:—adv. -ῶς, Anth.
in pl., = τρεῖς, Pind., Soph., etc.

div1.head: τρίστεγος
div1.sense: of or with three stories: τὸ τρ. (sc. οἴκημα) the third story, NTest.

div1.head: τριστοιχί
div1.sense: in three rows, Il., Hes.

div1.head: τρίστοιχος
div1.sense: in three rows, Od.:— threefold, Anth.

div1.head: τρίστομος
div1.sense: three-edged or -pointed, Anth.

div1.head: τρισύλλαβος
div1.sense: trisyllabic, Luc.

div1.head: τρισχίλιοι
div1.sense: three thousand, Il., etc.

div1.head: τρισχιλιοστός
div1.sense: the three-thousandth, Plat.

div1.head: τρισώματος
div1.sense: three-bodied, Lat. tricorpor, Aesch.

div1.head: τριταγωνιστέω
div1.sense: to be a τριταγωνιστής, Dem.

div1.head: τριταγωνιστής
div1.sense: on the stage, the player who took the third part, a third-rate actor, Dem.

div1.head: τριταῖος
div1.sense: on the third day, used with Verbs so as to agree with the subject, τριταῖοι ἐγένοντο ἐν τῇ Ἀττικῇ Hdt.; ἐσβεβληκὼς τριταῖος ἐς Μηλιέας having invaded Melis three days before, Hdt.; τρ. γενόμενος after being three days dead, Hdt.:— τριταῖος (sc. πυρετός) , a tertian fever, Plat.
of events, lasting three days, Eur.
generally for τρίτος, Eur.

div1.head: τριτάλαντος
div1.sense: of three talents, Ar.
worth three talents, Isae.

div1.head: τριτάλας
div1.sense: thrice-wretched, Eur., Anth.

div1.head: τριτάνυστος
div1.sense: thrice-stretched, very long, Anth.

div1.head: τριτημόριος
div1.sense: forming a third part of, c. gen., Hdt.
as Subst., τριτημόριον, ου, a third part, a third, Hdt., Thuc., etc.

div1.head: τριτοβάμων
div1.sense: forming a third foot, Eur.

div1.head: Τριτογένεια
div1.sense: Trito-born, a name of Athena, Hom., Hes., Hhymn., Orac. ap. Hdt.
div1.etym: From the Lake Τριτωνίς in Libya, near which the goddess was born, Eur. Others interpret τριτογένεια born on the third day of the month, or the third child after Apollo and Artemis.

div1.head: τριτόκος
div1.sense: bearing three times or three at a time, Anth.

div1.head: τριτόσπονδος
div1.sense: τρ. αἰών a life in which one has poured the third libation (to Ζεὺς Σωτήρ) , i. e. complete felicity, Aesch.

div1.head: τριτόσπορος
div1.sense: sown for the third time, τρ. γονή the third generation, Aesch.

div1.head: τρίτος
div1.sense: the third, Lat. tertius, Hom., etc.; τρίτος ἦλθε he came himself the third, i. e. with two others, Od.; so, τρίτος αὐτός, Attic:— the third often appears as completing the tale, τρίτην ἐπενδίδωμι (sub. πληγήν) the third and finishing stroke, Aesch.; cf. σωτήρ I. 2.
τρίτη, with or without ἡμέρα, the day after to-morrow, ἐς τρίτην ἡμέραν Ar.; τῇ τρίτῃ Xen.;—but, χθὲς καὶ τρ. ἡμέραν yesterday and the day before, Xen.
τρίτον as adv., thirdly, Soph., Eur., etc.; also, τὸ τρίτον Hom., Attic
τρίτα, ων, τά,
(sub. ἱερά) a sacrifice to the dead, offered the third day after the funeral, Isae.
τὰ τρίτα λέγειν τινί to play the third part to any one, Dem.

div1.head: τριττύς
div1.sense: the number three, Lat. ternio: esp. a sacrifice of three animals, a boar, goat, and ram, Ar.
at Athens, a third of the φυλή, Dem., Aeschin.

div1.head: Τριτωνιάς
div1.sense: Τρῑτωνιὰς λίμνη, ἡ, the Libyan lake Tritonis, Eur.

div1.head: Τριτωνίς
div1.sense: Tritonis, a lake in Libya famous for old Greek legends, Pind., Hdt.; cf. Τριτογένεια.

div1.head: Τρίτων
div1.sense: Triton, a sea-god, son of Poseidon and Amphitrite, Hes.:—pl. Τρίτωνες, Tritons, a lower race of sea-gods, Mosch.
the god of the Libyan lake Tritonis, Hdt.
a river in Libya, joining the lake Tritonis with the sea, Hdt., Aesch.

div1.head: τριφάσιος
div1.sense: threefold, Lat. triplex, Hdt.:—in pl., much the same as τρεῖς, Hdt.

div1.head: τριφίλητος
div1.sense: thrice-beloved, Theocr.

div1.head: τρίφυλλον
div1.sense: a plant, tre-foil, clover, Hdt.

div1.head: τρίφυλος
div1.sense: of three tribes, τριφύλους ποιέειν to divide into three tribes, Hdt.

div1.head: τριχάϊκες
div1.sense: the threefold people, i. e. the Dorians, so called from their three tribes, Od.

div1.head: τριχάλεπτος
div1.sense: very angry, Anth.

div1.head: τρίχαλκον
div1.sense: a coin worth three χαλκοῖ, Theophr.

div1.head: τρίχαλος
div1.sense: cloven in three, Aesch.

div1.head: τρίχα
div1.sense: threefold, in three parts, Lat. trifariam, Hom.; c. gen., τρ. νυκτὸς ἔην ʼtwas in the third watch of the night, Od.; τρίχα σχίζειν τι Hdt.

div1.head: τριχῆ
div1.sense: in or into three parts, Hdt., Xen.
in three ways, triply, Plat.

div1.head: τριχθά
div1.sense: in or into three parts, Hom.

div1.head: τρίχινος
div1.sense: of hair, Xen.

div1.head: τριχίς
div1.sense: a kind of anchovy full of small hair-like bones, Ar.

div1.head: τριχόβρως
div1.sense: eating hair: hence τριχόβρωτες, = σῆτες or θρῖπες, moths, Ar.

div1.head: τριχοίνικος
div1.sense: holding or measuring three χοίνικες, Xen.: Comic phrase, τρ. ἔπος a most capacious word, Ar.

div1.head: τριχόλωτος
div1.sense: thrice-detested, Anth.

div1.head: τριχόμαλλος
div1.sense: hair-fleeced, Anth.

div1.head: τριχόω
div1.sense: Pass. to be furnished with hair, Sch. in Arist.

div1.head: τριχορρυέω
div1.sense: to shed the hair, Ar.

div1.head: τριχοῦ
div1.sense: in three places, Hdt.

div1.head: τριχόφοιτος
div1.sense: τριχό-φοιτος ἴουλος, the first down of youth just passing into hair, Anth.

div1.head: τρίχωμα
div1.sense: a growth of hair, hair, Hdt., Xen.; ἐν γενείου συλλογῇ τριχώματος, i. e. just at the age of manhood, Aesch.

div1.head: τριψημερέω
div1.sense: to waste the day, Lat. terere tempus, Ar.

div1.head: τρῖψις
div1.sense: rubbing, friction, Plat., etc.
resistance to the touch when rubbed, firmness, Hdt.
τρίψεις potted meats, Anth.

div1.head: τριώβολον
div1.sense: a three-obol-piece, a half-drachma, at Athens, the pay of the dicasts for a dayʼs sitting, first given by Pericles, Ar.
the pay of the marine soldiery (ἐπιβάται) , Thuc.

div1.head: τριώροφος
div1.sense: of three stories or floors, Hdt.

div1.head: τριώρυγος
div1.sense: of three fathoms, Xen.

div1.head: Τροίαθεν
div1.sense: from Troy, Od.; ἀπὸ Τροίηθε Il.; Doric Τρωίᾱθεν Pind.

div1.head: Τροίανδε
div1.sense: to Troy, Il., etc.; Doric Τρῴανδε Pind.

div1.head: Τροία
div1.sense: Troy, whether of the city, "Troytown, " Hom., etc.; or the country, the Troad, Il.:— also Τροΐα, as trisyll., Soph.; Doric Τρωία, Pind., Aesch.; contr. Τρῴα, Pind.

div1.head: Τροιζήνιος
div1.note: Τροιζήνιος, α, ον, Eur.; fem. Τροιζηνίς, ίδος,
div1.sense: of Troezen, οἱ Τροιζήνιοι the people of Troezen, Hdt.

div1.head: Τροιζήν
div1.sense: Troezen in Argolis, Il., Hdt., etc.

div1.head: τρομερός
div1.sense: trembling, Eur.: trembling for fear, quaking, Eur.
fearful, Eur.

div1.head: τρομέω
div1.sense: to tremble, quake, quiver, esp. from fear, Il.:—c. inf. to fear to do, Theocr.
c. acc. to tremble before or at a person, to stand in awe of, Hom.
div1.etym: In each sense Hom. uses both Act. and Mid., but only in pres. and imperf.; Epic and Ionic τρομεοίατο for τρομέοιντο, Il.; Ionic part. τρομεύμενος Solon.

div1.head: τρόμος
div1.sense: a trembling, quaking, quivering, esp. from fear, Il., Aesch.
from cold, Plat.

div1.head: τροπαία
div1.sense: (sc. πνοή) , an alternating wind:—metaph., λήματος, φρενὸς τροπαία a change in the spirit of oneʼs mind, Aesch.; τρ. κακῶν a release from evils, Aesch.

div1.head: τρόπαιον
div1.sense: a trophy, Lat. tropaeum, Trag., etc.; i. e. a monument of the enemyʼs defeat (τροπή II), consisting of arms taken from the enemy, hung on trees or posts; the common phrase was στῆσαι or στήσασθαι τρ. to set up trophies, Eur., Thuc.; ἱδρῦσαι Eur.; c. gen. pers., τροπαῖα τῶν πολεμίων a trophy won from the enemy, Eur.; so, τροπαῖʼ ἔστησε τῶν ἐμῶν χερῶν Soph.; and, στῆσαι τροπαῖα κατὰ or ἀπὸ τῶν πολεμίων, Lat. triumphare de aliquo, Oratt.

div1.head: τροπαῖος
div1.sense: of or for defeat (τροπή II), ἐχθρῶν θύειν τροπαῖα (sc. ἱερά) a sacrifice for their defeat, Eur.; Ζεὺς Τρ., as giver of victory, Soph.
causing rout, Ἕκτορος ὄμμασι τροπαῖοι, i. e. terrible to the eyes of Hector, Eur.
like ἀποτρόπαιος, averting, Lat. averruncus, Ζεύς Soph.

div1.head: τροπαιοφόρος
div1.sense: bearing trophies, Plut.

div1.head: τρόπαλις
div1.sense: a bundle, bunch, σκορόδων τρ. a bunch of garlic, Ar.

div1.head: τροπέω
div1.sense: to turn, Il.

div1.head: τροπή
div1.sense: a turn, turning:

τροπαὶ ἠελίοιο the tropics or solstices, i. e. midsummer and midwinter, Lat. solstitium and bruma, when the sun appears to turn his course and cross the ecliptic. Hom. speaks of τροπαὶ ἠελίοιο as denoting a point in the heavens, prob. to the westward, Od.; τροπαὶ θεριναί and χειμεριναί, Hdt., Attic:—when τροπαί is used alone, it mostly refers to the winter solstice, περὶ ἡλίου τροπάς (sc. χειμερινάς) Thuc.
a turn, change, = μεταβολή, Aeschin., Plut.
τροπαὶ λέξεως a change of speech by figures or tropes (τρόποι) , Luc.

the turning of the enemy, putting him to flight, a rout, τροπήν (or τροπάς) τινος ποιεῖν or ποιεῖσθαι to put one to flight, Hdt., Ar., etc.; τροπὴ γίγνεται Hdt.; ἐν τροπῇ δορός in the rout caused by the spear, Soph.

div1.head: τροπικός
div1.sense: of the solstice, ὁ τροπικός (sc. κύκλος) the tropic or solstice, Arist.; αἱ τρ. ἡμέραι Arist.
in Rhetoric, tropical, figurative.

div1.head: τρόπις
div1.sense: a shipʼs keel, Od., Hdt.; τρόπεις θέσθαι to lay the keel, Plut.; and metaph., λέγε τὴν τρόπιν τοῦ πράγματος Ar.

div1.head: τρόπος
div1.sense: a turn, direction, course, way, Hdt.

a way, manner, fashion, τρόπῳ τοιῷδε in such wise, Hdt.; τίνι τρόπῳ; Lat. quomodo? how? Aesch., etc.; ποίῳ τρ.; Aesch.; ἑνί γε τῷ τρ. in one way or other, Ar.; παντὶ τρόπῳ by all means, Aesch.; οὐδενὶ τρ., μηδενὶ τρ. in no wise, by no means, on no account, Hdt., etc.:—so in pl., τρόποισι ποίοις; Soph.; ναυκλήρου τρόποις Soph.

absol. in acc., τίνα τρόπον; how? Ar.; τρ. τινά in a manner, Eur.; οὐδένα, μηδένα τρ. Xen.; πίτυος τρόπον after the manner of a pine, Hdt.; in pl., κεχώρισται τοὺς τρόπους in its ways, Hdt.; πάντας τρόπους in all ways, Plat.
with Preps., γυναικὸς ἐν τρόποις, ἐν τρ. Ἰξίονος Aesch.:— ἐς ὄρνιθος τρ. Luc.; κατὰ πάντα τρ. Ar., etc.; κατὰ πάντας τρόπους Ar.:— κατὰ τρόπον, absol., fitly, duly, Lat. rite, Isocr.

of persons, a way of life, habit, custom, Pind.; μῶν ἡλιαστά; Answ. μἀλλὰ θατέρου τρ. are you a Heliast?—No, but of the other sort, Ar.:—a manʼs character, temper, τρόπου ἡσυχίου of a quiet temper, Hdt.; οὐ τοὐμοῦ τρόπου not to my taste, Ar.; πρὸς τοῦ Κύρου τρόπου Xen.; so in pl. ways, habits, σκληρὸς τοὺς τρόπους Ar.; ὑπηρετεῖν τοῖς τρόποις τινός Ar.
in Music, τρ. Λύδιος Pind.; ᾠδῆς τρόπος Plat.
in speaking or writing, manner, style, Isocr.:—but in Rhetoric, tropes, figures, Cic.

div1.head: τροπός
div1.sense: a twisted leathern thong, with which the oar was fastened to the thole, Od.

div1.head: τροποφορέω
div1.sense: to bear with, τινά NTest.

div1.head: τροπόω
div1.sense: to furnish the oar with its thong: Mid., τροποῦτο κώπην ἀμφὶ σκαλμόν fastened his oar by its thong round the thole, Aesch.:—Pass., of the oar, to be furnished with its thong, Ar.

div1.head: τροφαλίς
div1.sense: a piece of cheese, Ar.

div1.head: τροφεῖα
div1.sense: pay for bringing up, the wages of a nurse or rearer, Aesch., etc.
βίου τροφεῖα oneʼs living, food, Soph.; τροφεῖα ματρός motherʼs milk, Eur.

div1.head: τροφεύς
div1.sense: one who rears or brings up, a foster-father, Soph., Eur.; of a woman, a nurse, Aesch.:—metaph. of the plains and fountains of Troy, χαίρετʼ ὦ τροφῆς ἐμοί ye who reared me, Soph.; πάσης κακίας τρ. one who fosters all wickedness, Plat.

div1.head: τροφή
div1.sense: nourishment, food, victuals, Hdt., Soph., etc.; ἡ καθʼ ἡμέραν τρ. oneʼs daily bread, Thuc.; τροφὴν παρέχειν to furnish provisions, forage, Thuc.
βίου τροφή or τροφαί a way of life, livelihood, living, Soph.; so, τροφή alone, δουλίαν ἕξειν τροφήν Soph.; then, simply, a mode of life, life, Plat.
that which provides sustenance, as the bow of Philoctetes, Soph.
nurture, rearing, bringing up, Hdt., Trag.; in pl., ἐν τροφαῖσιν while in the nursery, Aesch., etc.
education, Eur., etc.
sometimes, in Poets, a brood, νέα τροφή, of young people, Soph.; ἀρνῶν τροφαί, i. e. young lambs, Eur.

div1.head: τροφίας
div1.sense: brought up in the house, stall-fed, Plut.

div1.head: τρόφιμος
div1.sense: nourishing: c. gen., γᾶ τρόφιμε τῶν ἐμῶν τέκνων Eur.
as Subst., τρόφιμος, the master of the house, ἡ τροφίμη the mistress, Anth.
pass. nourished and reared up, a nursling, foster-child, Eur.; οἱ τρόφιμοι our nurslings, pupils, Plat., Xen.

div1.head: τρόφις
div1.sense: well-fed, stout, large, τρόφι κῦμα a huge, swollen wave, Il.; of men, ἐπεὰν γένωνται τρόφιες οἱ παῖδες when the children grow big, Hdt.

div1.head: τροφόεις
div1.sense: well-fed: hence large, big, of waves, Hom.

div1.head: τροφός
div1.sense: a feeder, rearer, nurse, Od., Hdt., Attic: metaph., of a city, Pind., Aesch.

div1.head: τροφοφορέω
div1.sense: to bring one nourishment, maintain, sustain, NTest.

div1.head: Τροφώνιος
div1.sense: the builder of the temple of Apollo at Delphi, Hhymn., Hdt.; καταβαίνων ὥσπερ ἐς Τροφωνίου (sc. ἄντρον) Ar.

div1.head: τροχάζω
div1.sense: to run like a wheel, to run along, run quickly, Hdt., Xen., etc.; τρ. ἵπποις, of a charioteer, Eur.

div1.head: τροχαῖος
div1.sense: running, tripping, Anth.
τροχαῖος (sc. πούς) , a trochee or foot consisting of a long and short syllable, used in quick time, Plat., Arist.

div1.head: τροχαλός
div1.sense: running, τροχαλόν τινα τιθέναι to make one run quick, Hes.; τρ. ὄχοι swift-rolling, Eur.

div1.head: τροχερός
div1.sense: running, tripping, Arist.

div1.head: τροχηλατέω
div1.sense: to drive a chariot: to drive about, drive round and round, Eur.

div1.head: τροχηλάτης
div1.sense: one who guides wheels, i. e. a charioteer, Soph., Eur.

div1.head: τροχήλατος
div1.sense: driven on wheels, wheel-drawn, Aesch., Soph.
dragged by or at the wheels, Eur.
metaph. hurried along like a wheel or chariot, Eur.; μανία τρ. whirling madness, Eur.

div1.head: τροχιά
div1.sense: the round of a wheel, Anth.

div1.head: τροχίζω
div1.sense: to turn round on the wheel, torture, Arist.

div1.head: τροχιλεία
div1.sense: the sheaf of a pulley, roller of a windlass, and the like, Lat. trochlea, Ar.

div1.head: τροχίλος
div1.sense: a small bird, the sandpiper, said to pick leeches out of the crocodileʼs throat, Hdt.

div1.head: τροχιός
div1.sense: round, Anth.

div1.head: τρόχις
div1.sense: a runner, messenger, Aesch.

div1.head: τροχοδινέομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to whirl or roll round, Aesch.

div1.head: τροχοειδής
div1.sense: round as a wheel, circular, Theogn., Hdt.

div1.head: τροχόεις
div1.sense: round as a wheel, round, Anth.

div1.head: τροχοποιέω
div1.sense: to make wheels, Ar.

div1.head: τροχός
div1.sense: anything that runs round:
a round cake, Od.
a wheel, Il., Soph.; τροχοὺς μιμεῖσθαι to imitate wheels, of one who bends back so as to form a wheel, Xen.
a potterʼs wheel, Il.
the wheel of a stage-machine, Ar.
the wheel of torture, ἐπὶ τοῦ τροχοῦ στρεβλοῦσθαι Ar., etc.; τῷ τροχῷ τινα προσδεῖν Luc.
a boyʼs hoop, the Graecus trochus of Hor.
τροχοὶ γῆς, θαλάσσης circles or zones of land, sea, Plat.
a ring on the bit of a bridle, Xen.

div1.head: τρόχος
div1.sense: a running, course, μὴ πολλοὺς τρόχους ἁμιλλητῆρας ἡλίου not many racing courses of the sun, i. e. not many days, Soph.; παῖδες ἐκ τρόχων πεπαυμένοι Eur.
a race-course, Eur.

div1.head: τρύβλιον
div1.sense: a cup, bowl, Ar.

div1.head: τρυγάω
div1.sense: with acc. of the fruit or crop, to gather in, Lat. vindemiare, ἑτέρας σταφυλὰς τρυγόωσιν Od.; καρπόν Hdt.:—metaph., τρυγήσομεν αὐτήν (sc. Εἰρήνην) Ar.:—Pass., τετρυγημένοι καθʼ ὥραν gathered in due season, Luc.
absol., Ar.
with acc. of the trees or ground, ὅτε τρυγόῳεν ἀλωήν (Epic opt. for τρυγῷεν) when they gathered fruit off the vineyard, Il.
proverb., ἐρήμας τρυγᾶν (sc. ἀμπέλους) to strip unwatched vines, i. e. to be bold where there is nothing to fear, Ar.

div1.head: τρύγη
div1.sense: ripe fruit, a grain-crop, corn, οὐδὲ τρύγην οἴσεις Hhymn.
the vintage, Anth.

div1.head: τρυγητήρ
div1.sense: one who gathers grapes, Lat. vindemiator, Hes. [with ῡ].

div1.head: τρύγητος
div1.sense: a vintage, harvest, Plut., Luc.
the time thereof, the harvest or vintage, Thuc.

div1.head: τρυγηφόρος
div1.sense: bearing fruits, esp. wine, Hhymn.

div1.head: τρυγικός
div1.sense: of lees, = κωμῳδικός, Ar.

div1.head: τρυγοδαίμων
div1.sense: Com. word for τρυγῳδός, with a play on κακοδαίμων, a poor-devil poet, Ar.

div1.head: τρύγοιπος
div1.sense: a straining-cloth for wine, Ar.

div1.head: τρυγῳδός
div1.sense: a lees-singer, = κωμῳδός, because the singers smeared their faces with lees (peruncti faecibus ora, Hor.), Ar.

div1.head: τρυγών
div1.sense: the turtle-dove, Ar.

div1.head: τρυμαλιά
div1.sense: a hole, ἡ τρ. τῆς ῥαφίδος the eye of the needle, NTest.

div1.head: τρύμη
div1.sense: a hole: metaph. a sharp fellow, sly knave, Ar.

div1.head: τρύξ
div1.sense: new wine not yet fermented, wine with the lees in it, must, Lat. mustum, Hdt., Ar.
the lees of wine, Lat. faex, Hdt., Ar.:—metaph. of an old man or woman, Ar.

div1.head: τρύπανον
div1.sense: a carpenterʼs tool, a borer, auger, Lat. terebra, worked by a thong, Od., Eur.

div1.head: τρυπάω
div1.sense: to bore, pierce through, Od.:—Pass., τὰ ὦτα τετρυπημένος having oneʼs ears pierced for earrings, Xen.; ψῆφος τετρυπημένη the pebble of condemnation which had a hole in it, Aeschin.
τρ. τῷ ποδὶ τὴν βελόνην to force the point through the foot, Anth.

div1.head: τρύπημα
div1.sense: a hole, τρ. νεώς, i. e. one of the holes through which the oars worked, Ar.: like τρυμαλιά, the eye of a needle, NTest.

div1.head: τρύπη
div1.sense: a hole, Anth.

div1.head: τρυσάνωρ
div1.sense: wearying a man, Soph.

div1.head: τρυσίβιος
div1.sense: wearing out life, Ar.

div1.head: τρυτάνη
div1.sense: the tongue of a balance, and generally, a balance, pair of scales, Lat. trutina, Ar., Dem.

div1.head: τρυφάλεια
div1.sense: a helmet, Il.

div1.head: τρυφάω
div1.sense: to live softly, delicately, luxuriously, to fare sumptuously, Eur.:—part. τρυφῶν as adj. delicate, effeminate, luxurious, voluptuous, Ar., Plat.; τὸ τρυφῶν, as Subst., effeminacy, Ar.
to be licentious, revel, run riot, wax wanton, Eur., etc.; to be extravagant, Arist.
to give oneself airs, be fastidious, Eur., Plat.

div1.head: τρυφεραίνομαι
div1.sense: Pass. to be fastidious, τρυφερανθείς with a coxcombʼs airs, Ar.

div1.head: τρυφερός
div1.sense: delicate, dainty, Eur., Anth.

of persons, effeminate, luxurious, voluptuous, Ar., etc.:— τὸ τρυφερόν effeminacy, ἐς τὸ τρυφερώτερον to more effeminate habits, Thuc.:—neut. as adv., τρυφερόν voluptuously, Ar.; τρ. λαλεῖν to speak softly, Theocr.

div1.head: τρυφηλός
div1.etym: rare poet. form of τρυφερός, Anth.

div1.head: τρύφημα
div1.sense: that in which one takes pride, a pride, Eur.

div1.head: τρυφή
div1.sense: softness, delicacy, daintiness, Eur., Plat., etc.:—in pl. luxuries, daintinesses, Lat. deliciae, Eur.
luxuriousness, wantonness, Plat.
daintiness, insolence, fastidiousness, Plat.

div1.head: τρύφος
div1.sense: that which is broken off, a piece, morsel, lump, Od., Hdt.

div1.head: τρυχηρός
div1.sense: ragged, tattered, Eur.

div1.head: τρύχνος
div1.sense: nightshade, used as a symbol of sweet forgetfulness, Theocr.

div1.head: τρυχόω
div1.sense: mid.-pass. to be worn out, perf. part. τετρυχωμένος Thuc.

div1.head: τρῦχος
div1.sense: a worn out garment, a rag, shred, Eur.;—in pl. rags, tatters, Eur.

div1.head: τρύχω
div1.sense: to wear out, waste, consume, Od., Hes.; πτωχὸν τρύξοντά ἑ αὐτόν a beggar to eat him out of house and home, Od.; τρύχει ψυχάν distresses, afflicts the soul, Soph.; τρ. στρατείαις τὴν πόλιν Xen.:—Pass. to be worn out, Od., Soph., etc.:— τρύχεσθαί τινος to pine away for some one, Eur.

div1.head: τρύω
div1.sense: to rub down, wear out, Aesch.:—Pass. to be worn out, τετρῦσθαι ἐς τὸ ἔσχατον κακοῦ Hdt.; τετρυμένος ταλαιπωρίηισι Hdt.

div1.head: Τρῳάς
div1.sense: Trojan, Od.; Τρωιάδες γυναῖκες, or alone, Τρωιάδες Il.
γῆ Τρῳάς the Troad, Soph.; so ἡ Τρωάς Hdt.

div1.head: τρωγάλια
div1.sense: fruits eaten at dessert, figs, nuts, sweetmeats, Ar.

div1.head: τρώγλη
div1.sense: a hole formed by gnawing, a mouseʼs hole, Batr., Babr.

div1.head: τρωγλοδύτης
div1.sense: one who creeps into holes:— Τρωγλοδύται, ῶν, οἱ, Troglodytes, cave-men, an Aethiopian tribe, Hdt.

div1.head: τρωγλοδύνων
div1.etym: part. with no ind. in use
div1.sense: creeping into a hole, of a mouse, Batr.

div1.head: τρώγω
div1.sense: to gnaw, nibble, munch, of herbivorous animals, as mules, Od.; of swine, Ar.; of cattle, Theocr.
of men, to eat vegetables or fruit, Hdt., Ar.

div1.head: Τρωΐαθεν
div1.sense: from Troy, Pind.

div1.head: Τρωϊκός
div1.sense: Trojan, Il., Soph., etc.; τὰ Τρωικά the times of Troy, Hdt.

div1.head: Τρώϊος
div1.sense: of Tros, Il.
Trojan, Il.

div1.head: τρώκτης
div1.sense: a gnawer, nibbler: Phoenician traffickers are called τρῶκται, greedy knaves, Od.; so, τρῶκται χεῖρες greedy hands, Anth.

div1.head: τρωκτός
div1.sense: to be eaten raw: eatable, Hdt.
τρωκτά, τά, τρωγάλια, Hdt.

div1.head: Τρωξάρτης
div1.sense: bread-gnawer, Batr.

div1.head: τρῶξις
div1.sense: a biting, τῶν ὀνύχων Arist.

div1.head: Τρωοφθόρος
div1.sense: destructive to the Trojans or to Troy, Anth.

div1.head: τρωπάω
div1.sense: to turn constantly, change its notes, of the nightingale, Od.:—Mid. to turn oneself, turn about, Hom.

div1.head: Τρώς
div1.sense: Tros, the mythic founder of Troy, Il.
pl. Τρῶες, Τρώων, οἱ, Trojans, Hom., etc.

div1.head: τρωτός
div1.sense: to be wounded, vulnerable, Il., Attic

div1.head: τρωχάω
div1.sense: to run fast, gallop, Hom.

div1.head: τυγχάνω
div1.sense: to hit, esp. to hit a mark with an arrow, Hom., etc.: he mostly constructs it with acc., when the object hit is alive, with gen. when it is lifeless; so, τ. τοῦ σκοποῦ Xen.;—a prep. is sometimes added, κατὰ κληῖδα, κατὰ ζωστῆρα τυχήσας τινά Il.;—absol., ἤμβροτες οὐδʼ ἔτυχες Hom.; the part. τυχών is often joined with βάλλειν, οὐτᾶν, etc., Hom.
to hit upon, light upon:

to meet by chance, meet with, fall in with a person, absol., Od.; c. gen., Aesch., etc.:—aor2 part. ὁ τυχών, the first one meets, any one, Lat. quivis, Hes., Plat., etc.; οἱ τυχόντες every-day men, the vulgar, Xen.; so, τὸ τυχόν any chance thing, Plat.

to meet with, hit, reach, gain, get, obtain a thing, and in the past tenses (like κέκτημαι), to be in possession of, to have, c. gen., Od., etc.:—after Hom. also c. acc., τ. μισθόν Hdt.; τὰ πρόσφορα Aesch., etc.:—gen. pers. added, to obtain a thing from a person, τ. τί τινος Soph.; τινὸς παρά τινος Od.
also in bad sense, βίης τυχεῖν to meet with, suffer violence, Hdt.; τ. κακῶν Eur.
absol. to hit the mark, to make a hit, Il., Attic; so, τυχόντες καλῶς Aesch.
to have the lot or fate, ὅς κε τύχηι whoever draws the lot (to die), Il.
intr. to happen to be at a place, εἴπερ τύχηισι μάλα σχεδόν if by chance she be quite near, Il. etc.
of events, and things generally, to happen to one, befal one, fall to oneʼs lot, c. dat. pers., Il., Attic; also to turn out well, Od.
impers., ὅπως ἐτύγχανεν as it chanced, i. e. without any rule, indefinitely, Eur.; ὡς or ὥσπερ ἔτυχεν Xen.; ὁπότε τύχοι when it chanced, sometimes, Plat.

joined with a part., τὰ νοέων τυγχάνω which I have just now in my mind, Hdt.; ὃ τυγχάνω μαθών which I have just learnt, Soph.; ἔτυχον στρατευόμενοι they were just then engaged in an expedition, Thuc.;—in phrase τυγχάνω ὤν, simply = εἰμί, Aesch., Soph., etc.

the part. is often omitted, ἔνδον γὰρ ἄρτι τυγχάνει (sc. ὤν) Soph.; εἰ σὺ τυγχάνεις ἐπιστήμων Plat.:—sometimes indeed τυγχάνειν is used very much like εἶναι, τ. ἐν ἐμπύροις to be engaged in sacrifice, Eur.; ὡς ἕκαστοι ἐτύγχανον just as they all were, Xen.
in many phrases it is easy to supply a part., ὅ τι ἂν τύχωσι, τοῦτο λέγουσι they say whatever comes uppermost (i. e. ὅ τι ἂν τύχωσι λέγοντες), Plat.
neut. part. τυχόν, absol. like παρόν, since it so befel, Luc.
as adv. perchance, perhaps, Xen., Plat.

div1.head: Τυδεύς
div1.sense: the hero Tydeus, one of the Seven against Thebes, Hom.

div1.head: τυῖδε
div1.sense: here, Theocr.
for δεῦρο, with Verbs of motion, Theocr.

div1.head: τύκη
div1.sense: masonʼs work, Eur.

div1.head: τυκίζω
div1.sense: to work stones, Ar.

div1.head: τύκισμα
div1.sense: a working of stones: in pl., κανόνων τυκίσματα, i. e. walls of stone worked by rule, opp. to the rude Cyclopean building, Eur.

div1.head: τύκος
div1.sense: an instrument for working stones with, a masonʼs hammer or pick, Eur.
a battle-axe, Hdt.

div1.head: τυκτά
div1.sense: a Persian word (tacht), which Hdt. translates by τέλειον δεῖπνον βασιλήιον.

div1.head: τυκτός
div1.sense: τυκτὸν κακόν created to be an evil, a born plague, Il.; τυκτὴ κρήνη a fountain made by manʼs hand, Od.: then, like εὔτυκτος, well-made, well-wrought, Hom.

div1.head: τύλη
div1.sense: like τύλος,any callous lump: a porterʼs shoulder, which has grown callous from carrying weights, Ar.
a cushion, bolster, Anth.

div1.head: τυλίσσω
div1.sense: to twist up: to bend: aor1 pass. ἐτυλίχθη Theocr.

div1.head: τύλος
div1.sense: a knot or callus, Xen.; esp. inside the hands, Luc.
a knob or knot; a knobbed bolt, a ship-bolt, trenail, Ar.

div1.head: τυλόω
div1.sense: to make knobby:—Pass., ῥόπαλα σιδήρῳ τετυλωμένα clubs knobbed with iron, Hdt.
to make callous, Xen.:—Pass. to be callous, Theocr.

div1.head: τυλωτός
div1.sense: ῥόπαλα τυλωτά, knobbed clubs, like τετυλωμένα, Hdt.

div1.head: τύμβευμα
div1.sense: a tomb, grave, Soph.
that which is or is to be buried, a body, Eur.

div1.head: τυμβεύω
div1.sense: to bury, entomb, Soph., Eur.
χοὰς τυμβεῦσαί τινι to pour libations on oneʼs grave, Soph.
intr. to dwell entombed, Soph.

div1.head: τυμβήρης
div1.sense: entombed, Soph.
grave-like, sepulchral, Soph.

div1.head: τυμβίτης
div1.sense: in or at the grave, Anth.

div1.head: τύμβος
div1.sense: a sepulchral mound, cairn, barrow, Lat. tumulus, Hom., Hdt., Attic
generally, a tomb, grave, Aesch.; ὥσπερ ἀπὸ τύμβου πεσών like an old grave-man, Ar.
also the tombstone with the figure of the dead, Eur.
of an old man, Eur., Ar.

div1.head: τυμβοῦχος
div1.sense: sepulchral, Anth.

div1.head: τυμβοφόνος
div1.sense: grave-murdering, disturbing the dead, Anth.

div1.head: τυμβοχοέω
div1.sense: to throw up a cairn or barrow, Hdt.

div1.head: τυμβοχόη
div1.sense: the throwing up a cairn, Il.

div1.head: τυμβοχόος
div1.sense: throwing up a cairn or barrow, Anth.
τ. χειρώματα cairns thrown up by work of hand, Aesch.

div1.head: τυμβόχωστος
div1.sense: heaped up into a cairn, high-heaped, Soph.

div1.head: τυμβωρυχία
div1.sense: grave-robbing, Anth.

div1.head: τυμβωρύχος
div1.sense: one who digs up graves, a grave-robber, Ar.

div1.head: τύμμα
div1.sense: a blow, Aesch., Theocr.

div1.head: τυμπανίζω
div1.sense: to beat a drum:—Pass., τυμπανίζεσθαι κατὰ τὰς ἐξόδους to march out to the sound of drums, Strab.
Pass. to be beaten to death, bastinadoed, NTest.

div1.head: τυμπανιστής
div1.sense: of a priestess of Cybele, Dem.

div1.head: τύμπανον
div1.sense: a kettledrum, such as was used esp. in the worship of Cybele, Hdt., Eur.
a drum-stick: generally, a staff, cudgel, Ar.
in Virgil tympana are wheels of solid wood.

div1.head: Τυνδάρεος
div1.sense: Tyndareos or Tyndarus, husband of Leda, Od., Eur.: Attic

div1.head: τυννός
div1.sense: so small, so little, Lat. tantillus, Theocr.

div1.head: τυννοῦτος
div1.sense: tantillus, Ar.; with ι demonstr., τυννουτοσί, -ονί, Ar.; gen. and dat. τυννουτουί, -ῳί, Ar.

div1.head: τυντλάζω
div1.sense: to work in the mud: hence, to grub round the roots of a vine, Ar.

div1.head: τύπανον
div1.sense: a drum, Hhymn., Eur.

div1.head: τυπή
div1.sense: a blow, wound, in pl., Il.

div1.head: τύπος
div1.sense: a blow, Orac. ap. Hdt.
the effect of a blow, the print or impress of a seal, Eur.; στίβου τύπος the print of a footstep, Soph.:— τύποι marks, letters, Plat.:— ὁ τ. τῶν ἵππων the sound of their tread, Xen.
anything wrought of metal or stone, in pl. figures worked in relief, Hdt., Eur.:—then, simply, a figure, image, statue, Hdt., Eur.
τύπος τινός a manʼs form, i. e. himself, Ἱππομέδοντος τ. Aesch.; βραχιόνων τ. βραχίονες, Eur.
general form or character, the type or model of a thing, Plat.:— an example, NTest.
an outline, sketch, draught, Plat.; so, τύπῳ, ἐν τύπῳ in outline, in general, Plat.

div1.head: τυπόω
div1.sense: to form, mould, model, Plat.: so in Mid., Anth.

div1.head: τύπτω
div1.sense: to beat, strike, smite, Il., etc.; ἅλα τύπτον ἐρετμοῖς Od.; ἴχνια τύπτειν to tread in his very track, Il.:—absol., Ζέφυρος λαίλαπι τύπτων the west wind beating, lashing with fury, Il.
metaph., ἄχος κατὰ φρένα τύψε sharp grief smote him to the heart, Il.; ἡ ἀληθηίη ἔτυψε Καμβύσεα Hdt., etc.
Mid., like κόπτομαι, Lat. plangor, to beat oneʼs breast for grief, Hdt.; c. acc. pers. to mourn for a person, Hdt.
Pass. to be beaten, struck or wounded, Hom., etc.; to be stung, Xen.
c. acc. cogn. to receive blows or wounds, ἕλκεα, ὅσσʼ ἐτύπη Il.; τύπτομαι πολλάς (sc. πληγάς) I get many blows, Ar.; so c. dat., καιρίηι (sc. πληγῆι) τετύφθαι Hdt.

div1.head: τυπώδης
div1.sense: like an outline:—adv. -δῶς, summarily, Strab.

div1.head: τύπωμα
div1.sense: that which is moulded, τ. χαλκόπλευρον, of a brazen urn, Soph.: a figure, outline, Eur.

div1.head: τύπωσις
div1.sense: a mould, model, Plut.

div1.head: τυραννεύω
div1.etym: τυραννεύω always in Hdt.; both in Attic Poets, as the metre required.
Pass., fut. mid. τυραννήσομαι in pass. sense
div1.sense: to be a τύραννος, an absolute sovereign or despot, and in aor. to become such, Hdt., etc.: to be a prince or princess, Eur.
c. gen. to be despotic ruler of a people or place, Solon, Hdt., Attic
c. acc. to govern, Luc.:—Pass. to be governed despotically, Hdt., Thuc.
to be tyrannical, imperious, Plat.

div1.head: τυραννίζω
div1.sense: to take the part of tyrants, Dem.

div1.head: τυραννικός
div1.sense: of or for a despotic ruler, royal, princely, Trag.; κύκλος τ. the circle or assembly of kings, Soph.

befitting a tyrant, despotic, imperious, τυραννικὰ φρονεῖν Ar.; τ. ξυνωμοσία in favour of tyranny, Thuc.; τὰ τυραννικά the times of despotic government, Arist.:—adv. -κῶς, Plat.; comp. -ώτερον, Arist.

div1.head: τυραννίς
div1.sense: kingly power, sovereignty, Pind., Trag.
absolute power, despotic rule, Hdt., Attic; τ. ὑμῶν lordship over you, Dem.
pl., αἱ τυραννίδες, οἱ τύραννοι, Hdt.

div1.head: τυραννοκτονέω
div1.sense: to slay a tyrant, Luc.:—Pass. to be slain as a tyrant, Luc.

div1.head: τυραννοκτονία
div1.sense: the slaying of a tyrant, Luc.

div1.head: τυραννοκτόνος
div1.sense: slayer of a tyrant, Luc.

div1.head: τυραννοποιός
div1.sense: a maker of tyrants, Plat.

div1.head: τύραννος
div1.sense: an absolute sovereign, unlimited by law or constitution, Hdt., Aesch., etc.: not applied to old hereditary sovereignties (βασιλεῖαι) such as those of Hom. or of Sparta; for the term rather regards the irregular way in which the power was gained, than the way in which it was exercised, being applied to the mild Pisistratus, but not to the despotic kings of Persia. However, the word soon came to imply reproach, like our tyrant, Plat., etc.
in a wider sense, the tyrantʼs son, or any member of his family, Soph.:—so, ἡ τύραννος was both the queen herself or a princess, Eur.
τύραννος, ον, as adj. kingly, royal, Trag.
imperious, despotic, Thuc.; τύραννα δρᾶν Soph.
div1.etym: τύραννος is prob. from same Root as κύριος, κοίρανος.

div1.head: τυραννοφόνος
div1.sense: slaying tyrants, Anth.

div1.head: τυρβάζω
div1.sense: to trouble, stir up, Lat. turbare, Ar.: —Pass., τ. περί τι to be troubled about a thing, Ar.

div1.head: τύρβη
div1.sense: disorder, tumult, Lat. turba, Xen.

div1.head: τύρευμα
div1.sense: that which is curdled, cheese, Eur.

div1.head: τυρευτήρ
div1.sense: one who makes cheese, of Hermes as god of goatherds, Anth.

div1.head: τυρεύω
div1.sense: to make cheese:—metaph. to make a mess of anything, Dem.

div1.head: Τύριος
div1.sense: of Tyre, Tyrian, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: Τυρογλύφος
div1.sense: cheese-scooper, a mouse, Batr.

div1.head: τυρόεις
div1.sense: like cheese: τυρόεις (sc. πλακοῦς) , a cheese, Theocr.

div1.head: τυρόκνηστις
div1.sense: a cheese-scraper, cheese-grater, Ar.

div1.head: τυρόνωτος
div1.sense: cheese-backed, spread with cheese, Ar.

div1.head: τυροποιέω
div1.sense: to make cheese, Strab.

div1.head: τυροπωλέω
div1.sense: to sell like cheese, Ar.

div1.head: τυροπώλης
div1.sense: a cheesemonger, Ar.

div1.head: Τύρος
div1.sense: Tyre, in Phoenicia, Hdt., etc.

div1.head: τυρός
div1.sense: cheese, Hom., Ar., etc.

div1.head: Τυροφάγος
div1.sense: cheese-eater, name of a mouse in Batr.

div1.head: τυροφόρος
div1.sense: with cheese on it, Anth.

div1.head: Τυρρηνολέτης
div1.sense: destroyer of Tyrrhenians, Anth.

div1.head: Τυρσηνός
div1.sense: Tyrrhenian, Etruscan, Hes., Hdt., Trag.:—also, Τυρσηνικός, ή, όν, Aesch.

div1.head: τύρσις
div1.sense: a tower, Lat. turris, Pind., Xen.

div1.head: τυτθός
div1.sense: little, small, of children, Hom., Aesch.; τ. θηρίον of a bee, Theocr., etc.
τυτθόν, as adv. a little, a bit, Hom.; τ. ἔτι ζώων breathing yet a little, Il.; τ. ἐδεύησεν it wanted a little, Od.:—of the voice, softly, gently, Il.
by a little, scarcely, hardly, Lat. vix; Il.; so neut. pl., Aesch.
τυτθὰ διατμῆξαι, κεάσσαι to cut small, Od.

div1.head: τυφεδανός
div1.sense: one with cloudy wits, a stupid fellow, dullard, Ar.

div1.head: τύφη
div1.sense: a plant used for stuffing beds.

div1.head: τυφήρης
div1.sense: made from τύφη, Anth.

div1.head: τυφλόπους
div1.sense: with blind foot, of Oedipus, Eur.

div1.head: τυφλός
div1.sense: blind, Il., etc.:—c. gen., τ. τινος blind to a thing, Xen.:— τὰ τυφλὰ τοῦ σώματος, i. e. oneʼs back, Xen.:—of the limbs of the blind, τ. πούς, χείρ Eur.; cf. τυφλόπους.
of things, blind, dark, obscure, Aesch., Soph.; τ. σπιλάδες blind rocks, Anth.
of channels, blind, i. e. closed, choked with mud, Plut.
adv., τυφλῶς ἔχειν πρός τι to be blind to it, Plat.

div1.head: τυφλόστομος
div1.sense: with blind mouth, of rivers, Strab.

div1.head: τυφλότης
div1.sense: blindness, Plat.

div1.head: τυφλόω
div1.sense: to blind, make blind, Hdt., Eur.:— Pass. to be or become blind, Hdt., Eur.
metaph. in Pass., μόχθος τετύφλωται is baffled, Pind.; τῶν μελλόντων τετύφλωνται φραδαί wisdom is blind as to the future, Pind.

div1.head: τύφλωσις
div1.sense: a making blind, blinding, Isocr.

div1.head: τυφλώττω
div1.sense: to be blind, Luc.

div1.head: τυφογέρων
div1.sense: an old man dim and dull with age, a dullard, dotard, Ar.

div1.head: τῦφος
div1.sense: smoke, vapour, Anth.:—metaph. conceit, vanity, Plut.

div1.head: τυφόω
div1.sense: to wrap in smoke; metaph. in perf. pass. τετύφωμαι, to be in the clouds, to be crazed, demented, Plat., Dem.

div1.head: Τυφωεύς
div1.sense: Typhoeus or Typhos, a giant buried by Zeus in Cilicia, Il., Pind.

div1.head: Τυφωνικός
div1.sense: tempestuous, NTest.

div1.head: τυφωνοειδῶς
div1.sense: like a whirlwind, Strab.

div1.head: Τυφῶν
div1.sense: Typhon, son of Typhoeus and father of the Winds, Hes.

div1.head: τύφω
div1.sense: to raise a smoke, καπνὸν τ. Hdt.:—absol. to smoke, Soph.
trans. to smoke out, τοὺς σφῆκας Ar.
metaph., καπνῶι τ. πόλιν to fill the town with smoke, Ar.
to consume in smoke, to burn slowly, Eur.:—Pass. to smoulder, Eur.:—metaph., τυφόμενος πόλεμος smouldering, but not yet broken out, Plut.; so of concealed love, Anth.

div1.head: τυφώς
div1.sense: a whirlwind, typhoon, Aesch., etc.

div1.head: Τυφώς
div1.sense: Τῡφώς, ῶ, ὁ contr. for Τῦφωεύς, q. v.
as appellat. τῡφώς, gen. τυφῶ, dat. τυφῶι, a whirlwind, typhoon, Aesch., etc.

div1.head: τυχαῖος
div1.sense: accidental, chance, Plut.

div1.head: τύχη
div1.sense: the good which man obtains (τυγχάνει) by the favour of the gods, good fortune, luck, success, Theogn., Hdt., etc.; σὺν τύχῃ Soph.; θείᾳ τύχῃ, Lat. divinitus, Hdt., etc.:— hence Τύχη was deified, like Lat. Fortuna, Τύχη Σώτειρα Pind.; T. Σωτήρ Aesch.
generally, fortune, chance, good or bad, in sg. and pl., Hdt., Attic
rarely of positive ill fortune, ἢν χρήσωνται τύχῃ, i. e. if they are killed, Eur.; τύχῃ by ill-luck, Antipho.

esp., ἀγαθὴ τ. Aesch., etc.; in dat. ἀγαθῇ τύχῃ "in Godʼs name, " Dem., etc.; by crasis, τύχἀγαθῇ Ar.;—this formula was also introduced into treaties, like Lat. quod felix faustumque sit, Λάχης εἶπε, τύχῃ ἀγαθῇ τῶν Ἀθηναίων ποιεῖσθαι τὴν ἐκεχειρίαν Decret. in Thuc.:—so ἐπʼ ἀγαθῇ τύχῃ Ar., etc.
Adverbial usages, τύχῃ by chance, Lat. forte, forte fortuna, Soph., etc.; ἀπὸ τύχης Arist.; ἐκ τύχης Plat.; διὰ τύχην Isocr., etc.; κατὰ τύχην Thuc., etc.
a chance, hap, accident, Aesch., Soph., etc.; τῆς τύχης, τὸ ἐμὲ τυχεῖν . . ! what a piece of ill-luck, that . . ! Xen.; mostly of mishaps, misfortunes, Aesch., etc.

div1.head: τυχηρός
div1.sense: lucky, fortunate, Aesch.:—adv. -ρῶς, Ar.

div1.head: τυχόντως
div1.etym: adverb from aor2 part. of τυγχάνω
div1.sense: by chance, Arist.

div1.head: τωθάζω
div1.sense: to mock, scoff or jeer at, flout, Hdt., Ar.: —Pass. to be jeered, Plat.
absol. to jeer, Ar.

div1.head: τωθασμός
div1.sense: scoffing, jeering, Arist.

div1.head: τῷ
div1.etym: dat. sg. neut. of ὁ, ἡ, τό, used absol.
div1.sense: therefore, in this wise, thereupon, Hom.
τῷ; for τίνι; dat. sg. of τίς; who?
τῳ, enclit. for τινί, dat. sg. of τις, some one.

div1.head: τώς
div1.sense: demonstr. adv., so, in this wise, Hom., Hes., Aesch.
Doric = οὗ, where, Theocr.
